PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: SPECIAL MINISTER OF STATE; LEADER OF THE HOUSE

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the following amendment to standing order 112 be adopted for the remainder of this session:
Petition to be lodged with Clerk
Standing order 112 be amended to read-
112. Every petition shall be lodged with the Clerk by 5 p.m. on the working day previous to the meeting of the House at which it is proposed that it be presented.

Standing order 112 currently requires that every petition shall be lodged with the Clerk at least three hours previous to the meeting of the House for which it is proposed that it be presented. With the recent dramatic increase in the number of petitions being lodged, it has become increasingly difficult for the Table Office to check petitions for certification and to prepare the announcement within the lodgment cut-off time allowed by the standing order. The average number of petitions per sitting day has increased steadily over the last decade-from 25 in 1975 to 45 in 1985. At the autumn sittings of this year the daily average rose to 52 petitions per day, but for the first week of these Budget sittings the daily average rose to 148. Yesterday 214 petitions were lodged and the system was finally unable to cope.

By moving this motion today I hope to provide some temporary relief for those involved in processing petitions. If, as appears likely, the current trend continues or worsens, a more permanent solution may have to be pursued. In any event, this and other problems related to petitions have been raised by the Standing Committee on Procedure and will be further canvassed when the Committee's report is debated in the House later in these sittings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst this matter is raised as a matter of procedure, the reality is that the Government has made such a mess of running the country that people naturally are resorting to every possible process in order to register their complaints. It really is appalling that the average citizen finds himself almost unable to get through the obfuscation that the Government creates around listening to the cries of ordinary Australians. The whole problem is that all that citizens can do is to send in petitions. So what is the Minister for long lunches doing? He comes into the House today and says: `Let us shovel those petitions off. We do not want to read them. We are not interested in them. We are not worried about the average Australian. We live up here in the glorious obscurity of Parliament House. Everybody out there in the real world can try the best they can'. But what chance have they got? The Government says: `No, you have to put your petitions in earlier. We are not going to consider them. We will not act on them. They are not going to be considered by us'. No Minister who has any responsibility for the running of government has a chance on earth of considering anything at all that citizens say.

SPEECH.PARA: What has happened is that the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) has come in here this morning, all pious and terribly sombre, and has said that this is really just a matter of implementing the recommendations in the report of the Standing Committee on Procedure. He has played it down. He has said we should not worry about it, that it does not matter. But the reality is that petitions are one of those sacred rights of the people of Australia. It is one means by which the average Joe and the average Mabel, if they have a bit of concern, can hopefully get their real pleas-I emphasise that a petition is a plea from the average person-through to big government to ask: `Please will you help me?' This Government is so remote and lacking in concern about the average citizen that it is seeking to change the procedures and play them down so that nobody will know what is going to happen to them. I accept the reality that there are difficulties in the procedures. I hope that when the Procedure Committee is considering the matter of petitions it finds some way to get through to the steel-hearted soul of the Special Minister of State. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) might have no heart. We know that he has no common sense or leadership. But surely the Special Minister of State, with his steel-hearted physiognomy, will finally accept that, when those people out there in the community want to plead to get some of the malfunctions of their Government corrected, they want to be able to get through to him and have him listen to them.

The Opposition will not oppose the change but, for goodness sake, I hope that the Government realises that petitions really express the increasing despair of the average Australian at the morass in which he finds himself, whether with the fringe benefits tax, the downgrading in our AAA borrowing rating, or the problems of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford) trying to have his name blazoned across the nation through radio stations in his own State or elsewhere-or was it perhaps the Casey or John Laws program? The reality is that the Government has to listen to people. The reality of this move is that the Government once again has had registered the concern of a lot of people about the direction in which Australia is going at present. We all know what the result will be when the next election comes around. In the meantime, people are trying to make sure that they register with the Government that there is a need for change. We accept for the time being the adoption of this sessional order. However, we believe it to be more appropriate that the Government listen to the pleas of the people of Australia. If it did so, hopefully it would change dramatically most of its present policies.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed from 16 September, on motion by Mr Keating:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Carlton had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after ``That'' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for-
(1) the failure of the Budget to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems, namely:
(a) the record and rising level of overseas debt;
(b) excessively high levels of government spending and taxation;
(c) an inflation rate 4 times the average of our major trading partners;
(d) interest rates once again approaching 20%;
(e) a wages policy that does not take account of the capacity of individual enterprises to pay, and
(f) the pernicious effects of the anti-business, anti-investment taxes such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, and
(2) the loss of Australia's AAA international credit rating following the failure of the Budget'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not come as a surprise to those listening to know that the National Party of Australia does not support the Australian Labor Party's 1986-87 Budget proposals. It is obvious that we are not being negative, as we cannot back something which fails to meet the needs of contemporary Australia. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) mentioned that the National Party and the Liberal Party of Australia in government would implement six major changes of direction to turn around the Australian economy. He referred to the need to reduce government spending, taxation and union power, and to provide incentive for employees, to encourage overseas investment and to improve our transport and communications systems. I wholeheartedly back what the Leader of the Opposition has said.

SPEECH.PARA: People throughout my electorate of Fisher will be hit hard by what can only be described as the Keating-Hawke tax and kick Budget. There is only a token gesture of cutting expenditure while large sections of the community have been hurt. There is a general consensus-if I might be excused for using that much discredited word-that the Budget has done little to address the long term problems facing Australia. It is a case of too little, too late.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order. We are debating a change to the lodgment of petitions. The honourable member has said nothing about that.
—Order! I am afraid that the honourable member has not been listening. I have already put that question and it has been passed. We are now considering appropriations.

—The honourable member is still asleep. It is too early for him. Let me give examples of what some groups have been saying about the Budget effort of the Treasurer (Mr Keating). The Australian Merchant Bankers Association expressed deep disappointment that the Government had failed to keep to its trilogy commitment to control the growth of public sector spending. The Master Builders Federation of Australia Inc. expressed doubts about the Government's ability to meet the deficit target. The Australian Federation of Construction Contractors accused the Treasurer of hypocrisy. Some of the most perceptive remarks came from the Macquarie Bank Ltd. It said that a number of severe reservations may be raised about the Budget and its figuring. The bank has correctly stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Overall the deficit has been achieved in a less than satisfactory way with too much reliance on tax increases rather than expenditure restraint.

This Labor Government is in deep trouble. It knows that. One of Australia's most respected political commentators, Wallace Brown, saw fit to head his column in the Courier-Mail of 30 August with the words: `A long, hard road to sell the Budget'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hard labour.
—It is hard labour, as the honourable member for Parkes points out. How right Wallace Brown is. One cannot sell the unsalable.

SPEECH.PARA: Just what has the Budget achieved? The time-honoured socialist trilogy of higher tax and higher inflation, and even higher levels of unemployment will certainly result. On the taxation side of the ledger, Australians should now be aware that the Government's increased Medicare and fuel levies-these are more broken promises-and sales taxes on goods such as flavoured milk, fruit juices and other items, will quickly erode any anticipated benefits from Labor's delayed taxation cuts. It is little more than one step forward and two steps back. The 10 per cent sales tax on flavoured milk and fruit juices amounts virtually to a tax on the health of the children of Australia, who are the main consumers of these products.

Road users especially have been hijacked by this Government, with over 60c in every dollar spent by them now going into the Government's coffers. Fuel excise has been increased from about 6c per litre to almost 24c per litre while at the same time Labor has steadfastly refused to pass on the large decline in world oil prices. The new 3c per litre levy on petrol and diesel fuel will reap a further $625m for the Government.

Where will it all end? The Treasurer has the distinction of building on his record as the highest taxing Treasurer in Australia's history. His fourth Budget will collect some 25.5 per cent of gross domestic product in tax, compared with 25.2 per cent last year and 25 per cent in 1984-85. For the second year in succession, the Government has broken its promise not to increase the total tax take. Labour will now gain an extra $1.4 billion in added taxation revenue this year. In addition, Australia's inflation rate will remain significantly higher than that of our major trading partners. In the June quarter it was more than treble the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average, and more than 16 times that of our main trading partner, Japan. The Budget is not likely to improve this situation.

Our unemployed also received more bad news, with the Treasurer admitting that unemployment was most likely to rise during 1986-87, with Australia's youth hardest hit. In some parts of my electorate about 1 in 3 young people have had to join Labor's dole queues.

TALK.START.PARA: —A tragedy.

—It is a tragedy for the young people of Australia. Another aspect of the problem is that the average duration of unemployment among full time workers has increased from 40.4 weeks in June 1983 to 55.4 weeks in June 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government simply does not have the answers and the Budget can be described only as an abject failure in almost every respect. Our dropping dollar is set to join the ranks of dubious currencies such as those of Ethiopia, Argentina and the Monopoly board. The London Financial Times was quick to see through the Keating rhetoric with a front page story on 21 August headed `A$ slides on doubts over budget figures'. The article stated:
Initial market enthusiasm for the . . . Budget turned sour yesterday as scepticism grew over the Government's economic forecasts.

Government expenditure under the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer has increased in real terms by 3.9 per cent a year, reaching mammoth proportions. The Government's own rubbery and over-optimistic figures estimate total Budget outlays will be $74.1 billion compared with actual spending in the previous year of less than $70 billion, an increase of 6.9 per cent. On the other hand, the Opposition is committed to a spending freeze during its first three years in government. As the Leader of the Opposition said, our policy on restricting government expenditure will make possible the complete removal of the Budget deficit, a reduction in the Commonwealth's overseas debt and a reduction in the total tax burden. Compare this with Labor's record of more spending, more debt and more tax.

Since Federation all governments had allowed Australia to accumulate a total foreign debt of less than $23 billion until Labor came to office. With less than three years of irresponsible Labor administration this almost trebled to $65 billion in the last year. It is tipped that in 1986-87 our foreign debt will balloon to a figure in excess of $90 billion. That is more than $6,000 for every man, woman and child in Australia. Nothing much has been done to boost exports, and Labor's fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, and superannuation tax will remain, along with the vicious assets test on our senior citizens. There is no longer any reward for initiative, enterprise and hard work.
Clearly, Labor has given the sign that it cannot properly manage the Australian economy. As the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) stated following the Budget:
Keating . . . displayed the death rattle of a government with no hope, no ideas and no future.

The Hawke-Keating Budget is a fraudulent document, based on an excess of optimism, fairy tale predictions, unrealistic expectations, and the desire to trick the public. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer stand condemned for their duplicity and deceit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) obviously subscribes to the view that one should never let the facts get in the way of a good story. He must be one of the only honourable members in this chamber who cannot see the benefits that will flow to the Australian people from the Budget brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I will go quickly to some points to illustrate what I mean. Time and again we hear those on the other side say that this is a deceitful Budget, that the information provided in the Treasurer's estimates in the Budget generally are based on rubbery figures, rubbery assertions, and so on. That is nothing but wishful thinking on the part of those opposite. If one looks at the proud record of this Government over the last three years under this Treasurer one will see that those statements amount to nothing more than hot air. I seek leave to table a document which indicates a particular point I wish to address.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This document looks at the trilogy the Government put in place over the last three or four years. It clearly indicates that we have made one error, and that is in a projection for the 1986-87 Budget. I refer to the increase in tax revenue as a proportion of gross domestic product. The 1984-85 outcome was projected to be 25.3 per cent. It was met under our trilogy of commitments. In the 1985-86 Budget, 25.2 per cent was budgeted for; the actual outcome was 25 per cent. The projection was met. For 1986-87, 25 per cent is projected, and this is the only time under the trilogy that our commitment will not be met. It will miss by a miserable 0.5 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the reductions in the proportion of GDP over the life of the Parliament, we see that the outcome in 1984-85 was 3.2 per cent. In the 1985-86 Budget the projection was 2.1 per cent and the result was 2.5 per cent. We have budgeted in the 1986-87 Budget for 1.4 per cent. The deficit is the most important and crucial factor here. The deficit in 1984-85 was $6,746 billion. Honourable members must not forget that we are talking about a deficit that has fallen from the $9 billion plus inherited from the former Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), when he had the reins of power, to $6.74 billion. That says something about our achievements in our very first year. In 1985-86, the outcome was $5,726 billion. What about the outcome predicted for 1986-87? The deficit projected in this Budget is $3.5 billion. Progressively, we have seen the economic policies of this Government, of this Treasurer, take the deficit from the $9 billion we inherited from the present Opposition down to a predicted $3.5 billion in 1986-87. That is based on very real figures and the conservative estimates that have been built into this Budget, not on rubbery or inflated figures. They are conservative estimates that the economists in the newspapers of Australia, in the banks and in the private sector are starting to realise are valid statistics.

That leads to a consideration of how the Budget has been received. We have heard in this place and in other places-the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) gave our caucus a rundown of the reception that he has received while going round Australia-that the Budget has been wonderfully received. The day after the Budget, the Australian Financial Review described it as a `remarkable Budget'. It said:

The Treasurer, Mr Keating has produced a remarkable Budget. He has met the most optimistic of market expectations, maintained a high level of welfare spending, confounded many of the criticisms which the Opposition had signalled in advance and taken the very real political and economic gamble that his measures might not be fully effective in time to save Labor at the next election. But it is also economically responsible and politically honest.

That sums it up. That is a very good reaction to the Budget. What about the mob on the side? As usual, when we give the opportunity to the Leader of the Opposition to tell us what Opposition members would do and what their alternative Budget strategy is, he says that they will repeal the capital gains tax, the fringe benefits tax and all those other things. Honourable members opposite say that they will get away from import parity pricing for oil. The honourable member for Fisher mentioned that a minute ago. He said that we should get away from that, that we should have passed on all the oil revenue decreases that the Australian people have come to expect. That is just great. It is fabulous to do those sorts of things. How will the Opposition pay for all those programs? There is the four-point plan referred to by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) yesterday and the nine-point plan which the National Party had some months ago, which was expanded to an 11-point plan and then to a 14-point plan. It is probably a 150-point plan by now. But where will the money come from? Where will the Opposition find the dollars to pay for all these programs that are going to save the world?

Opposition members are talking about dropping the tax rates even lower than the Government proposes. They talk about a flat tax of 30 per cent, and I even read somewhere about a tax of 24 per cent. How will they pay for all the programs that they still believe they will put in place? It cannot be done. We are waiting to hear.

Interestingly, the honourable member for Fisher also talked about indirect taxes, saying that it was a scandal and shameful that the poor little kids in the street have to worry about the price of their flavoured milk going up by a few cents. What rubbish! The Leader of the Opposition in his response to the Budget said that there would be a greater reliance on indirect taxes if the Opposition got back into power. Where is the sense in it? Where is the consistency? Do the Liberals talk to the National Party?

TALK.START.PARA: —Dangerous.

—It is dangerous, as the honourable member for Dobell says. It will be dangerous if those two start to talk to each other because they will find that their policies do not match. They do not balance in any way. What they propose in all their alternative Budgets is a total blowout. It is hypocrisy. They would present to the people of Australia exactly what they did before-nothing but deceit and a Budget that was totally underestimated. When the people of Australia realised what had happened in the days of the coalition, that lot went out the door.

SPEECH.PARA: More importantly, the people of Australia should refer to the document that has been put out by the Government as a guide to the 1986-87 Commonwealth Budget, because it offers a clear and concise guide to the direction in which the Government proposes to move and the reasons why the decisions in the Budget were taken. No one can do better than to look at the attachment at the back of this document, which talks about recent trends in Australia's major commodity exports.

Members of the National Party should read this over and over again, because they purport to represent those people who would like to export more and more of such commodities as wheat, wool, beef, sugar and barley. If they take the time to look at what is reported in the document, they will see why Australia's terms of trade and balance of payments are in their present position. The reason is historically low prices overseas.

We cannot afford to sit back in this economy and wait for such matters to improve. The Government has to make some decisions within the economy itself and decisions have to be made in the market place to try to improve the situation. It has to be a unified effort from the Government, the community generally and in particular secondary manufacturing industry. They all have to decide for themselves that it is no good continuing to come to government, be it our Government or a government of those on the other side when in power, and saying when times are tough that government has to come to their assistance by putting in tariffs, increasing protectionism or providing subsidies through the steel industry plan type of thing-whatever it happens to be. They have to look at ways in which to improve the situation for every Australian. They have to look at how they, as the industrial base of this great country, can diversify more. They have to look for markets overseas and start to sell their products there.

This Government has embarked upon a `buy Australia' campaign as part of its Budget strategy. I endorse that campaign 150 per cent. I think it is about time that we in this country looked more and more towards buying Australian made products as a substitute for foreign products. In that way the employment opportunities in Australia will be improved.

Having quickly gone through what I consider to be the most positive aspects of the Budget strategy and the Budget itself, in the time remaining to me I would like to make a few comments on what I think the Budget is lacking. Quite frankly, I am a very strong supporter-I make no apology for this-of the belief that what was done in respect of the family allowance did not go far enough. I am of the view that there is too much middle class welfare operating in this country at the present time. We on this side of the House are responsible-indeed it is our political credo, our political philosophy to do this-for looking after those people who are in desperate need. Our philosophy is based upon the redistribution of wealth from those who have it to those who do not, so that everyone can have a reasonable living standard.

The family allowance is a very important area in which to start looking at how this redistribution might occur. We could have a system whereby family allowance is granted to growing families with multiple children, and then we could start looking at how that might apply across the board. In days gone by, when the family allowance was introduced as a social security benefit for those in need, I really do not think it was meant for people on incomes of $30,000, $40,000, $50,000 and $60,000 a year or more, including two-income families. I do not believe it was envisaged that we should be paying out the moneys we are now paying to people who obviously have the financial resources to look after their children.

I would like to look at means testing the family allowance across the board. I think, in fact I suggest, that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), when considering the Budget and our Budget strategy next year, should look at that as one possible way of eliminating a lot of the middle class rorts that occur and should look at how we might help those people in real need. I believe the Budget strategy that we have put in place is a good one and I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking in support of the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87, I would first like to take up a couple of points that the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) made in their speeches on this matter and to correct a myth-it goes very close to what I would call a misleading statement-which is often spread by many honourable members on the other side of this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: We hear so much about the Budget deficit that this Government inherited. The statements really are extremely misleading. In 1982, when the last Budget was brought down by the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) when in government, the deficit was something like $4.3 billion. The Australian Labor Party came to power in early 1983 and, by the time it had had a chance to prepare its Budget in 1983, it had let the deficit blow out to something approaching $8.7 billion. Talk about inheriting a $9.6 billion deficit is a total myth. If we go further we find that the following year, when the Treasurer (Mr Keating)-the one man who wanted to cite these figures-was asked what the Forward Estimates for 1984 were, he said: `They don't matter. We don't even publish those any more. They only matter if they are to our advantage electorally'. The Government ought to give up on this. The fact is that the previous Government's worst effort was a deficit of $4.3 billion in the 1982-83 Budget. That occurred in the year in which we had the worst drought this century, a world-wide downturn and, generally, the economy was not looking good. But the deficit was certainly less than half of the mythical $9.6 billion figure. The honourable member for Macarthur also talked about low commodity prices. I am sure that everyone knows about that. But the Government, instead of trying to blame everything on that, should be saying: `What are we going to do to help those who are suffering as a result of these rising costs, particularly the exporters and the farmers'. But what has the Government done? It has increased fuel prices and other costs which I will return to later.

This Budget is a bit of a pea and thimble trick. We have seen yet again the introduction of higher taxes. We have seen a direct hit on families. But we have seen virtually no cuts in government spending. There has been talk about a tough Budget and so on. But where are the cuts? There are virtually none. We see figures which refer to modest growth. But where on earth will this modest growth occur? By looking at the Budget figures, the only way in which I can see this growth occurring is by a Public Service led recovery. That is the only sector that might have any chance of achieving some growth. The Budget also has a fundamental flaw-that is, wages policy. I know that this has been mentioned previously in this place, but it must be repeated that the fundamental flaw of this Budget is wages policy. While wages continue to grow, while we continue to be in so much trouble, there is no doubt that the Treasurer's dire predictions about the banana republic will become more and more real.

We then come to the question of higher taxes. The Government tries to talk about tax cuts. However, this year the tax collected by the Federal Government will be equal to 25 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product. Last year it was 25.2 per cent and in 1984-85 it was 25 per cent. So taxes are still rising. We can talk about tax cuts, but the overall tax take is still increasing. If we were to give the Treasurer an award, he would get my vote as the world's No. 1 taxer.

What are these new taxes? I have mentioned the tax on fuel. People in country areas in particular rely on fuel, not only for their cars but also for the transport of goods. Everything that comes into the country and everything that is freighted out is affected by the price of fuel. What do we find? The price of fuel has increased by 3c a litre. A couple of weeks after the Budget was brought down, it increased by another 2c a litre. At the beginning of next year, because of indexation, it will increase by another 2c. The Government talks about things being tough. But what has it done? It has made sure that things will be even tougher for those who must bear the brunt of the downturn in world-wide commodity prices. In respect of these fuel price rises, I think we might use the phrase that has been used before-that is, that this Government has turned every petrol pump into a branch of the Australian Taxation Office.

When the Government came to office in 1983, excise was 6c a litre. I seem to recall that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) even made a promise that he would cut fuel prices by 3c a litre if he was elected. Excise is now almost 24c a litre and that fourfold increase does not take into account the increase that will occur shortly.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was the promise he made?
—He promised that he would cut prices by 3c a litre.
—They have gone up 24c.

—Excise has increased from 6c a litre to 24c a litre. The Government's attack on families in this Budget is really quite scandalous. It is the biggest attack on families that I have seen. At a time when there is an economic downturn and families are probably the ones who are feeling it the most, we see that, despite the so-called tax cuts that will be implemented in December, the average Australian family will still be $23.50 a week worse off. Families will be hurt; they will be hit hard. Families will be hit by health costs. The Medicare tax has been increased by 25 per cent. We have seen an increase in chemist prescription charges. Of course, as I have mentioned, all families also have to buy petrol. We have seen the means testing of family allowances for 16- and 17-year olds. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur, said that he would like to see all family allowances means tested. Most honourable members would know that it is when children get to the age of 16 or 17 years that they cost their families the most. We have a crying need in this country for more children to stay at school, but what is the Government doing? It is cutting out family allowances and encouraging people either to get a job or, in many cases because they cannot get a job, to go on the dole. By any analysis, by any commonsense approach, such a move is just plain stupid.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most interesting things in the Treasurer's Budget Speech is how he used the word `cut'. I went through the Budget Speech fairly quickly and I may have missed a couple of instances, but I found that he used the word `cut' at least 25 times. Page 3 of his Budget Speech states in part:
For these reasons, the Budget incorporates a very large cut in spending.
On page 4 in relation to outlays the Treasurer stated:
We have cut back to zero real growth.

That is interesting. In other words, there have been no cuts. I guess this is another example of what one might call Keatingspeak at its worst. They are cuts and yet they are not cuts. In the mind of the Treasurer the word `cut' is one with which he tries to mislead people. What he should be saying is: `We have held growth at its current level. In dollar terms it is increasing but in real terms it is remaining static.' The Treasurer is asking the rest of the community to bear cuts. He has even told the Australian Council of Trade Unions that it should accept cuts. But when it comes to his Government's outlays, his Government's expenditure, there are no cuts.

As time is running short I will repeat briefly what I said earlier. The fundamental flaw in the Budget is without doubt the wages policy. Even the Budget Papers forecast an increase in unemployment. What does the Government do? It goes mealy-mouthed to the ACTU and says: `You can still have a pay rise but it might not be quite the full amount of indexation'. Indexation seems to be one of the few things this country has not learned from the rest of the world. We can do without it. It only builds in inflation and rising unemployment, as the Budget Papers tell us. Yet the Government still does not have the strength of character to say to the union movement `The party is over, fellows; we have told the rest of Australia it is finito', to use that great word. The Government cannot go to its bosses in the trade union and say: `We have to cut wages and you will have to accept a wage freeze'.

The saddest thing about this matter, as my colleagues the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) would be the first to tell us, is that when one talks to Australians one learns that they would accept such an approach. They say: `We know things are tough'. People are worried. Wherever one goes people ask what is going on. They are very uneasy. If the Government only had the strength to say that it wants a wages pause, as the previous Government had the strength to do, I am sure that Australians would go along with it. If the Prime Minister got out of his little ivory tower occasionally and spoke to the real Australians he would find that a wage pause would be acceptable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of the bunker.

—Yes, out of the bunker. In conclusion, this Budget has been a bitter disappointment. The reaction of the media, which the honourable member for Macarthur was quick to quote, was a one-day wonder. Initially the media was conned but it soon woke up, and as it analysed the Budget in more detail it realised that the Budget really was a non-event. As I have said, the Government has talked about the party being over, and this wonderful new word `finito' is coming into use in our language. Despite the use of the word `cut' in the Treasurer's Budget Speech, when we look at the so-called cuts we find there are absolutely none in government expenditure. Yet taxes have been raised even to the point of taxing children, as the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) has mentioned. We are taxing children who buy fruit juice and flavoured milk. There is a tax on what should be the nutritious drinks, the things this Government and all Australians would like to see children encouraged to drink. We will send them off to drink soft drinks which everyone knows are not nearly as healthy for them. Probably the most damning comment on this Budget comes from the former Head of the Treasury, Mr Stone-someone who really knows what he is talking about. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: 1974-75 aside, when measured against the yardstick of the economic crisis confronting Australia today this must truly be one of the worst Budgets by any government during the post-war period.

From the point of view of this side of the House, the Budget has been a bitter disappointment. The Government will rue the day when it built up the expectations of the people of Australia to think that the 1986-87 Budget was to be the cure for our economic ills. Sadly, all Australians will pay, and pay very dearly, for the Government's mismanagement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Budget has been a disappointment for the Tories on the other side of the House. It has been disappointing for them because it has been accepted by the overwhelming majority of Australian people. The honourable member for Wannon (Mr Hawker) very cleverly tried to throw up a smokescreen. But no matter what he does, the Australian people will never forget the inarguable fact that, when this Government came to office, it inherited from the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer, a Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. If we want to judge the success of the Budget, let us not go to biased people such as John Stone. Let us look at what has happened in New South Wales since this Budget came down. Let us forget about Bass Hill and Rockdale. Let us look at the Newcastle City Council elections last Saturday when the people voted solidly for a Labor administration. It is very interesting to remember that in the Newcastle City Council election Labor ran first, Independents ran second and third and trailing miserably behind in fourth position was the Liberal Party of Australia. The people of Newcastle and the Hunter Valley showed what they think of the Liberal Party's answer to the economic problems confronting this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The dollar has stabilised as a result of this Budget. While the United States and British share markets are tumbling, a remarkable buoyancy remains in the money market in Australia. The Liberals and the Nationals have been making whistle-stop tours of my electorate but the crowds they have attracted required accommodation no larger than a telephone booth. They have failed dismally to stir up any concern about this Budget. A chap walked into my office the other day and said: `I do not understand all the economic jargon being preached to us. What has happened to our economy?'. I said: `How much do you earn a week?'. He said: `I earn $400.' I said: `Supposing your right arm fell off. How much would you earn then?'. He said: `I would be lucky to earn half'. That is exactly what has happened in this country. There has been a massive turnaround in our terms of trade. There has been a glut of minerals and agricultural products on world markets, and Australia's primary products and minerals are largely unwanted. The trade war between the United States of America and the European Economic Community has slashed our national income by over $6 billion.

Other speakers have shown how the prices for our minerals and primary products, such as coal, wheat, wool, iron ore, aluminium, beef, sugar and lead have tumbled amazingly. I would say that, taking a guesstimate, the prices for most of these commodities are down by some 35 per cent. The list goes on. All told, there has been a 15 per cent fall in our terms of trade. The same chap said to me: `All right, you have explained it to me simply. Who is to blame for all this?'. I said: `It has been coming for a long time. No one is really to blame. What happened is that some time ago Mr Fraser and Mr Howard decided-with the advantage of hindsight I can say that they were wrong-to pursue a resources boom. They decided that we would not try to compete with overseas manufacturing and that we would place all our eggs in two baskets. They decided that we would place all our hopes on minerals and agriculture and the export of those commodities'. Unfortunately, Fraser and Howard made a mistake and they allowed our manufacturing industries to wind down.

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member will refer to honourable members in the correct form.

—I am sorry-the Leader of the Opposition and the previous Prime Minister. The chap then said to me: Is there a solution to all this?' I said: `Yes, the solution is outlined in the Budget. We must tighten our belts so that we can stay competitive with the rest of the world. Also, we must restructure our industry base so that we can lift our export performance and win back markets. We must buy Australian and reduce our imports'. The chap then said to me: `Yes, we can do those things, and I understand and respect that the Government is trying to do that, but is there any other danger for Australia?'. I said: `Not really, not if we handle the economy responsibly and sensibly, as this Government is doing, but there is a good deal of danger if demagogues mislead voters with an impossible grab-bag of promises'. How economically and politically dishonest are those opposite who promise the world and give not the simplest explanation as to how they will fulfil their ridiculous promises?

SPEECH.PARA: The Leader of the Opposition, who left this Government with a deficit of $9.6 billion, now wants to bat again, and to give Australia a deficit of over $10 billion. But I have this absolutely positive feeling that the Australian people do not want a second batting performance from the person who now occupies the leadership of the Opposition and that they will not give him a second innings. The chap said to me: `Is there a greater danger for Australia?'. I said: `Yes, there is a far greater danger, and that far greater danger is a drift to the extreme right, to fascism'. Consider what happened to other countries which moved to the extreme right to solve their economic ills: During the Great Depression, in Italy, Mussolini had just started to get the trains to run on time when the Depression and the economic ills gave him the chance to establish a dictatorship. We all know that in Germany in 1933, as a result of the economic problems that confronted it, Hitler came to power. As a result of the Depression in Japan, a moderate government was replaced by a government that sought to end its economic problems through militaristic imperialism, and from that we had World War II.

The truth is that this country can solve its problems if we treat all citizens fairly. We can have restraint with equity and restore our economic prosperity. With a fair tax system, an ID card and a fair deal for all Australians, we can restore this nation's health. This Budget has its critics, certainly, but they are few and far between. Most people recognise that this Budget is a budget that is fair to all sectors of society. Extremism in any form is abhorrent to all Australians. People do not want divisions created in our society. The conservatives-those who believe they were born to rule-are trying to establish two divisions within Australian society: They want a creation of one class, namely, the haves, and the creation of a second class, namely, the have-nots. Australians face the spectre of jack-booted conservatives marching throughout Australia disciplining the unions, the unemployed and anyone and everyone who points to their absurd megalomania.

At a time when real wages are at their lowest level in 17 years and big business profits are at their highest level since World War II, we have the Howards, the Copemans and members of the H. R. Nicholls Society running around endeavouring to kneecap workers and to moderate union leaders. While Crean, Kelty and company talk sense, Copeman and his cronies talk nonsense and confrontation. While senior management gains record salary increases and directors' fees rise by up to 34 per cent, we have an absurd attack on wages, working conditions and holiday loadings. Anyone who cannot recognise the benefits derived for this nation as a result of the accord is either blind or demented. Australia has led the world in economic growth. We have led the world in employment growth. We have delivered wage restraint. We have slashed the incidence of industrial disputes. This Hawke Government Budget has the ideal strategy. It is light years ahead of the extremist solutions advocated by the conservatives. Consider the nonsense spoken about holiday leave loadings: When one looks at the figures-I thank Ross Gittins of the Sydney Morning Herald for these figures-one finds that the leave loading applicable to workers in Australia is insignificant really when compared with the leave loading applicable in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. Our average 17 1/2 per cent leave loading compares favourably with the conditions that apply in other countries.

There are perhaps a great number of things we should talk about here, but each speaker is restricted to 10 minutes. I shall tell honourable members on the other side of the House what they are doing. They are frightening the Australian people with extremist talk. The people are being scared out of their pants by the deeds of the New Right, the Copemans of this world, and honourable members opposite are giving us more support than we could hope to gain through any argument out there in the market-place. This is an extremely sensible and extremely responsible Budget. It is the very Budget which is designed to get Australia back to economic health and it is light years ahead of any proposals that honourable members have come up with.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians have all awaited this Budget for the Government's response to what is the deep Australian economic malaise and certainly the trade crisis that we are facing. The national accounts estimates for the June 1986 quarter showed that the economy had entered a very serious recession, much worse than had been previously reported and previously thought. The non-farm gross domestic product fell in each of the last three quarters, being minus 0.6 per cent in the December 1985 quarter and minus 0.2 per cent in both the March and the June 1986 quarters.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians were told we had to tighten our belts. We were told also that our economic problems were due to external forces. It was said that the European Economic Community and the United States of America were to blame for our trouble by corrupting world commodity markets. The fact is that it is this Government which has corrupted the domestic economy, and the Budget has failed to address the real reasons for our economic malaise. These reasons are: The rigid inflexible wage system that Australia is particularly faced with, a massive growth in the public sector over many years, high taxation-particularly high direct taxation-and high government expenditure. Obviously, following this Budget sacrifices will have to be made by some, but not by all Australians. Unfortunately these sacrifices will be borne by the private and the productive sectors of Australia. They will be the ones to suffer. Australia's inflation rate remains well above the inflation rates of our trading partners. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a schedule which shows what these inflation rates are.

At the time of the presentation of the Budget we were faced with a realisation of where Australia is in comparison with the rest of the world and the rest of the productive world. That was given in two graphs that were published in the Australian on 26 June, showing the cost of manufacturing labour at the end of December 1983 and the hours worked per week. SPEECH.PARA: Before the presentation of the Budget Australians were looking for some guidance. We were told to wait for it. I believe the guides to getting economic growth again that we were waiting for in that response were four in number: Firstly, we had to cut taxation in real terms; secondly, we had to cut our expenditure, particularly on programs; thirdly, we had to bring our deficit into a situation where we could balance it within the coming 12 months, that is, 12 months after this; and, fourthly, there should have been a wage freeze until productivity caught up with this. As I tried to indicate, productivity is not one of our main points. The Budget responded in only one regard, and that was in the Budget deficit coming down to the figure of $3.5 billion. TALK.START.PARA: —A bit rubbery.

—It is very rubbery, because the $3.5 billion figure was achieved by actual increases in taxation and hiving off to the private sector such things as health and education costs. In that regard, I believe the Budget has failed dismally. As I say, the deficit was achieved by rigging the figures. In all of this, Labor is trying to tell us that the Budget is a fair one. It argues the success of the accord in reducing real labour costs without taking into account those negative growth figures that I mentioned for the last three quarters or the wages blowout in the early 1970s under the then Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, particularly in the Public Service, and again in the early 1980s. I think we should note that the blowout in the early 1980s was under the jurisdiction of Mr Hawke as President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

I also indicate that, while in office in the last three and a half years, this Labor Government has been the biggest spending government in Australia's history. In its first three years Labor achieved record deficits totalling $20.3 billion. This is a record, even in terms of the last deficit which was recorded by the Fraser Government of some $4.4 billion, which was arrived at because of a severe drought and at a time when a wage pause had been implemented to try to bring that into balance. In all of this we have Labor trying to indicate that there was a real record Budget deficit of $9.6 billion. I say once and for all those Labor Government members who do not seem to understand economic philosophy that the $9.6 billion was never a deficit; it was a Forward Estimates first bid. The only one to compare it with was the deficit of $4.4 billion for 1982-83. It is interesting to note that at June 1986 Australia's gross external debt stood at some $88 billion. We should note the growth in that figure over the years under Labor, but more particularly in the last three and a half years. It is recorded that Australia took nearly 82 years to arrive at a net overseas debt of $22 billion.
—How many years?

—It was over 82 years of federation. In the last three years the Government has been able to triple that figure by the same amount. As at the end of 1985-86 the net debt stood at $66 billion, which is three times greater than it was three years previously.
—Shameful!

—It is shameful. It is an indictment of the treasurership and the people in whose hands the economic responsibility is placed, who tried to hide that fact by saying that it is a result of external factors. These are the internal factors that are very important. The public sector growth figure has grown from 14 per cent of Australia's net external debt in June 1983 to 34 per cent at the end of 1985. Clearly these economic indicators paint a sorry picture of the Australian economy and the prospects for Australia's export sector, the sector on which Australia has to rely if it is to pull itself out of this economic morass. The pictures are there and the economic indicators are there, but the Budget did not address them.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians were looking forward to a Budget which would cut government spending and lift the constraints on enterprise, but Australians have been disappointed by this Budget. I must say to the Government that Australians have been disappointed because the Budget was flawed in its assumptions, flawed in its approach and flawed in its preparation. It is a taxing Budget, and that is what we have to remember. It is a taxing Budget which increases by some 13 per cent the pressure on direct taxation, in spite of an inflation forecast of 8 per cent. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) says, it is a taxing, not an axing Budget. At this time it is precisely the wrong remedy for Australia's economic ills. It is not a time when the Government should be putting out its greedy hand and taking more; it is a time when it should be measuring growth in terms of a reduction, not an increase, in taxation.

The lowest deficit figure of $3.5 billion sounds good, but it has been brought about, as I said, by lifting taxes by some $1.4 billion and it is based on the heroic assumptions about economic growth and employment projections, all of which have been questioned by the private sector and many Australians. The Budget forecast of 2.25 per cent growth in GDP for 1986-87 is, of course, overly optimistic, particularly when one judges it in relation to performance in the December, March and June quarters of this year, and it requires a June on June growth of over 5 per cent.

Most of Australia's growth is expected to come from net exports of 1.75 per cent. However, it is clear that this will result more from driving the economy into recession and reducing imports than from the J-curve effect. With its added-on taxation, the Budget gives no incentive to manufacturers to export, and very little incentive to import substitutes.

Despite the fall in imports associated with the recession, the current account deficit is forecast in the Budget to be around $14.6 billion, which will be worse still than the record of the previous year. The Budget forecast of 8 per cent inflation confirms the view that inflation will remain high, particularly in comparison with our overseas competitors.

The continued large external imbalance and the forecast high inflation rate will keep interest rates high and continue to make the dollar vulnerable. We saw the effects immediately before the Budget when the dollar collapsed as a result of high inflation, the record high current account deficit, industrial award increases, indexation and superannuation decisions. That was followed by a further downward march as a result of the Budget itself.

When we take into consideration a 1986-87 current account deficit of at least $14 billion, a forecast inflation rate of 8 per cent and the 10 per cent depreciation of the dollar since June 1986, Australia is looking at a gross level of external debt at June 1987 of something in excess of $110 billion. I do not want to compare that with the debts of South American countries, but this debt will be the equivalent of nearly $7,000 per person in Australia. It is clear that the Budget has failed to address this country's fundamental economic problem.

Indeed, the Government has sought even in this debate to divert attention from the disastrous Budget by claiming again international corruption, while it sweeps under the carpet its own corruption of the Australian economy over the past three and a half years. It diverts attention from the domination of the Government by the kingmakers of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Mr Crean, Mr Kelty, Mr Halfpenny and Mr MacBean, by ranting against the New Right. We heard a short while ago of an attempt to try to stampede the Australian people by talking about the terror that might be associated with such a move, and that attempt has been repeated in this debate. More importantly, the Government tries to buy off the union leadership with free fact-finding trips to Europe. For what purpose have these trips been arranged and just what are they intended to achieve?

During the course of the past three weeks uranium has been raised as a major social issue. Again, the purpose has been to try to divert attention from the real issues of the Budget. I wish to deal with some of the trade specifics. As a result of a suggestion by the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins), the Government, in the Budget, lifted the ban on sales of uranium to France to sell its $66m stockpile. However, it did not take the further step of deciding that all exports of uranium would be good. The House will be aware that some uranium in Australia is good and that other uranium is bad. In some cases the ACTU can still dictate whether the export of uranium will be banned.

The Kakadu National Park comprises almost 20,000 square kilometres in the Alligator Rivers area and, I am sure that we can all agree that it is a truly beautiful part of Australia. It is rich in all sorts of minerals, but particularly in uranium.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to mine it.

—The honourable gentleman should not talk to me about that. Let him remember that his own Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wanted to mine it. If I were the honourable gentleman, I would sit in my place and keep quiet while trying to take a few lessons. Economic knowledge is not a high point of the honourable gentleman's fortes nor one of the Government's. I suggest that the honourable gentleman sits down and listens. We should all know that the Kakadu National Park is rich in all sorts of minerals, but especially in uranium. Last year, its two relatively small operational mines exported $428m worth of yellowcake. That is regarded as good uranium. A radiometric survey carried out from the air over the Kakadu region by the Department of Mines and Energy in 1982 found that there is $40 billion worth of proven uranium deposits at current prices, and in 1982 dollar values. This does not include the other mineral wealth in the area.

SPEECH.PARA: Active mining exploration was banned in the Kakadu region 14 years ago, because of the area's proposed future as Aboriginal land and as a national park. This is holding up exports from Australian mines such as Pancontinental's Jabiluka and Denison's Koongarra. Both mines have reached agreement with traditional owners and they are anxious to proceed. Obviously these owners, together with the miners, recognise that mining, sacred rites and national parks are not necessarily incompatible. Yesterday the Prime Minister said that there would be no new mining in existing stages 1 and 2 of Kakadu, and that in relation to stage 3 there would be no mining of uranium. So we get the hard socialist Left ensuring that their theories prevail over and above economic logic. By responsibly mining the uranium in Kakadu, the Government could quite easily wipe off a significant proportion of Australia's overseas debt. One must ask whether the Government is serious about trying to rectify Australia's economic problems.

In his address to the nation in June, the Prime Minister announced the new small exporters scheme and the high technology exporters scheme. But as a result of the Budget, the new small exporters scheme is redundant. The high technology exporters scheme was given a minuscule budget of just $1m and will help only a handful of high technology exporters, the people whom we want so desperately in this country.

The mixed credit scheme operated by Austrade has had its budget reduced. Also, as a result of the Budget, the overall expenditure on export development schemes has declined massively to $92m. These moves will not enthuse exporters, who are relying on some assistance, given that during the last three years of coalition government under Mr Fraser export incentives averaged $267m. With Australia's trade in the Middle East decreasing, the Budget also closed Austrade's offices in Bahrain, Dubai and Kuwait which have been important windows for Australia in its efforts to find a place in that fast developing market. Now the United States of America will be quite happy to step into our markets, having just commissioned a $200,000 study into market opportunities for United States sheepmeat in the Middle East.

So within the trade portfolio itself, the Budget has failed clearly to address the current trade and economic crisis facing Australia. It has failed to grasp opportunities to reinvigorate our export and trade sectors, which is something that the private sector is more than willing to do. It has failed also to expand Australia's intelligence in world markets, particularly the Middle East.
