SPEECH.PARA: Listening to the Opposition, one would think that all the problems in Australia, including those responsible for the uncompetitive nature of Australian industry, are the fault of the workers. It is about time that the Opposition and manufacturing industries in Australia faced a few hard facts. There are a few exceptions, but overall Australian manufacturers have been content to hide behind protective tariffs and quotas, taking full advantage of government tax incentives, subsidies and other forms of assistance, and to give nothing in return. They have not looked to innovation, technological change and improved managerial and marketing techniques. Still less have they sought to pull their weight by investing part of their profits in research and development.

The result is that Australian manufacturing industry has stagnated. It has become less and less competitive on the domestic market and almost totally ineffectual on the international market. To compound the problem, rather than being honest with itself and with the Australian public, our manufacturing industry has sought to divert public opinion from the real source of its problem-its own incompetence, ineptitude and shortsightedness-by putting the blame on workers and rising wage costs. This has been done at a time when the floating of the Australian dollar and its subsequent devaluation has given the industry an unparalleled opportunity to become more competitive on the domestic and international markets. The Australian dollar has been devalued by something like 40 per cent, which gives our manufacturing industry a 40 per cent comparative cost advantage. If industry cannot export and take advantaged of the market with this devaluation then it should have a very good look at itself.
As the Australian Manufacturing Council admitted in its 1984 statement to the Economic Planning Advisory Council:
The Australian economy has grown up around a framework of government intervention in industries . . . too great a concentration on tariff rates and quotas.

This is, of course, essentially a short term band-aid approach in that it seeks to protect our manufacturing industry rather than to develop it. It is an approach which has led to defending the status quo, protecting industry from the threat and challenge of innovation and technological change. What is needed is a more dynamic approach which pushes the Australian manufacturing industry towards innovation and change. The key to this is research and development. A key aspect of Australia's existing export trade is that exports are heavily weighted towards a limited number of unprocessed mineral and agricultural commodities which we are able to deliver to a limited number of customer countries. Mineral and agricultural exports together account for about 65 per cent of our total exports, of which some 30 per cent go to Japan. As recent events have so clearly illustrated, there is every indication that these exports face a most uncertain future. We would be complete idiots to think that we can continue to place all, or even most, of our eggs in the primary industry basket.

In the 1890s our nation experienced a remarkable burst of creative energy. We were pioneers in agricultural technology, refrigeration techniques, welding, ferro-concrete construction, pharmaceuticals, medical technologies and scientific instrumentation. By 1900 Australia was a world leader in technology and our per capita income was the highest in the world. Sadly, we did not use our initial success as a springboard for continued industrial growth. Instead, we were content to rely on our agricultural and mining industries, and allowed our manufacturing industries to remain poorly developed and immature. Other nations, however, have made the successful transition from a resource-based economy to one based on intellectual skill and the development of an efficient and innovative manufacturing industry.

One such nation, comparable in many ways to Australia, is Sweden. Just over 100 years ago, about the same time that we witnessed that extraordinary burst of creative technology, Sweden was emerging from an agricultural economy based on subsistence farming. It was then one of the poorest countries in Europe and a large proportion of its population was emigrating because they lacked the opportunity to make a decent living. Like Australia, Sweden's emergence as an industrial nation was based on its raw material resources. Like Australia, too, Sweden went through an economic crisis in the mid-1970s. There had been a cost explosion, with a 40 per cent increase in wages over a two-year period. The decline in export income, coupled as it was to the world-wide increase in oil prices, resulted in a major recession. Today, the situation is in striking contrast. Sweden's balance of trade is favourable, its budget deficit, though considerably larger than Australia's, is declining, unemployment is down to 3 per cent, and the foreign debt is being reduced.

The key to all this is the great success of the Swedish manufacturing industry, particularly in the export field. Significantly, the Swedish Government in 1984 decreed that 10 per cent of all profits made by industrial organisations should be deposited with the Bank of Sweden. These renewable funds, amounting to approximately $A2 billion, are only now becoming available to the companies on condition that they are used for purposes of research and development, employee education and employee retraining.

There are four major identifiable elements in Sweden's economic recovery. First, there were two currency devaluations-one in 1981 and the second in 1982-amounting to about 30 per cent overall. Secondly, there was a major restructuring of Swedish industry, involving close collaboration between the Government, business management and the trade unions. Amongst other things, this involved the closure of the Swedish shipbuilding industry and the Swedish textile industry, but it also involved massive retraining and re-employment programs, which meant that workers changed jobs rather than losing them and that they continued to reside in the same towns, cities and regions. There is an awareness on the part of unions that they will benefit from the 10 per cent of all profits paid by Swedish manufacturers into renewal funds. Such a program, I might add, would not have been possible were it not for the policy of worker participation in Swedish industry, as embodied, for example, in the 1977 Act on employee participation in decision making. Such an approach to industrial relations is in stark contrast to that proposed by the New Right and its many supporters, tacit or otherwise, sitting on the Opposition benches. The Swedish model, based as it is on national negotiation, points the way to the future. The New Right's approach of mindless confrontation can but lead down the path of managerial anarchy and the ultimate destruction of Australian society.

The third element of the recovery is the expanded investment in research and development by both industry and government. It is this element especially which I would like to emphasise. Expenditure on research and development in Sweden is among the highest in the world, being approximately 2.3 per cent of gross domestic product. In Australia, by comparison, expenditure on research and development is only one per cent of GDP. When one compares government expenditure to private sector expenditure, the figures are even more telling. In Australia, our figure of one per cent GDP expenditure on research and development is made up of 0.8 per cent government expenditure and a paltry 0.2 per cent private sector expenditure. In Sweden, by contrast, the 2.3 per cent GDP expenditure is made up of 1 per cent Government expenditure-only slightly more than our Government's expenditure-and 1.3 per cent private sector expenditure. There is the difference. The Swedish manufacturing industry outspends its Australian counterpart by more than 6:1. Is this the reason why the world drives Volvos and Saabs, rather than Holdens? Is this the reason why we import so many more manufactured goods from Sweden than they do from us? To make matters worse, our meagre efforts in research and development actually declined during the 1970s and early 1980s, the same period in which Sweden so dramatically lifted its game. During the early 1980s, our manufacturing industry was outlaying on research and development only 40 per cent of what it had been doing during the 1960's.

Fortunately, things are beginning to change, thanks to the initiatives of the present Hawke Labor Government. The Government's response to the failure of Australian manufacturers to look to their future, and the future of all Australians, has centred on the 150 per cent tax concession for firms spending money on research and development. This policy was introduced in the 1985 Budget, and I am pleased to note that it has been retained in this year's Budget. The results to date are encouraging. Approximately 1,000 firms are currently taking advantage of the scheme, and 1985-86 tax concessions are likely to cost the Government something of the order of $100m. The pay-off is that spending on research and development by those companies is anticipated to rise by $200m.

To use another set of figures, private sector expenditure on research and development has risen from the absurdly low level of 0.2 per cent of GDP in 1981 to about 0.3 per cent in 1985, and the Government initiative should get the figure up to 0.4 per cent or even 0.5 per cent by 1987. That will do nothing more than get us back to where we were in the late 1960s. In other words, we are still a long way behind just about every other country we could reasonably use by way of comparison. Clearly, it is now up to Australian manufacturers to shake off their inertia and apathy and to pull their weight. Sweden has pointed the way. There is no reason why we cannot pursue the same path.

The 150 per cent tax concession scheme for research and development expenditure is but one component of this Government's budgetary program for technology development. Other programs include the grants for industrial research and development scheme, which will provide up to 50 per cent funding for approved research and development projects, with the emphasis on assisting small, innovative start-up firms; the continued commitment to the former Australian industrial research and development incentives scheme; the National Industry Extension Service; the management and investment companies program; and of course, the continuation of the steel industry plan. All in all, the 1986-87 budgetary allocation for industry, technology and commerce programs amounts to $380m, which represents a rise of 7.6 per cent on actual expenditure in 1985-86. I commend these measures to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seldom in my years in Parliament have I seen a Budget which has been so signally unsuccessful. In all the pre-Budget presentation to the public we were led to believe that a national disaster was on our hands and that the Budget would bring some stability to the exchange rate, to the lenders to this nation and to the performing sector. Instead of that, we have been saddled with a Budget which is in error in its presentation of a deficit of $3.5 billion and which is grossly optimistic in its assessment of economic growth and of government spending levels. As a consequence, the general public's perception of the Budget is poor and the response by commentators and those responsible for economic decisions is negative, so much so that Ministers are now walking round saying, `We will have to have another try at it.' Three Ministers have already said that publicly, fewer than 10 days after the Budget came down.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning I wish to address myself to the question of public debt. It is a very serious matter that the whole of Australia should look at. The balance of payments as depicted in the Budget would lead me to believe that we will have a deficit in the current year at least as large as that in the previous year. In consequence, we will expect to see some pressure on the exchange rate. That in itself will lead the nation to experience further declining business and employment opportunities unless we address ourselves to the problems of external debt.

Figures provided by the Parliamentary Library show that between 1981 and 1985 the gross external debt rose from $15.7 billion to $68.4 billion or, in terms of gross domestic product, from 11 per cent to 33 per cent. That is a staggering growth in anybody's language. This is made up from government borrowings and private operations. It is true that, without the heavy capital inflow of the past year or two, the additions to the country's stock of real capital would probably have been even lower, but the evidence suggests that of late we have been going into debt on an increasing scale, mainly to maintain the levels of current consumption. This implies the likely need for a severe contraction of consumption at some future time as and when the debt has to be serviced, and even more so if the point comes at which overseas investors decline to continue to lend to us on anything close to the recent scale, which could happen at any time.

It is certainly unwise to allow our present level of consumption to depend upon a net inflow of capital which may not continue at anywhere near its present rate. It is true that many countries-although for the most part we would not wish to be one of them-have succeeded in borrowing externally to an unwise and unjustifiable extent. This implies that in recent years there have been lenders around the world willing to continue to lend to such countries even when further increases of their indebtedness appear to be unwise.

But it would be unjustifiable for Australia to take any comfort from these facts. In the first place, we would not wish to fall into the serious economic problems that face so many of the heavily indebted developing countries. Secondly, we may reasonably suppose that the institutional lenders around the globe will look with increasing suspicion in future upon any country that appears to be borrowing excessively and will be much less likely to make the same mistakes again. Thirdly, Australia is not such a large and significant borrower that the lenders are likely to feel obliged to keep renewing loans merely to ensure the servicing of the loans that they have already made. That is a very significant state of affairs, and because of that I would urge the Government to look at the problems in the balance of payments.

Since 1981 we have borrowed extensively to maintain current consumption. This has been reflected not only in the extent of foreign loans but in the percentage of the Government's budget that is now directed towards interest payments-some 10 per cent of total outlays. This is likely to increase and so leads us to the question of where we will go in the future to supplement these quantities of money. The role of the Reserve Bank of Australia is critical in this area. I refer to the way in which it operates in the market today to support the exchange rate at about 60c to the American dollar and the way in which the reserves held it are being applied to that support.

If the balance of payments deficits continue at their current levels, it is unlikely that the Reserve Bank will be able to maintain that position from current reserves. The Government will then be forced into considering special borrowings to support the balance of payments or to take other actions to contract imports to Australia. I would suspect that the trade union movement would be the first to call up the IOUs and demand import restrictions, whereas the answer lies in a far more competitive economy, a far more open labour market and a far more progressive approach to exports from this nation. If those measures are not taken, it is unlikely that we can maintain the exchange rate at these levels.

If that is the case, what is the implication for the economy? Firstly, the inflation rate is likely to increase even above its high level of 8 per cent. That would make our competitive position weaker than it has been over the last five years. Secondly, it is unlikely that import substitution investment, which is so necessary for the external payments to be reduced, will take place unless there is real profitability in the manufacturing sector. To ensure that this occurs, we will need to ensure that the competitive advantages and the opportunities that are gained by devaluation are maximised. This can be done only through the labour market and export opportunities.

The final area of the balance of payments which requires considerable thought is exports. In the last five years or so we have failed to maintain our position of advantage in the South East Asian markets. We have a natural advantage in this area and we should go into it competitively with much more promotion and a far greater sales drive. Corporations must address themselves to genuine risk investment and to the impact of foreign investment outside Australia. This will be necessary if we are to develop and maintain what footholds we have in the South East Asian continent.

All of those measures put together will bring about a reversal in our balance of payments only if there is a combined and concerted effort by private enterprise and by government. I believe that it can be achieved, but it will not do anything for the balance of payments in the short term. As a consequence, I must continue to be gloomy in predicting Australia's economic outlook for the next two years. As a consequence, the Government's Budget is wholly inadequate in every respect. It does not address the balance of payments problem, which is the most critical for Australia. It does not address the question of government debt in terms of fiscal policy and it does not address itself to the record levels of taxation, which can only add to unemployment. The higher the level of taxation, the lower the probabilities of employment. Higher levels of government spending are no substitute for encouraging employment. One of the fallacies of socialist economics is that if governments spend excessively employment will increase. The truth is indeed quite the opposite. Large amounts of government spending are more likely to lead to employment contraction in the longer term. In the 10 minutes I have been given I conclude by saying that I find the Government's Budget presentation to be wholly inadequate and I notice that the Ministers themselves also think so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 August the Treasurer (Mr Keating) brought down one of Australia's most important Budgets. It was important because Australia's position has changed since the days when we were able to live off the golden fleece, not affected by international markets. Australia's international debt, affected by market fluctuations in 1985, grew to a stage where it was impossible for the Government and the taxpayer to meet the enormous interest on that debt. That should have been revealed many years ago. This debt has been of concern to previous governments of all persuasions, but it built up to a stage where the Hawke Government was the Government which was faced with a possible recession if it did not reduce the deficit. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) therefore alerted all Australians to the crisis-that is now history-and appealed for their support in bringing down the deficit, the amount overspent annually in the Budget. The 1986-87 Budget, with a deficit reduced from $5.7 billion to $3.5 billion, is the result, In 1984-85 the deficit was $6.7 billion and in 1983-84 it was $7.9 billion. Considering the highly publicised national economic circumstances under which the 1986-87 Federal Budget was brought down, this was no mean achievement.

SPEECH.PARA: I can witness to the fact that our Federal Ministers, who spent weeks and months weighing up natural priorities against available money, looked traumatised and fatigued by the exercise. I believe it was particularly difficult for members of the Expenditure Review Committee who took on the task of paring down Budget allocations to the desired $3.5 billion as evenly and as fairly as possible. I understand that this entailed the onerous and soul destroying task of going over and over the Estimates on a line by line basis in the search for another area of saving. Not everyone could be satisfied with any outcome in any Budget, but it is important for us to reflect on the fact that the Ministers concerned did not want to reduce expenditure on items which they ideologically supported. As they have reported, it was a case of doing so or of exposing those Australians whom the Labor movement supports to a depression of dimensions which could have exceeded that of the 1930s Great Depression.

This Budget, in cutting the deficit so drastically while actually increasing expenditure on programs for the handicapped and the unemployed, is really a great achievement. Regardless of diverse opinions of political commentators as to whether this or another tactical or economic direction would have best achieved the desired result, it is up to all people honestly concerned with the future of our nation to do their utmost to see that the provisions of this Budget are given a fair go. For this to happen and for us to play our part it is important that we understand just what those provisions are. I am thankful that in making the necessary cuts the Government did not cut pensions. This would have been unthinkable, as I believe a nation is only as strong as its most needy person. I am therefore also pleased that funding has increased in the important areas of the disabled and training for the unemployed.

It is important that the Budget measures be understood at a time when the future of our wonderful country is at stake. It is not a time for party politicking. I would therefore like to touch on some of the major elements of the 1986 Budget as clearly and factually as possible. One of the major areas in which the facts have been distorted for political gain in the past is, regrettably, that of pensions and social security generally. Indeed, this abuse of aged people by conservative opponents of the Hawke Government emerged at its ugliest during the 1984 election campaign, when certain Liberal Party and National Party of Australia candidates actually visited nursing homes, giving residents false information regarding the assets test. I am not saying that they all did this but I came in contact with some of this and I was not impressed. People who were entirely unaffected by the test-and that is the vast majority of aged people-were frightened into believing they would be left destitute. Of course they now know that this is not so. So that the same abuse of our aged citizens does not occur following the 1986-87 Budget, I would like to emphasise some facts regarding this Government's priorities as reflected in this and, indeed, preceding Budgets.

The pension has actually increased from 22.7 per cent of average weekly earnings-the rate when we took office in March 1983-to 24.2 per cent of average weekly earnings; the figure for the end of this year. As stated in 1983, we are committed to raising the pension to 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Under the previous Fraser-Howard Government the pension actually fell from 24.7 per cent in December 1975, the last quarter under Labor, to 22.7 per cent in March 1983, the last quarter under the Liberals. This decrease occurred in seven and a half years. By the May quarter of 1986 pensions stood at 24 per cent of average weekly earnings. The Government will spend more than $300m increasing pensions and benefits this financial year, taking these payments close to the 25 per cent which must be reached even in, and in fact because of, these difficult times.

By the end of this year, the pension will stand at 24.2 per cent. This has been achieved in three years. The single and adult pension will have increased by 37.5 per cent since the Hawke Government came to office. Further, despite difficult economic circumstances, the six-monthly indexation which the Government provides to pensioners to keep up with the cost of living will also be maintained, but the November increase will be deferred for six weeks. This will change the automatic six-monthly pension increase to December and June instead of the present rises in November and May.

Other increases in this Budget are the additional benefit for dependent children of pensioners and other recipients and the family income supplement, which will also be increased to $17 a week. From 1 January family allowance for 16 and 17 year olds will be income tested, but only for families earning more than $39,000 a year. From 1 November the following increases will apply: The handicapped child's allowance will increase by $7 a month to $92 a month. The orphan's pension will increase to $60 a month after a very small 30c increase and the mobility allowance for disabled people will increase to $11 a week after a $1 increase. The point is that these amounts have been maintained and increased at times when the deficit has been cut.

The threshold on rent assistance-one of the most vital aspects of welfare assistance-will also be increased by $5 a week so that recipients renting at more than $15 a week may also be eligible for rent assistance. Pensioners seeking to earn money outside their pension without adversely affecting their benefit or concessions will be assisted by an easing of their income test limit from July next year. The easing of these poverty traps, originally intended for November this year but postponed because of budgetary restraint, will lift the weekly income test for single pensioners from $30 to $40 a week and from $50 to $70 a week for married couples.

It is significant that, within the context of this budgetary restraint, funding for community services and assistance to families has been increased. The Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) has managed an 11 per cent increase in this important area. Spending on aged and disabled care has been increased in the Budget, and in line with government policy greater emphasis will be given to home based and community care rather than to nursing homes because care in the home is more cost efficient and the home can be a more helpful environment for aged and disabled people. An amount of $94m has been set aside for the home and community care program for four years from July 1987. These funds are in addition to the $65m allocated to the program in the 1984-85 Budget.

A most important fact to emerge from a factual reading of the 1986-87 Budget is this Government's continuing support for families in Australia. We see the family unit as occupying a central position in Australian society. There have been a number of changes, but in the four Budgets over which we have presided since taking the reins of government the family income supplement has been increased by 70 per cent, from $10 a week to $17 a week. In the past three Budgets the Labor Government has increased the additional pension for children by $2 a week, taking it from $10 to $16. Similarly, the Government has progressively doubled the mothers-guardians allowance paid to single parents receiving social security benefits, taking the allowance from $6 a week to $12.

Another issue of prime importance to families and, indeed, to all Australians, is that of health care. I would therefore like to clarify the main changes which have occurred in the Medicare system and prescription charges. For working people, the 85 per cent rebate for doctors' fees will still apply following the increase in the Medicare levy to 1.25 per cent, and the standardisation of doctors' fees will be introduced before the end of the year. This will mean that the variance in the amount of rebate provided by Medicare when patients visit their doctor will be the same in all States. The Federal Government had intended to introduce this initiative in August, to remove the anomalies which had existed under previous health systems. But this change will now come into effect from 1 November. That is the same date on which the new `safety net' system for prescription charges on pharmaceuticals will be introduced. Under this system patients will pay between $5 and $10 for their scripts, but once they have purchased 25 single prescribed drugs in a year, additional purchases will be free of charge. I think it is important to note that if one prescription form contains three different items, this will count as three out of the 25 needed for a free entitlement. When the new system begins, a card will be available from pharmacists on which each separate prescribed drug will be entered. When 25 entries have been made, a free entitlement card will be issued and future prescriptions for the year will be free. This will definitely benefit families. Pensioners will continue to receive all drugs on the pharmaceutical benefits list free of charge.

Before closing, I will comment briefly on major employment initiatives which have received funding increases in the Budget. I point out that the community youth support scheme will receive a 12 per cent increase. Funding for the Australian traineeship scheme-part of the Priority One program-will be increased by $35m in 1986-87, in anticipation of 15,000 trainee places. Funding for other work and training programs, including Jobstart, the community training program and the adult training program, also will be increased. The Prime Minister, during his address to the nation, proposed a system of community work for unemployed people. An amount of $2.5m will therefore be put into the volunteer youth program so that young unemployed people can voluntarily help the community and gain useful work experience. It is obvious that even within the tight budgetary restraints of the 1986-87 Budget, the Labor Government has indicated its priorities by maintaining and/or expanding programs for those Australians most in need who absolutely cannot take part in a national belt-tightening exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my contribution to the Budget debate by congratulating the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) for bringing down what appeared on first reading to be a very clever Budget. It was so clever that I, like many Australians who heard the Budget Speech, was at a loss to figure out what the pre-selling of it as a draconian document was all about. But alas, the Australian Labor Party sought to hoodwink the public into thinking that the Government was going to make the difficult decisions necessary to improve our balance of trade problems. Sadly, and unfortunately, that is not the case.

SPEECH.PARA: I trust, now that the Labor Party, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have been caught out in this duplicity, as well as in regard to the overstated trade figure projections, that they will not use this tactic again as a method of conning the community. The Prime Minister and the Treasurer may treat people such as the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, and their back benchers as a pack of mental pygmies or, in the Treasurer's famous words, a group of fourth graders. But I say to them that they should beware of doing this to the rest of the people of Australia, which is what they have been doing in recent times. The public is more sophisticated and more knowledgeable than they would like to think. They understand when performance does not match rhetoric. If any of the Labor socialists are in doubt about that, I will read to them the results of the opinion polls. I will explain those results to them, if they cannot understand them. The results reflect the judgment of the Australian public on the conning that the Government has undertaken.

The Prime Minister, in his build-up to the Budget, led us to believe that there would be equity with sacrifice. But there is no equity with sacrifice in this document. The Labor Party has taken the line of least resistance and has not looked in depth at the real needs of the public, which is suffering from the weight of the bureaucracy, high structural costs and outmoded work practices. Taxes were raised and some benefits were withdrawn. But, very importantly, the size and cost of government were maintained. The Government did nothing about doing away with bureaucratic control and waste.

The Treasurer offered no incentives, no blueprint for the future, and no long term hope for our nation. Instead, as he said in his speech, unemployment is expected to rise. I cannot understand how socialists will go along with that. Inflation will increase and private investment will decline. I can understand why they do not want private investment to increase-they want the public sector to grow. I suggest to the socialists opposite that it is time for them to get off the backs of the taxpayers. After all, they did increase taxes by $1.5 billion. It is about time that they began to reduce their costs. They should cut back government spending, just as they have forced the family to cut back on its budget. I suggest that they could begin by eliminating or reducing the amount of overlap between Federal and State government departments. Why do we need a Federal department of sport? Thank heavens, the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) is a beauty from our point of view. He visited Queensland in the middle of a State election campaign and said: `I am delighted to be here in the fastest growing region of this great country'. Joh Bjelke-Petersen thought that was great.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was right.

—Of course, he was right and the Minister was right. I suggest to the socialists that State governments are more than capable of administering the functions and programs in regard to health, housing, welfare, education and community services. We do not want duplication. The Ministry and corresponding departments, as well as some statutory bodies, could be reduced. I am delighted to read the statements of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), who will soon be Prime Minister of this country, indicating that he will have fewer Ministers and less government involvement in his first Ministry. This move would not only cut out expenditure on the Public Service, but also would make for a leaner, more efficient public sector at less expense to the private sector.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to have an export-led recovery, as prophesied by the Treasurer, where are the incentives for the business community to invest? He should talk to the ordinary people-the home owners, farmers and small business people-who have seen since Budget night that interest rates have become unstable and the dollar has declined in value as a reaction to the Government's inability to make the difficult decisions. This is not the environment in which an aware businessman ventures. There is no security for his investment. I am conscious of the fact that the Budget aims to stabilise this situation. But surely, other alternatives can be tried.

The Government has exhibited some sensitivity to the variation in income received by artists, sportspeople and authors, by allowing them to average their earnings over time. I ask: Why cannot this relief be extended to genuine new Australian businesses and existing businesses which are seeking to export or to be import replacement oriented? Certainly, it is in the Government's interests for those businesses to succeed and prosper. To that extent, it should offer some relief from the burdens of high current account figures. This proposal would be an incentive to those business people who are too timid to venture into the market-place because of the uncertainty of the present economic climate and it would also offer some relief to our unemployment problem. This proposition has merit and the Government should give careful consideration to it.

As the Treasurer mentioned in his Budget Speech, some $6 billion of our international income has been slashed because of several factors beyond our control. Not only have international investors pulled out of the Australian market-place but commodity prices have fallen across the board, indicating that recessionary pressures are at work on a world scale. However, once these pressures are lifted and more prosperous times are at hand demand for our commodities will surge into prominence again. Therefore, it is necessary to take a longer term view of our current rural export situation and not jeopardise our close relationships with our long time friends and neighbours. After all, our security as a nation is paramount and should not be used as a bargaining tool or incorporated with trade matters.

Farmers and businessmen alike are aware that cycles exist in all enterprises and numerous factors influence these cycles. For instance, three weeks ago the cotton industry was giving up this year. Sales were not forthcoming or, if they were, prices were rather low. Yet since that time, prices have jumped by almost $100 per bale because of factors beyond everyone's control. Hence, it is absolutely vital to remain flexible and forward thinking about our longer term gains and not to react to a situation because it appears to be popular to do so at a particular time.

The Budget, like society, has placed little value or importance on the family. It is a sad comment that the family as a unit comes far down the line when concern is expressed about the welfare of our nation. Previous speakers from the National Party have given details of where the family has been hit. I do not want to reiterate those details because others have done it very well indeed. Some of my colleagues who will follow in this debate will also have something to say about that matter. It has been estimated that middle and low income families will be $12 to $15 per week worse off after the full effects of this Budget and the tax cuts come into play.

The Government is not interested in the family. I just happen to be old fashioned. I believe that the family is the basis of society and that we should be building a nation on the family. Honourable members opposite do not believe in that. They attack the family because obviously they want to destroy society and build up a socialist society where the state is supreme. Neither I nor the National Party want to have a bar of that, and there are several reasons why I say that. There are some good people who are socialists. They talk a lot, but I just cannot understand why they have allowed the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the Cabinet and the Ministry to get away with this savage onslaught on the family. I think it is about time that all of us stood up and fought for the family. Why does the family have to put up with such things as the increased cost of petrol, which is a rip-off, bracket creep into higher levels of income tax and increased indirect taxation of food items such as chocolate milk and juices? What child does not like a glass of chocolate milk? Members of the Government have forgotten that they were children once. We also have the higher cost of Medicare and prescriptions. The Minister for Health went around Australia saying: `There will be no increases in Medicare'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Broken promises.
—They are broken promises, as the honourable member for Parkes says.
—Are they lies?
—I would not go quite as far as calling them lies, but I just have difficulty in understanding how someone can sit in a chair-
—Order! I do not think the interjection in that form was appropriate.
—I withdraw the interjection, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—I can understand why the honourable member is excited; he is a very honest man. He has never told a fib or a lie in his life and he gets upset when other people do not treat the truth with such delicate care and tenderness as he does. The Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services (Mr Uren) has entered the chamber. I know that he does not go along with this attack on the family. He is one of the better members who sit opposite and it must be upsetting for him to have to sit around a table and listen to an attack on the family. He will not have a bar of it, but he should convince some of his colleagues. Food, clothing and transport are all items which come out of the disposable income of families. With less disposable income families with children have to bear a disproportionate burden of maintaining their offspring. Added to this, the family allowance for 16- and 17-year-olds has been discontinued. This will affect an estimated 60,000 families and reflects a decreased redistribution of tax money to families. The Government has clearly stated that it puts no value on the family. We in the National Party and the Opposition put all value on the family.

SPEECH.PARA: The redistribution of tax burdens rests not only at the family level but also at the business level. Our businesses have been weighed down with increases in taxes, inefficient work practices and an inflexible wages structure. At the same time calls have been made for an export led recovery and a greater degree of international competitiveness. If this is to be the case, we need to restructure our operations to reflect more closely our international position. The concept of using an export earnings index, rather than the consumer price index figure, as the main foundation for our wage adjustments has been around for some time. If we used this alternative index we would see a more rapid adjustment in our real wages level and all Australians would become more fully aware of our international performance as a trading nation.

How can the farmers of this nation pay higher wages this year when they are getting only $55 a tonne for their barley while last year the price was $120 a tonne? Last year the price for sorghum was $140; this year it is $99, yet our wages have gone up. If we are to have equity with sacrifice let all of us carry a punch and hammer around with us, take off our belts and put in an extra hole when overseas prices come down. We should not have this silly arrangement that wages go up, export income comes down and everyone goes broke. One does not have to be a Rhodes scholar to understand that the system cannot work if one adopts that stupid sort of economics. Our living standards would adjust according to how well we were performing on the world scale.

We are just a small nation of a few people. We cannot influence world market conditions except in the case of wool. We are price takers on world markets and consequently our labour force also has to be a price taker according to world market conditions. This would in turn give the Australian community the incentive to buy more Australian-made products, become more productive, eliminate wasteful work practices and become more efficient. It could be like a national profit sharing project in which the whole of the country would participate. As it is not, wages only go up. If we have a depressed commodities market and a declining manufacturing base we simply tax our way out of the situation. For the sake of our survival we need to get out of this high inflation and interest rate cycle.

Like all my colleagues, I sincerely hoped that this Budget would make the tough decisions required for our tough times, but it failed to do so. Not only did the Government let itself down, but it also let down the Australian people. To summarise, the socialists handed out more taxes and took away incentives. What good is a capital gains tax if there are no gains? What good is a fringe benefit if there is no business or job? What good is an assets test if one has nothing to show for a lifetime of work? Australia must respond strongly to the adjustments necessary so we can get out of this disincentive, high taxing situation we have found ourselves in. We need to adopt the attitude of going into business to make products people will buy and not just to make money. The objectives of management and staff must be complementary in order to achieve the goals necessary to make us competitive. We must begin to attract our best brains and talent into the manufacturing sector, but this can be achieved only if the right economic climate exists. Working together we can produce this climate but it is up to all Australians. We, as Australians, must stop blaming the world for our problems and instead take a positive approach to how, as a nation, we can overcome them and regain our rightful place as a premier exporting nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments made by the honourable member for Groom (Mr McVeigh) remind me of the guest who comes to dinner and propounds his moral virtues and the old saying about such a guest: `The louder he talked of his honour, the faster we counted our spoons'.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am a rather sensitive sort of character. I thought the honourable member's remarks were rather hurtful. I ask that they be withdrawn.
—My impression is that the remarks were not directed to any particular honourable member.
—I disagree, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member said: `The remarks of the previous member reminded me of . . .' That is rather precise and pertinent. I ask that his remarks be withdrawn.
—I ask the honourable member for Ballarat, if his remarks were directed to a particular honourable member, to withdraw them.

—With all due regard to the honourable member's sensitivity, I withdraw. I congratulate the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on bringing down a Budget which stands as a first class response to Australia's current economic position. The context in which this Budget has been put together is one of a massive decline in Australia's terms of trade, brought about by a significant decline in prices for raw materials and farm products. At the same time, the rate of growth of imports, brought about by a remarkably strong domestic economy, had made the position more difficult because of the structural inability of the manufacturing sector to take advantage of dramatically improved international competitiveness consequent upon the floating of the Australian dollar. In addition to adverse terms of trade factors, we have watched the United States and the European Economic Community plunder world agricultural markets via the ill-advised and globally destabilising practice of providing to buyers of all shapes and sizes farm products at subsidised prices.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a Budget over which the Government has agonised. Programs and departments have been affected, which no one on the Government side would have felt particularly happy about. But feeling happy or unhappy is not what this Budget is all about. Responsibility and necessity have imposed other demands. Cuts have been made in areas which, in the best of all possible worlds, would have seen increased expenditure properly targeted for need. But this is not currently the best of all possible worlds. The significant pruning of the Budget deficit has come to be talked about as an end in itself. The simplistic utterances of many on the other side of the House and, I am sorry to say, in the community, have centred on the need to rein in the deficit to an ever lower figure, the object of the game being nothing more than to quote a figure lower than the last self-styled commentator. The deficit gain is one that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) has failed at before. We remember the $9.6 billion deficit in prospect in March 1983 when this Government was first elected. It is perhaps not surprising that he kept revising his preferred deficit figure downward because, as usual, he was being outflanked. It is a measure of his economic credibility when it comes to deficits that the only way anyone would pay any attention to his statements was when he came up with a lower figure than the last one he had heard.

The pruning of the deficit, as I said, was not an end in itself. It was not just a matter of chopping away for the sake of coming up with cuts and a figure that looked tough. The pruning of government expenditure has come about because restraint is absolutely necessary, given the current state of world markets and our unfortunate legacy of several decades or more in which our ability to compete as manufacturers has slipped. This Government has worked hard at industry policy. It has pressed for a revitalisation of industry and has encouraged restructuring that would put the bulk of our manufacturing sector firmly on the path to the 1990s and beyond. It will continue to do these things. Obviously, it takes more than a few years to turn around the neglect of so many decades. So we find ourselves in a hiatus, as our traditional export markets have gone sour and as our industry is in the early stages of restructuring itself and taking on an export orientation. It is all right to come up with a lot of rhetoric about what is good for the family but if, as happened with the previous Government, there is no attempt to restructure and reform the tax regime and the income of families is allowed to be eroded by fiscal drag, I do not think much of that rhetoric. It is nothing short of a kind of parasitism.

The lowering of the deficit is an express recognition by this Government that under present circumstances we have to accept for the time being, a lower standard of living as a nation. A lower standard of living implies lower levels of government expenditure as much as it implies lower income levels for all Australians. One cannot pass the buck to the bloke down the road because the buck is not there. This Government is saying, without fear or any attempt at sweetening or covering-up, that we are going to spend what we can afford to spend, not what we would like to spend. A rather different approach is that taken by the gentleman who had the $9.6 billion deficit. The Government, under the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, has done its job in bringing the deficit to well under half that which it inherited on coming to office. Instead of defending and applauding the Government's efforts for the nation's best long term interests, even if they do not like the details of the Budget, the Opposition, including the Australian Democrats, has publicly toyed with, or not expressly denied, entertaining the idea of knocking out parts of the Budget provisions. Such proposals are the height of irresponsibility. The Democrats are prepared, if they really do fly their kite, to mortgage Australia's future in a fruitless attempt to save their own. Those whom they say they quite genuinely wish to protect, they will grievously harm. It is the response of this Government which will in the longer term give those people the greatest protection and the best future.

I want to make a couple of comments about a development which has taken place in Australia over the last 12 months or so and which is now reaching crescendo level. I speak of the difficulty of some people who in many respects are the legatees of those responsible for allowing Australian industry to run down. These people are classified as the New Right. I think it is incumbent upon those people to examine what they are doing to the fabric of Australian society. If ever it was necessary for all elements of Australian society to pull together and to recognise that it is only through the processes of co-operation that this nation will be able to overcome the deficit of the last few years and the neglect of Australian industry and to achieve an appropriate direction of the Australian economy, it is now. I believe that it is a very sorry state of affairs that there are people who are living so far in the past and who believe that it is appropriate to raise the strange ideological spectre of laissez-faireism as appropriate for Australia today. It is a sad reflection upon the limitations of those people.

I suppose one might say that those people are captives of their own rhetoric. In many respects we are seeing a group of people who believe that it is important to set up again a conflict situation-perhaps the only situation they know, the only way in which they have made their fortunes-and blame the trade union movement which, of course, represents the Australian worker, for the ills of this society. They have very little sense of history and very little understanding that the regime under which this country's problems arose was a regime under which this country paid little attention to the international market-place. They have paid little attention to the need to maintain viable secondary and tertiary industries. It is these people who, in many respects, are the guilty ones. They believe that power and capital are synonymous and that, somehow or other, if one has the capital, one has the power over people. That is, indeed, a destructive way of thinking and a totally destructive way of looking at the development of society. They have given no credit to the trade union movement. Over the last three years members of the trade union movement have been the only people-I might say, with the exception of politicians-who have been prepared to take a real cut in their incomes for the nation's good. The farmers of this country have taken a very serious cut in their incomes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad you recognise that.
—Of course I do.
—Why did you put up the price of fuel on them?
—I will leave that aside.
—That is the knock-out blow; you cannot answer it.

—I am just suggesting that the farmers have taken a cut in their incomes because of a decline in world markets. They know that as well as honourable members opposite do. The people who are really responsible for this are the people who are bleating on the other side of the House, because for 20 or 30 years they allowed this country to run down and not be internationally competitive. They cannot run away from that. That was disastrous.
—Specifics! Give us some figures.
—If honourable members opposite want figures, given plenty of time I can give them the figures.
—They are all generalisations.

—The honourable member knows that it is true. An honourable gentleman on the other side said that the honourable member interjecting is a man of great probity and veracity. I am afraid that that is something about which the honourable member will take a long time to convince me.
—Order! Would the honourable member please address his remarks through the Chair.

—Of course, and I am terribly sorry that I have been waylaid. However, I make the point that it is the responsibility of those people who are now declaring that they want to return this country to the nineteenth century to realise that if there is to be any chance for the country to get back onto its feet, they are the ones who have to be responsible and who have to join with this Government and co-operate to ensure that this can be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are no longer interested in the rhetoric. Australians are no longer interested in the history of a $9.6 billion artificially created deficit projection that neither stood on the figures nor was the responsibility anyway of a past government. I have made that point frequently. Honourable members opposite mention the word inheritance so often in this place that one would think the Government was going to reintroduce probate. The deficit that the Hawke-Keating Government inherited was the $4 billion deficit that occurred in the last Fraser Budget, which it inherited in March 1983 and was obliged to administer until 30 June of that year. The next Budget and all the succeeding Budgets have been produced by the Hawke-Keating Government and have been theirs and theirs alone. Included in that expenditure, and that over-expenditure of $8,000m in its first year, was provision for Medicare. Is anybody in this chamber suggesting that Malcolm Fraser was going to reintroduce Medicare, which is costing close to $4,000m compared with a revenue income of $1.6 billion in the Budget that we are debating today?

SPEECH.PARA: If there is anybody in the gallery or anywhere else who believes that if their grandmother, as much as they loved her, had left to them a forward commitment for debt and they would have accepted the inheritance, I would like to hear them say it. That is what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and his Treasurer (Mr Keating) have tried to tell us for years-that someone else had dreamed up a commitment to a debt of $9.6 billion and they were so incompetent that they had to accept it. It was their decision. We know it was their decision, just as this Budget is their decision, and it was done deliberately to introduce the old Keynesian economic theory that one can kick start a modern economy by the process of massive government expenditure and debt.

In simple terms, the realities of this Budget are that the Government has increased expenditure to $74,764m. That is up a mere $26,000m or 53 per cent on the last Fraser Budget. This Government has increased expenditure to 29.4 per cent of our gross domestic product. This Government has increased tax revenue from $44,344m in the last real inherited Budget to $71,261m, which is up $27,000m per annum in just over four years. Taxation revenue under this Government is now the highest ever level-25.5 per cent-as a percentage of gross domestic product. We had the spectacle of this economic genius, the Prime Minister, the other day trying to compare that level with the highest level under the Fraser Government of 24.6 per cent, and said the Government had to adjust the percentage for inflation. In other words, we are going to have percentages in real terms in the future. That is the economic genius that honourable members opposite call a leader.

Let us look quickly at what the Government has done. It set out on a deliberate course of Keynesian economics. The Government has not yet learnt how to get off the merry-go-round and, of course, the financial community of the world has passed judgment on it. This is the first government and the first Treasurer ever to preside over a downgrading of our sovereign credit rating. How did the Treasurer react to that? He came in here singing `Moody Blues'-a smart-Alick. Every time we asked him any questions in this place relating to the hard economic facts of the day-there was evidence of it yesterday-he did not know the answers. He does not even know the percentages applicable under the fringe benefits tax statutory formula for the use of motor vehicles. He told us once that he was not a computer. That was the first time I had been able to agree with him for some time.

The Government tried to reinvent the wheel with its economic policy, which is no different in this particular Budget, because it thought it could reintroduce Keynesian economics. History has proved that that will not work. The most recent history of Keynesian economics is the attempt of President Mitterrand. I will read what David Clark wrote about that experiment in the Australian Financial Review recently:
After coming to power in June 1981--

TALK.START.PARA: —What has President Mitterrand got to do with it?
—I will give you the reason. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: the Mitterrand Government tried a classic Keynesian demand stimulus. Wages were increased by a minimum of 10 per cent and elderly pensions by 20 per cent.
I know that this Government did not do that; it hit the pensioners, but it put up the dole:
Public investment was boosted to provide many more public sector jobs.

This Government did that. The Government has increased public sector jobs by 15,000. Premier Cain increased his public sector by 25,000 jobs. The total increase under Labor governments in recent times is 45,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most successful government in the Commonwealth.
—If the honourable member listens to this, he might just learn something. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The Mitterrand Government hoped that this package would raise profits and stimulate private sector investment.
French consumers spent all right, but they purchased imported consumer goods--
Does that strike a chord with honourable members opposite? The article continued:
which France either did not produce at all, like video recorders, or goods which were in limited production within France.
The previous speaker bemoaned the decline of our manufacturing sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —You lot wiped it out.
—It does not matter how it happened. The pity of it is that the Treasurer decided that he could fix it. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: The French Socialists discovered that they could order the populace to consume but not to produce.
By the end of 1981--
just six months into his program, a program which the Government has followed so slavishly here--
France had an inflation rate of 14 per cent, a growing foreign and domestic debt, a falling franc and a spiralling import bill.

Have honourable members opposite heard any of those things around Australia lately? Each and every one of those things has occurred for the same reason. The Government had a debt led recovery. The Government borrowed $24,000m against the security of our children in just four years, but it has not worked. Credit is running out, just at a time when, because of a fall in overseas commodity prices, the Government needs a bit of credit. The Government has created 600,000 jobs, it says. It can probably take credit for 150,000 of them, but if we gave it credit for the whole 600,000 it would have borrowed over $30,000 for each job. What happened? We find in this article that President Mitterrand, with his socialist policies, had to devalue his country's currency twice, by 6 per cent and 3.5 per cent. Despite an announcement that the French Government would try to keep the deficit at about 3 per cent of GDP and other efforts to talk up the economy-our Government has been doing that for the last three weeks-and to talk down speculation about the franc, another 8 per cent devaluation against the West German mark could not be avoided in March 1983.

Surely honourable members here recognise the significance of March 1983. It is the very month and year in which the Hawke Government was elected. France had a massive disaster because of these policies, but the Government was too blind to see what it was doing and what it has done in successive Budgets. The Australian situation had nothing to do with what the Fraser Government did. This Government took the decisions; it decided to borrow the money, and it cannot blame anyone else. The Australian public is starting to wake up. It is fed up with this type of rhetoric: Win the argument at any cost; do not be confused by the facts.

We had the Treasurer running around the other day telling business that it could afford the 3 per cent productivity case and the superannuation that goes with it because its profits have never been higher. The figure that he was using was one that was calculated prior to the removal of interest and taxation. Today we have the highest interest rates of any part of the world, bar the banana republics. That was not the case under Fraser. We had high interest rates then, but they were high around the world. The Japanese businessman today can get a prime rate of interest of 4.25 per cent; his American counterpart can get an interest rate of below 8 per cent; and his British counterpart can get one of around 10 or 11 per cent. Similar relative rates apply to householders, who are the people whom the Government says it is looking after.

An amazing thing about this Budget is that this Government, the representative of the workers-I just heard someone say that-is putting up the price of beer every six months. It is the only entertainment that some workers have. I read the other day that the Minister for recreation, culture and everything else was saying how grateful he was that the various Ministers supported his culture program because one loves the opera and one loves the ballet. They are pretty good at going to them on subsidised tickets while the workers of Australia are made to pay the bill through the taxes on their fuel and their beer. This Government taxes, taxes, taxes the simple pleasures that people need. Excise is going up by $715m in this Budget because the Government is so hungry for revenue. It is prepared to tax the very people whom it came into this Parliament to represent, so that it can pass some subsidies on to others.

The same thing applies to the fringe benefits tax. The Government makes such a fuss about this tax, which of course has received very little mention in this Budget. It is a tax that has entrenched the tax-free benefit for the fat cats who are allowed to put it into their costs and pass it down into the Treasurer's little brown paper bag, which will have the Vegemite sandwich in it. Kraft Foods Ltd has to pay the tax-it will pay it on its salesmen's vehicles-but it will not let its dividend income fall; it cannot afford to do so. This is the day of the corporate raider. If it lets its dividend income fall it will be taken over-maybe not Kraft Foods but I could put many others in that place. The Government will see 90 per cent of the fringe benefits tax passed on to consumers, but the Prime Minister denies it. It just shows his inability and his lack of knowledge of the workings of business. He has been involved in Bourke's store and ACTU-Solo. What a disaster they were. The reality of it is that it is the working people of Australia who will pay the fringe benefits tax. Salesmen are paying it already at $20 a week on the cars that they are obliged to use as demonstrators to earn their living. That is what the Government has done.

Let me mention a couple of other taxes which the Government has imposed and which are plainly silly. It has put $100m of taxation on computer software. It is exhorting business to get technology and to get out there and compete with the rest of the world, yet it taxes the thing that business needs most in this modern world. I do not know how many honourable members opposite know the difference between computer hardware and software. The hardware is the machines and the software is the programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Is that right?

—I am sorry, but honourable members on the Government side have a look on their faces that makes me feel obliged to explain it to them. The software is the repetitive item. Businesses have to keep buying it all the time. The Government will tax it; it will create a disincentive for people to invest in new programs which can improve the efficiency of their manufacturing processes and which can improve the efficiency of their accountancy processes. It is really smart stuff! The Government said that licensing is a tax avoidance measure. Of course it is not. Licensing is the process by which the invention is protected. It was not a tax rort. The Government is so paranoid about tax rorts that it does not look behind them for common sense.

SPEECH.PARA: I am aware that I do not have any more time. If I had an hour I could go through the foolishness of this Budget, but it is not really necessary because the evidence is all around us. Our sovereign credit rating has been degraded, and we have to pay between 18 and 20 per cent for our money in this country when the rest of the world is paying for it at much, much lower levels. It is only the banana republics that have to pay this. Maybe the Treasurer was getting pretty close to the truth when he made his statement, but it is all his fault.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87, which is presently before the House, I have some difficulty because with the present deregulatory state of the Australian economy the Government has put itself in a position in which influential overseas financial analysts can virtually dictate how we will run our economy. This means that, had the Government not planned for a substantial reduction in the Budget deficit, the overseas analysts would have cried doom and gloom about the Government's financial policies and our free floating dollar could have plunged to well below the $US0.60 mark. I have to say that I abhor the deregulatory state of our economy. I agree with the assessment by the Government of how we arrived at our present precarious situation, which included bad economic decisions by previous governments that were controlled by the Opposition parties in this House.

SPEECH.PARA: Why must we persist with a floating dollar? Why not fix the dollar at its present level to avoid the manipulation by foreign currency speculators? My major concern about the Budget is that it will cause a further decline in the living standards of the two and a half to three million Australians who are living on or below the poverty line. When Opposition members in this chamber continue to talk about the need to cut wages they should appreciate that many workers are already receiving a wage which is close to or below the poverty line. Those Australians on social security benefits also are well below the poverty line. I seek leave of the House to incorporate in my speech two tables on poverty as at May 1986 which were prepared by the Melbourne University Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research.
Leave granted.

Table 3, for example, shows that a single, unemployed adult with two children receiving maximum social security payments and having no other income receives $168.85 per week, compared with the poverty level of $199.80.
