However, I think honourable members on both sides of the House must agree that these figures are most salutary and indicate that the Government should be introducing urgent measures to overcome the poverty traps into which so many social security beneficiaries fall.

SPEECH.PARA: I hope to say more about these matters in a later speech, and give examples relating to the circumstances of two or my constituents. As my time in the present debate is limited, I have to continue with more general comments about the negative effects which financial deregulation has imposed on our economy.

Australian investment abroad was minimal until our foreign exchange markets were deregulated in 1983. As Kenneth Davidson of the Age newspaper has pointed out, private investment abroad increased from $2,200m in 1983-84 to $5,000m in 1984-85 and to a massive $6,900m in 1985-86. Incidentally, unlike some members on this side of the House, I consider Kenneth Davidson to have provided over the years a most thoughtful and incisive analysis of the economic issues facing Australia. He points out:
Australia has no future unless it undertakes the massive investment in new industries necessary to replace the export revenue now lost as a result of a collapse in world demand for commodities.

It seems ironic to me that at a time when the Government is urging Australians to buy Australian goods because of our terms of trade problems, stockbrokers are urging their clients to invest overseas. As a consequence of the advice of professional investment advisers, a high proportion of the capital outflow is caused by the overseas investments of life insurance offices and superannuation funds. This capital investment is needed badly in Australia but it is quite obvious that patriotism is not a hallmark of institutional and private investors.
The Government has made it clear that its Budget strategy is reliant on private investment by the private sector to improve our terms of trade. The guide to the 1986-87 Budget documents states:

The Government is helping to bring about the necessary changes through the Budget by spending less and borrowing less. With reduced government borrowing there are more funds available for investment by the private sector.

The continuing huge capital outflow to overseas investments does not bode well for the underlying Budget expectations. The Budget deficit has been cut severely from $5.7 billion to $3.5 billion and the Government has achieved a reduction of $2 billion by making a cut of $3 billion in existing government programs and increasing revenue collection through taxation by $1.5 billion. Combined with the cuts in funding for the States, the cuts in government programs must lead eventually to a slowing of economic growth and a loss of jobs. As one who spoke strongly in favour of the prices and incomes accord, I am particularly disappointed that the cuts in government programs will fall most heavily on the poorer sections of the Australian community.

Whilst the Government has always emphasised the wages side of the accord, to the extent that some Ministers have welcomed enthusiastically the large cuts in wages, my own emphasis has always been on the need for increases in the social wage, which was an equally important aspect of the accord. If wage cuts are adequately compensated by increases in the social wage, the benefits flow on to pensioners, the unemployed and low-income earners, and represent a redistribution of income in line with one of the basic principles of the political platform of the Australian Labor Party.

Regretfully, the Government has not kept its side of the bargain with the union movement and the Budget has resulted in heavy cuts in the social wage areas of education, health, social security and welfare. It is difficult to see how the prices and incomes accord can survive in such circumstances. Of course, there are those who will ask: `What is your solution to the problem?'. As I have already indicated, and as I shall attempt to clarify in other contributions to the Budget debate which I hope to make later, I am not in favour of a contractionary Budget. I do not believe that we should have placed ourselves in such a vulnerable position vis-a-vis financial institutions.

It is interesting to note that despite the heavy cuts in government spending and the reduction of the Budget deficit, some overseas economic analysis and some Opposition members are calling for even heavier cuts. It seems quite likely to me that the contraction in government spending will result in a serious economic downturn, particularly if private businesses and households cut back their spending and increase their savings. Such a downturn will result in more unemployment, less tax revenue for the Government and an increase in welfare payments. With no evidence that private business is prepared to take up the slack in the economy, it seems to me potentially disastrous to introduce cuts in government spending which could lead to a recession.

I take the opportunity at this point to comment on two specific proposals in the Budget which, apart from my general comments about the effect of the social wage cuts on the three million Australians who are on or below the poverty line, have caused me concern.

Honourable members will be aware already of my abhorrence of the Government's decision to sell uranium to France in clear contradiction of the Party's policy. My spontaneous reaction of disquiet expressed during the Budget Speech of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), which was shared by my friends and comrades, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent), has since been vindicated by the hundreds of letters, telegrams, telephone messages and other messages of support from not only people in my electorate but also from others throughout Australia.

Party members and supporters are disillusioned that party policy could be so blatantly overturned by a Labor government. Our South Pacific neighbour nations have expressed their dismay and disappointment that financial considerations have overcome our moral responsibilities. I appeal to the Government to reverse this decision. Such a reversal would not indicate weakness. On the contrary, it would show a recognition of the strength of the structures of the Australian Labor Party and the need to honour Federal Caucus obligations to our party members and supporters.

The other matter to which I wish to refer is the decision to reduce the majority of industry assistance bounties by 20 per cent. This decision will prove to be a most blunt and negative means of reducing government expenditure, particularly for the textile, clothing and footwear industries. The Federal Government promised the industries that there would be no change to the protection package until 31 December 1988. The 20 per cent cut in bounties will have a serious effect on the future business policy of an important Australian company called Fibremakers Australia Pty Ltd, whose factory is situated close to the borders of the Federal electorates of La Trobe, Streeton, Casey and Aston. The majority of its 1,029 employees, whose livelihoods could be seriously affected by the reduced bounty decision, live in the four electorates concerned. Incidentally 179 employees live and work at Penrith.

During a recent visit to the factory the honourable member for Aston (Mr Saunderson) and the honourable member for Streeton (Mr Lamb) and I held discussions with management and the employees, who were represented by their union shop stewards. We were advised of a letter which the management had written to the employees, which read as follows:

The announcement on last Tuesday night of a 20 per cent cut back in bounties, applicable to the TCF industries, came as a complete shock to the Company and consequently the Company will need to reconsider its business policy, and immediately set out to recover the consequent $5.5 million in lost revenue.

Whilst justifiable strong representations to the Government will be made on this irrational decision ahead of the pending decision on the IAC recommendations in October 1986 affecting the post-1988 protection package, we will be acting immediately to recover the lost bounty revenue by a further substantial price increase across our product range effective from the 25th August.
Nevertheless, this is unlikely to recover the total losses without some potential loss of volume and market share in some market segments, depending on the relative intensity of competitive activity.

The management also indicated in its letter that the reduced bounty would inevitably have an adverse effect on the $40m expansion and modification program that is currently under way. It is regrettable that the expansion program will be affected because it was welcome news when we Federal members learnt that the Australian company, JGL, had bought Fibremakers from the transnational corporative ICI and was embarking on the expansion program. The management had told us that whilst it has yet to assess the practical effects of the bounty cut, it is highly likely that the program will not be extended beyond the present stage 1 to stages 2 and 3. The curtailment of the expansion program would have a negative effect on the current drive to increase exports. Thus, the bounty cut has had the reverse effect of that intended by the Government, namely, to reduce government expenditure.

As I do not wish to end my contribution to the debate on a negative note, I wish to make a positive plea to government. I am not calling for a change in the decision to cut the bounties, but I do ask that as the sudden decision was commercially unrealistic in respect of the forward commitment of sale prices, three optional payment methods be considered. First, the 20 per cent cut could be phased in over nine months, with 5 per cent on 19 August, 10 per cent on 1 October, 15 per cent on 1 January 1987 and the full 20 per cent on 1 March 1987. Secondly, the bounty could be paid on material contracted pre-19 August 1986 for future delivery at prices that are legally binding. Thirdly, the bounty could be paid on all finished goods produced after 20 May 1986 and before 19 August 1986, being stock held on that date and subsequently sold.

Finally, the recent administrative decision to redefine the scope of bountiable items involving production staff cars and the polymer storage facility appears manifestly unfair and should be reconsidered. I hope that the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) will give serious consideration to the issues that I have raised on the bounty decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101 (a). The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The chair will be resumed at 2 p.m.

—Is the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer aware of the offer by the New Zealand Labour Minister for Finance, Mr Douglas, to resign because of Budget disclosures? As Minister assisting the Treasurer, did the Minister, as stated by Mr Allan Calleja on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation 7.30 Report on 29 August, leak to 5DN Adelaide on 12 August a decision on funding for the Institute of Multicultural Affairs as part of a deal for regular air time? If not on that occasion, did he intend as part of his negotiations with Mr Jeremy Cordeaux to enter into some type of deal related to such Budget disclosures? Why does the Minister have a lesser standard of propriety in such matters than his New Zealand Labour Colleague?

—I have been waiting for the interjection `Scoop' because that, I understand, is my new nickname. I admired the late Senator `Scoop' Jackson from the United States. It is not a nickname I will worry about very much. Yes, I am aware of that offer by Mr Douglas. No, I did not disclose any Budget secret on 12 August. The fact is that I made the announcement on that day, with Cabinet backing, that the Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs was terminated. It was not a Budget decision, it was a decision that was announced by me on 12 August. I have noticed that Mr Calleja has defamed me and I am considering the action I will take arising out of that. I will look at what else the right honourable member had to ask me in his long, voluminous question. If there is anything else that I think this House deserves to learn about I will make a supplementary answer.

—Has the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism noted recent reports in Queensland newspapers that he believes that Queensland is the fastest growing State in Australia? Are these reports correct and, if not, was the Queensland National Party guilty of false advertising in its newspaper campaign last weekend?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see those reports. I do not know whether to be flattered or not that Joh considers me to be such a fount of political and sociological wisdom that he wants to use me in his advertising campaign. I think it is fair that I put the remarks in context. Honourable members will understand that, upon our assent to the throne of government in Australia, this Government inherited Expo 1988, which was a contract entered into by the Queensland Government in conjunction with the previous Federal Government to stage an international exposition in Brisbane in 1988. It is a responsibility which we undertook honourably if reluctantly. I think the decision to have Expo in our bicentennial year was a mistake. Nevertheless, we have honourably approached our responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: I have spent a good deal of time in the last two years inducing countries around the world to take part in Brisbane Expo 1988, as has the Prime Minister. I have also spent a good deal of time trying to get the States to appear at Brisbane Expo. Most of them are fairly reluctant to have anything to do with the Queensland Government. To that end, last week a conference was held in Brisbane, attended by 100 delegates from countries around the world, some of which have agreed to come to the Brisbane Expo. Some are sitting on the fence about making a decision. The first speaker at the conference was Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, the Premier of Queensland, and they are welcome to him. To follow him at the lectern was a very embarrassing experience. One of the delegates asked me later: `Is that man senile?' The rambling incoherencies, the absolute piffle he spoke for 20 minutes, were an embarrassment to me as an Australian. I do not know how Queenslanders live with it.

The House will remember that I was talking to 100 delegates from around the world who were thinking about coming to the Brisbane Expo. I confined my remarks to Australia's tourism effort and pointed out the incredible increase in tourism since this Government has been in power. I mentioned at the end of my remarks that we considered Brisbane Expo to be an extension of that effort, that there was an opportunity for Australia to show off to international visitors and to the international media the extraordinary lifestyle we have in Australia. I said that tourism was our fastest growing industry and that Queensland was the fastest growing State. Of course, I meant in tourism. Everybody at that conference knew exactly what I meant. I note that the Hon. Llew Edwards, the Chairman of the Expo Committee, apologised to the Prime Minister the next day for the absolute perversion of my remarks as construed by the Premier.

The misuse of figures, quotations and advertising campaigns by the Nationals in Queensland is symptomatic of a decaying State. If the House wants a further example, another was given here yesterday by the Minister for Primary Industry when he spoke about the loan moneys that had been given to a National Party member. It is all part of the decay of Queensland. I think the Premier has come out of this with no respect at all, using an occasion when the Commonwealth was co-operating with the State to try to get it off the hook. Believe me, if the Commonwealth withdrew its support for Expo 1988 Queensland would be sitting on an economic problem of mammoth proportions. Although we have co-operated as well as we can to try to help them with this event, the Premier would seek to pervert those good intentions for his own short term political advantage. It is fairly representative of the evil state of the Queensland Premier's mind.

As to Queensland being the fastest growing State in Australia, nothing could be further from the truth. The only area where it is showing any advantage at all in an economic sense is in tourism, and that is despite the Queensland Government. The Queensland Minister for Tourism is not only the least capable but the least co-operative of all Ministers in Australia. Anything that has happened in tourism in Queensland in the last three years is directly as a result of policies implemented by this Commonwealth Government. It has had nothing whatever to do with Queensland. The remainder of the Queensland economy is a disaster area. When the resources bubble burst, the Queensland Government had no idea how to cope with the changed economic environment. The Queensland Government is absolutely bewildered by the economic difficulties it faces. It has very little in the way of manufacturing industry. Coal, sugar and beef prices have retreated to ridiculous levels. It has nothing going for it except tourism.

Anybody who suggests that the Queensland economy is in a good position or that Queensland is the fastest growing state in any area but tourism almost needs to be certified. After all, the average income in Queensland is 10 per cent below the average income for Australia. That is a fair measure of its economic capacity. Its living standards are the lowest in this land. A wave of bankruptcies is sweeping Queensland. There has been a 45 per cent increase in bankruptcies in the last year-the worst performance in Australia. It has an unemployment rate of 9.4 per cent-the worst in Australia. It has the second highest rate of industrial disputation. The Queensland Government is a dinosaur, a relic of days past when the State rode on a tide of resources. It is now sitting on a swamp of its own failure. The State needs new approaches and particularly it needs a new Premier. The State of Queensland, which has the capacity to be a great State, is ruled by a man who is not only in senile decay but is also absolutely evil and ready to pervert even the most honourable of intentions to suit his own advantage. I discount absolutely any imputation that I said that the Queensland economy was growing quickly or that Queensland was the fastest-growing State in Australia. It is a disgrace to the Australian political scene.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to his repeated and bogus claims about the so-called benefits of his Government's tax changes. Is it a fact that, even if the promised personal tax changes of the Government are fully implemented, the average tax rate for a person on average weekly earnings will have risen to 24.5 per cent next year from a level of 22.9 per cent when the Government took office in March 1983? Is it also true that, on the same basis, the marginal rate of tax for such a person will also have risen from 30 per cent to 40 per cent? Is this yet another reason why the level of taxation under the Hawke Government has reached an all-time Australian high?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should preface my reply by putting into context the performance of the Leader of the Opposition when he had the responsibility as Treasurer. We do not have to rely upon his adversaries to make an assessment of his performance. As I have reminded the House on a previous occasion, I rely on what the honourable gentleman himself had to say. On 8 November 1983 he said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . when the former Government left office, taxation as a proportion of gross domestic product was higher than it was as a proportion of gross domestic product in 1975. That is a correct statement. It is there for all to see and I cannot dispute it.

Let us understand that the performance of the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer was to produce, after 7 1/2 years in office, a higher tax load than existed when he came into office. It is not surprising, because the characteristic of the previous Government in regard to taxation was not an effort to introduce a fair and equitable system, but a continuous process of ensuring that those most able to make a contribution to the revenue of this country were precluded from doing so or given the opportunity of not doing so because of the failure to impose the proper laws of this country.

It is no wonder that the worst indictment ever made of a government in this country was made by a royal commissioner appointed by the previous Government. It appointed Commissioner Costigan, and in the report which was tabled in this House, commenting upon the achievements of the Government which had appointed him, he said that the fastest growth industry in Australia in the period since 1976 was the Australian tax avoidance industry. That was the assessment of the previous Government's own royal commissioner. Who are honourable members opposite now to deny the assessment of the royal commissioner whom they appointed? The tax avoidance industry was the fastest growth industry in Australia because of their virtually criminal ineptitude and negligence.

As I said yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition walked out of office in March 1983 with his legacy to the people of Australia being a top marginal rate of 60c in the dollar, because he allowed billions of dollars to escape the taxation net and imposed a greater burden upon the ordinary, average, honest Australian taxpayer. Against that gross dereliction of duty, this Government, particularly under the leadership of the world's best Treasurer, has brought about a situation whereby, from 1 July next year, the top marginal rate will have been reduced from the Howard 60c in the dollar to 49c in the dollar. Associated with that will be the greatest taxation reform in the history of this country.

The Leader of the Opposition has said that he wants tax to be a major issue in the political debate in this country between now and the next election. The Government joins with the Opposition. Indeed, we will make tax the major issue in the debate leading up to the next election. Opposition members will be judged by the fact that they are urging taxpayers in this country not to obey the law of the land. That means that they are saying that in opposition they continue the policy that they had in government; that is, to encourage those who have benefited from their criminal negligence to continue to do so. In government, they allowed those people the luxury of not applying the law to them; in Opposition, when we have a government that has brought in laws to impose a fair, reasonable and equitable taxation system, their contribution to the political debate is to urge those people who will have their perks and lurks taken away from them to disobey the law.

The overwhelming majority of the Australian people will make the judgment that they should-that is, to condemn a political party which in office perverted this taxation system and which in opposition encourages disobedience of a law that would bring about a fair and equitable tax system. We welcome that debate, and we will win it overwhelmingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations aware of claims being made that implementing a compulsory work-for-the-dole scheme in Australia involves little or no additional cost? Could he inform the House as to the accuracy of these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims made by the Opposition that a compulsory work-for-the-dole scheme could be introduced at little, if any additional cost. The Government rejects the notion of a compulsory scheme for a number of reasons, one of which is that it would certainly involve a very substantial increase in outlays. Although the Opposition claims that it is definitely committed to a compulsory scheme, it apparently has not worked out the details of any such scheme or how it would be administered. If it had, it would know that it would cost a lot of money.

ANSWER.PARA: For the benefit of honourable members opposite, let me spell out the implications of a compulsory scheme, assuming that it would be introduced for all persons who are on unemployment benefit for more than three weeks and that they had to work for two days a week. In the year to February 1986, 790,000 persons had been unemployed for more than three weeks and they had an additional period on unemployment benefit of 30 1/2 weeks. If we round the figure up to 800,000 for the purpose of this calculation, in view of the forecast of a slight increase in unemployment this year over last year, we see that we will have to find 800,000 additional work opportunities for two days a week for an average period of 30 1/2 weeks in the voluntary sector. There must be enormous doubts as to whether we could find appropriate work in the voluntary sector of this society on such a massive scale.

But even assuming that that was so, the additional costs, on our calculations, would be about $700m. The cost includes $488 as a contribution to the employment-related costs of generating those 800,000 positions, and those costs are related to the costs of materials and equipment used in undertaking work, supervision of that work, administration of the scheme and worker's compensation insurance. That $488m represents only a very modest Commonwealth contribution of $20 a week--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did the Prime Minister advocate this scheme?
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—The Prime Minister is advocating this.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will heed the Chair.

—He is about as effective in here as he was on Channel 9. The $20 a week on which we base our estimate is very modest, as it compares with a figure of $30 to $40 under the current volunteer youth program and is less than the $25 a week which is paid under the voluntary scheme that exists in Canada. Another factor would be travel costs, which we have estimated would be $183m, assuming an average claim of $7.50 a week. Travel costs are paid under the volunteer youth program introduced by the previous Government. We assume that that would continue under any such compulsory scheme. The amount of $35m for Commonwealth Employment Service staffing and administrative costs would of course be involved in matching unemployed persons to available placements, monitoring placements to ensure that the program guidelines are adhered to and other administrative tasks involving 1,000 extra CES staff. These are all conservative estimates and in practice would probably be considerably exceeded.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition has claimed that these costs would be offset by weeding out dole cheats through the introduction of such a scheme. It should be recognised in that regard that in this Budget we have significantly tightened up the administration of unemployment benefits, as already announced by my colleague the Minister for Social Security. I remind the House that that involves special reviews being conducted in selected regions by teams of officers to identify and disqualify those wrongfully receiving unemployment benefits, that New Zealanders have been excluded from unemployment benefits for their first six months in Australia and in the following six months must prove an intention to reside in this country and that registration with the CES is to be mandatory for all unemployment beneficiaries--

TALK.START.PARA: —Why wasn't it before?

—As it was, I tell the Leader of the National Party, until his Government removed that requirement in 1981. It was there until 1981 and his Government took it away. We are putting it back and making sure that people who do not maintain CES registration will have their benefit automatically cancelled. Also, people on unemployment benefit will be required to attend an office of the Department of Social Security in person each fortnight to lodge the forms necessary for the continuation of their benefit. That also was a requirement that existed until it was removed by the previous Government, which apparently allowed fraudulent practices to creep into the system to some degree.

ANSWER.PARA: All of these measures will ensure that any cheating in the system is massively reduced. The Government's approach in tightening up the unemployment benefit administration and in introducing a greatly expanded voluntary community work program represents a far more cost effective, sensible and compassionate approach than does the ill-conceived approach of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I ask the Minister to table the document.
—I will.

—Will the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs confirm that when the Commonwealth purchases the Gimbat and Goodparla leases to create the proposed stage 3 of Kakadu National Park traditional owners will still be able to lodge claims under the existing Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act? Will he also confirm that traditional Aboriginal land owners could apply a veto on exploration and mining under the current Act and thus effectively prevent any new mining within stage 3 of the Kakadu National Park granted to them? Does the Minister propose to introduce amendments to the land rights Act to override the Aboriginal veto on mining? If not, how does the Government propose to open stage 3 of the Kakadu National Park to new mining as promised yesterday by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Resources and Energy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first aspect of the honourable gentleman's question is yes. Land at Gimbat and Goodparla, having been purchased by the Commonwealth, would be subject to Aboriginal land claim. Any such claim would be dealt with by a commissioner who would, under the Act, make recommendations as to any detriment which may follow. Detriment is always a matter of report where it occurs in respect of either an existing or a potential mining interest. It is not for me to endeavour to pre-empt either the recommendations of the commissioner or the way in which he would conduct those hearings.

ANSWER.PARA: It is the intention of the Government to introduce amendments to the land rights Act. Those amendments have been widely circulated to a whole range of interest groups, including miners, the Northern Territory Government and the land councils. The response of those groups is currently being considered by me and relevant Caucus committees. It is unfortunate, however, that a response which we received from the Northern Territory Government, which indicated that it had some objections on the basis of duplication to what was being proposed, has been beaten up in the Northern Territory by the Chief Minister on the basis that what we are proposing is an alternative black State. Let me say this: This Government has spent some time conferring with all relevant interest groups, including the Northern Territory Government. If, because of the situation in the Northern Territory, the Chief Minister wants again to try to bring on an election by dividing the community in kicking a black head wherever he sees one, I certainly will review the whole position in respect of the Northern Territory Government, because the purpose of the amendments which have been so carefully considered has been to try to reduce some of the problem areas that have been exhibited in the operation of the Act. The Government has entered into all those discussions in good faith. We would be defeating our own purpose if we allowed the situation to arise where, for the most narrow, expedient and short sighted political reasons, these amendments were used by the Northern Territory Administration as an exercise in creating tension within its own community and conducting another election campaign on the basis of kicking a black head where it sees one.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. What would be the effect and cost to taxpayers of abolishing the pensions assets test as promised by the Opposition?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question, I think all of us in the House were somewhat surprised, if not shocked, on the night the Leader of the Opposition made his alternative Budget speech.
—If you could call it that.

—Well, that is a bit overly-generous. He made his speech in response to the Government's Budget. On what I think was generally regarded as a pretty tough Budget, a very tight Budget, one in which the Government had to make a number of very difficult decisions, the Opposition Leader indicated that one area in which the coalition could make a decision and give an assurance. The only significant decision affecting expenditure that he indicated in his speech on the Budget was to remove the assets test and thus to restore social security pensions to some 34 millionaires and 524 people with assets ranging from half a million dollars to a million dollars over and above the worth of their family home. That suggests to me, and indeed I think it would suggest to the vast majority of Australians, where the Opposition's priorities are.

ANSWER.PARA: The Opposition is unable, in the current circumstances, to nominate areas in which it would cut expenditure and is unable to say in any detail what it would do, except that it would protect 34 millionaires and 524 people with assets worth between half a million and a million dollars. That was the Opposition's only spending promise, and I think it is highly indicative. We recall that when the Opposition did occupy the Treasury benches it had all sorts of opportunities to take tough and difficult decisions and it was not prepared to take them. That is why, when we came to office, we faced such a massive problem of an overblown deficit. I think this particular decision is a clear indication that, when the Opposition talks tough and talks hard, when it indicates, as the honourable member for Menzies was prepared to indicate, that it will wipe off everyone who has been on unemployment benefit for over two years--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is nonsense. Who said that?
—And when other members indicate that they will knock young people off unemployment benefits--
—You liar; you absolute liar. You wouldn't know.
—Order!
—We know that if the Opposition selects that group of people it selects them because it thinks they are a push-over or those are areas in which they are going to be able to get away--
—He is telling lies.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will withdraw that comment.
—Yes, all right, and I will fix it up in a personal explanation later.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will withdraw.
—Yes, I did Madam Speaker--
—You did not withdraw.
—And I do again. Like my colleague, I have to do it several times--
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition knows full well that the words are: `I withdraw'.
—I withdraw, Madam Speaker. But he should tell the truth, too, while he is at it.
—Order!

—It is quite clear that, if one is to deliver in terms of deficits and tight spending, one must make decisions. One has to be able to make decisions. It is quite clear what kind of decisions would be made by the coalition parties. They would make the decisions that would effectively mean that wealthy people-indeed, millionaires-would be protected. They would make those decisions to protect those people. They would not be prepared to make decisions which would lead to greater fairness and greater equity in terms of the welfare system in Australia. I think that has been made very clear by the Opposition whenever it has made any statements in this area. Its approach to economics represents a kind of lunacy. It suggests that the burden of economic difficulties would have to be borne by low and middle income earners. That is what would happen if we were unfortunate enough to have a government led by the coalition. That approach should be contrasted with the approach that we have taken-that is, effectively, while recognising the difficulties, we take decisions which are fair.

ANSWER.PARA: I want to pick up the point that was made by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations with respect to the removal in 1981 of the compulsory requirement for people to register for the unemployment benefit. That is certainly true but it goes a bit further than that. It is also true that in 1981 all selective reviews were effectively eliminated in terms of unemployment beneficiaries. The Government has made big decisions in regard to the assets test and also in the achieving of a disciplined approach to social security administration. It is hard to find a single decision made by the coalition parties when they were in government which had the effect of producing a system which had greater integrity and which was tighter than the one that was in place when they came into office in 1975.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an absolute disgrace.
—You should call the Minister to order and wind him up.

—If one contrasts the decisions that we have been prepared to make this year-not only in the context of the Budget but also in the course of this year-with the record of honourable members opposite, one sees what frauds they really are.
—The Chair has no authority to wind the Minister up.

—Is the Prime Minister aware that the conditions of payment of travel allowance to a Minister as listed by the Remuneration Tribunal require his home base to be his principal place of residence? Why has the Prime Minister permitted for the past two years the Treasurer to list a Sydney property-in which, by his own admission, he does not live-as his home base, so enabling the Treasurer to receive more than $30,000 in travel allowance for residing in Canberra, which is in reality his principal place of residence? As recent statistics issued by the Special Minister of State indicate that the Treasurer may have spent no more than 11 nights in his alleged home base of Sydney over the past year-unless he has claimed travel allowance for weekends he has spent in his Canberra home-will the Prime Minister now require the Treasurer to repay the money improperly obtained by him?

—It is no wonder the Opposition received such a mauling in today's Press for its ineptitude during Question Time. This question was asked of the Treasurer yesterday and was more than adequately answered by him. The fact is that the Remuneration Tribunal determination concerning travel allowance allows Ministers to nominate their home base. The Treasurer's claims are in accordance with the determination and the relevant Cabinet decision. May I say that this Government regularly publishes figures in relation to Ministers' expenses, a course of action which contrasts dramatically with the previous Government's attitude to expenses. We publish the figures; the previous Government did not. Having regard to the performance of some Ministers of the previous Government, it is absolutely no wonder it did not publish them. I hope that, as the Opposition has raised this question twice, the Special Minister of State will have the opportunity, as he indicated yesterday, of throwing some light on the hypocrisy of honourable members opposite. They will see that the practices that they followed make the practices of my Ministers appear to be the practices of the paragons of virtue they are. What the Treasurer has done is totally in accordance with the determination of the Tribunal. Therefore, of course, it follows, in regard to the last part of the honourable member's question, that the answer is no.

—Is the Minister for Defence aware of the new policy of the United States Army strictly to limit smoking in military offices and buildings and to prohibit smoking altogether in vehicles and aircraft? Is the Minister aware that an estimated 16,000 Australians die from smoking related illnesses each year? Does he agree that smoking contributes to illness and to absenteeism in the general work force, not only on the part of smokers, but also on the part of non-smokers who inhale tobacco smoke? Does the Minister agree that the health, fitness and occupational readiness of Australian defence forces would be enhanced by controls on smoking by military personnel? What steps will the Minister take to reduce smoking by personnel of the defence forces?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not actually aware that any members of the defence forces smoke. I have not actually seen any of them smoke when I have been present, except perhaps on the odd occasion after dinner in the mess and a pipe on Sundays. So I am not sure of the extent of the problem to which the honourable gentleman referred. I know from the responses of my Cabinet colleagues to the events earlier in the week, when they had an opportunity to go out to sea, that most of them would take the view that service personnel who have to put up with being at sea for any lengthy period should be able to do anything they like. I doubt very much whether there would be much support among my Cabinet colleagues for banning smoking or any other relaxing activity in that atmosphere.

ANSWER.PARA: I was not aware of the policies of the United States Army that the honourable member mentioned. He invited me to make a series of medical comments which are tendentious, to say the least, among people with far more expertise in that area than I. I would not presume to give him any direct answers. All I can say is this: The defence forces take very seriously the health of their members and behaviour which encourages better health. I doubt very much whether smoking by members of the defence forces occurs to a greater extent than in the general community. If anything, it would be less. In fact, I think there is a concern for fitness among members of the defence forces which makes them very low users of tobacco products. I doubt very much whether there is any substantial requirement on us to make any particular effort in this regard in relation to the defence forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Prime Minister aware that the price of petrol has risen by an average of 13c a litre throughout Australia since he became Prime Minister? Is he further aware-these are the facts-that the pump price of petrol in Tasmania is nearly 64c a litre?
—Change the Government.

—Do not worry about the State Government. It is all attributed to the Hawke Government; that is the reason for it. What has happened to the assurance given in 1983 by the Prime Minister that the price of petrol would be reduced by 3c a litre and that he would put a freeze on the price of overseas crude?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I always welcome a question from my good friend the honourable member for Franklin and I thank him for this one. I have to share the view expressed by way of interjection behind me that if that is the price of petrol in Tasmania there ought to be a change of government. I understand that the price is 48c in Victoria. Let me go seriously to the issues involved in the question of the price of petrol. Madam Speaker, as you know, the Government is committed to the import parity pricing policy which was the policy of the previous Government. That policy has a clear and sensible foundation, and that is to ensure that domestic crude oil prices reflect international trends. That is the foundation of the policy and it is a sensible one.

ANSWER.PARA: Looking at the current situation, world oil prices have continued to strengthen since the last IPP adjustment on 1 September. As to what the Government will do regarding the future price of petrol, we will make the announcement closer to the appropriate date of fixation. I make the very important point that the Government will continue to deal with adjustments to the IPP on a revenue-neutral basis, that is, to adjust the product excise rates to offset fully the revenue gained from higher prices which would otherwise accrue. If we look at comparative petrol prices, even with the Budget and the September IPP adjustment, Australian petrol prices are still amongst the lowest of those of any comparable industrialised country.

We make no apologies for the actions and decisions of this Government. Essentially, they are based upon the principles of the IPP policy which were followed by the previous Government. To the extent that adjustments have been made necessary in recent times by the very seriously and wildly fluctuating price for oil, this Government has conducted its policy decision making on the basis of revenue neutrality. I think that policy is understood and respected by the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Health been drawn to an article by Dr Peter Yellowlees of the Flinders Medical Centre in the latest issue of the Medical Journal of Australia entitled `Thiamine deficiency in prevention of the Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome'? In that article does Dr Yellowlees come to the conclusion that this syndrome is a major public health problem in Australia which requires immediate political intervention? Does the evidence show that thiamine deficiency in the diet, particularly of heavy drinkers, including alcoholics, is the cause of this major public health problem? Is the simple and cheap solution adding thiamine to the diet, including staples such as bread and beer? Would this prevent the present large number of admissions to psychiatric hospitals? Can the Minister say what action is being taken by the National Health and Medical Research Council to assess these claims and to put in train appropriate action?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the article by Dr Yellowlees and I am also aware of the concern in the community about the extent of the Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome in our society. It is a disease which is usually associated with an excess intake of alcohol. To answer the second part of the question, there is evidence from overseas that the addition of thiamine to bread and flour reduces nutrition-related alcoholic diseases. However, it is not clear that that would be of great benefit in this country because our bread and cereals naturally have a higher level of thiamine than those of comparable countries. No data is available on the benefits of adding thiamine to alcoholic drinks, although some studies have suggested that there might be a cost benefit to government in doing that.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the first part of the question, the National Health and Medical Research Council has this issue on board. It has commissioned two major studies-one on the prevalence of the disease in Australia and the second on thiamine absorption and alcohol beverages. In addition, my Department's national dietary survey is examining the Australian adult's intake of thiamine. An NHMRC expert committee will consider the results of all these surveys and will aim to develop a public strategy to deal with this disease. I can assure the honourable member for Kingston that in the consideration of those strategies the proposals by Dr Yellowlees will be taken on board.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the Government's response to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia. It is the substance of a ministerial statement by the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Gareth Evans, QC.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

—Yes, I do, and by no less a personage than the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Yesterday the Prime Minister claimed-he repeated it today-that I had urged people to break the law. I want to make it clear on my part and on behalf of the Opposition that it will never be my policy or the policy of the Opposition to urge any citizens in this country ever to break the law of this country.
—Madam Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes, Madam Speaker.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—During Question Time the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) said that I had advocated that recipients of unemployment benefits who had received them for two years or more should, to use his expression, be wiped off the slate; that is, that they should be denied unemployment benefits. I have never made any such statement whatsoever. What I have said on a number of occasions-if the Minister had his wits about him he would take notice of what people say on these subjects-is that the unemployment benefit may not be an appropriate form of social security payment for the long term unemployed and that there may well be a case for some different and possibly even some better form of social security for the long term unemployed. I have said, certainly, that the unemployment benefit is not appropriate for people on an open-ended basis, but I have also said that there should be some other and possibly even better form of social security for them.

PETITION.TITLE: Closure of Post Office Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we strenuously object to the proposal that many post office agencies are to be closed. They provide a network of offices with postal and agency services to residential areas and small communities.

They serve a community need and we would be seriously inconvenienced if forced to travel further to purchase postal items or collect parcels. It would be an unnecessary expense particularly for pensioners without their own transport. We maintain that the purpose of Post Offices should be to serve the public for the variety of services they offer. They are a community centre particularly in country areas and if necessary they should be subsidised to retain them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House should take all possible steps to prevent the closure of post office agencies and that the network should be extended, with the Agency services they offer expanded.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Adermann,Mr Beale,Mr Beazley,Mr Blanchard,Mr Blunt,Mr Braithwaite,Mr Brumby,Mr Carlton,Mr Charles,Mr Cobb,Mr Cohen,Mr Dobie,Mr Everingham,Mr Fife,Mr Peter Fisher,Mr Steele Hall,Mr Hicks,Mr Jenkins,Mr McGauran,Mr McVeigh,Mr Martin,Mr Millar,Mr Nehl,Mr Price,Mr Ian Robinson,Mr Scott,Mr Spender,Mr Tuckey and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Censorship Board
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We, the undersigned, plead that Parliament will legislate, or act in accordance with the present legislation to replace the current members of the Film Censorship Board who have admitted to Senator Harradine on 12th December, 1984 as reported in the Senate Select Committee on Video Material, (see attached extracts), that they are not applying either the blasphemy or obscenity tests as required under the provisions of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations, and that these persons be replaced by persons who will apply these and the other related test in accordance with the said Regulations.
Your petitioners humbly pray that you will give this matter your earnest attention.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Steele Hall,Mr Jenkins,Mr McGauran,Mr McVeigh and Mr Tuckey.

PETITION.TITLE: Radioactive Substances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth. We most strongly oppose the process of Food Irradiation by radioactive Cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance.

We oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process by State Governments. We express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

We call on the Government to immediately ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances and to immediately disallow the regulations that permit the irradiation of food here in Australia.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby,Mr Langmore and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That taxpayers with dependent children have been gravely disadvantaged by a serious decline in the level of recognition provided in the taxation system for the costs of maintaining a family, in particular:
The failure to index family allowances which has resulted in an erosion of more than 50% in their real value since May 1976;
the abolition of family allowances for dependents who have turned 18, even those still at school;
the abolition of concessional tax rebates for education and other expenses.

That this erosion in horizontal tax equity has placed an intolerable financial burden on many large families, particularly those on middle incomes who fail to qualify for means-tested benefits such as TEAS but whose living standards are now well below average due to heavy expenses on necessities such as education, housing, food and clothing.

Your petitioners humbly pray that: family allowances be restored to the 1976 value (in real terms), and indexed according to the CPI; the dependent spouse rebate be retained; the Federal Government take urgent measures to restore equitable provisions in the taxation system through the introduction of family income splitting.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale and Mr McGauran.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows:
Graduated family allowances are of important assistance to families with more than one child.
All family allowances, whether for one, two, three, or more children, have not kept pace with inflation.
There are suggestions that all family allowances should be paid at the one flat rate. This would severely disadvantage families with more than one child.
There are also suggestions that the dependent spouse rebate be reduced or removed. This would represent another blow to the family unit.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, should:
Ask the Federal Government to increase the value of existing family allowance payments, and
reject any moves to change the payments to a flat rate or to tamper with the spouse rebate.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Extradition (Foreign States) Act 1966
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners have grave concern about recent changes in the Extradition (Foreign States) Act of 1966 which deny basic rights which have been a cornerstone of the English and Australian law for over seven hundred years. We are speaking of the right to be presumed innocent until proven guilty and the right of an individual to defend himself against his accusers. This concern has come to light during recent extradition proceedings against Messrs Hempel and Etheredge in Western Australia.

We are concerned that because judicial protection of these basic rights has been excluded from the Act, refugees, migrants, Australian overseas travellers, and visitors are at risk when they have been to (or come from) countries where the norms and practices of human rights and civil liberties are below traditionally accepted Australian standards.

We the undersigned petitioners, therefore urge the Government to re-examine the Extradition (Foreign States) Act (as amendment in 1985), and amend the current Act so that the rights of the accused are once again judicially protected in Australia.

In addition, we urge the Government to refrain from entering into any further extradition treaties or proceedings under the current Act until the process of re-examination and amendment of the Act has occurred.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Campbell and Mr Drummond.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian national flag.
2. We are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
The Union Jack-itself the creation of 3 Christian crosses-represents the nation's historical origin, and the source of its language and law.
The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its place in space.
The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. We know the flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. We recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. We are certain that any change to the flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your Honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian national flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Repatriation Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned as an ex-service person protest strongly at the reported intention of the Commonwealth Government to make drastic reductions in repatriation benefits in the forthcoming 1986 Budget.
And we pray that the Government not make any changes in repatriation benefits.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:

That Labor's capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, tax on lump sum superannuation and assets test are an unwarranted burden on the people of Australia, have contributed to the national economic crisis and the anomalies in the legislation are causing confusion and anger amongst all sections of the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek the repeal of Labor's Assets Test, Labor's Capital Gains Tax, Labor's Fringe Benefit Tax and Labor's tax on lump sum superannuation.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
1. Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices
2. Not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
3. Maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
That many Australian wage and salary earners and self-employed persons do not enjoy secure retirement incomes provided by superannuation; and

That the Government issued in December 1985 Guidelines for the implementation of the proposed productivity decision by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission and draft Operational Standards for Superannuation schemes.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:
1. Guarantees to every employee the right and freedom to select the superannuation scheme of his/her choice.
2. Protects the individual exercising that freedom of choice from any coercion, influence or other pressure which may be applied by any employer, association or trade union.
3. Will recognise only those schemes which provide genuine superannuation and reject those schemes which do not provide for:
preservation of benefits to retirement
vesting of employer contributions on a reason- able sliding scale
equal employer and employee Trusteeship control to ensure security of investments.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Wollongong Area Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the closure of the Wollongong area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

2. That the impact of the closure of the office in Wollongong will be particularly felt by the non-English speaking migrants and community at large from Shoalhaven to Hellensburg and as far as Wingecarribee and Wollondilly.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that the area office of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in Wollongong be kept operational and fully staffed.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Lalor/Thomastown
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:
The lack of a Medicare Office in Lalor/Thomastown is seriously inconveniencing the residents of the Shire of Whittlesea.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare office be established in Lalor/Thomastown as soon as possible.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Test Ban Treaty
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia shows that:
In this International Year of Peace, 1986, the world needs a Nuclear Test Moratorium by the United States, the Soviet Union, France and other nuclear-testing powers.
That such a moratorium would create a favourable climate and basis for the negotiation of a Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.
That such a Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty would
be the first vital step to nuclear disarmament
impede the development of new nuclear weapons
decrease the reliance upon an unstable nuclear strategy
inhibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
Your petitioners therefore ask that the Australian Government be urged to:
1. Use its influence with the United States Government to encourage it to join the moratorium on nuclear testing begun by the Soviet Union on 6 August 1985.
2. Use its influence in all forums to encourage other nuclear nations to join the Nuclear Test Moratorium.
3. Use its influence in all forums to encourage non-nuclear nations to demand the establishment of a Nuclear Test Moratorium and Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty.

PETITION.TITLE: First International Earth Repair Year
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House or Representatives in Parliament assembled.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out:

That deterioration of the total global environment is continuing at an increasing rate; that important environmental resources vital to human livelihood such as trees, soil and water are decreasing at an alarming rate; that there is a need for educating all people to assume a greater responsibility for the conservation, sustainable use and maintenance of vital resources; that dynamic and active initiatives are needed to conserve and renew the total environment; and that protecting, conserving and repairing the Earth can unite all people and nations in co-operative action for survival.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government will: propose to the United Nations General Assembly at its 41st Session in September 1986 that 1988 be proclaimed the ``First International Earth Repair Year''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the Government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25 per cent of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted,
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.

PETITION.TITLE: Fringe Benefits Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Government's Fringe Benefits Tax is a vicious, punitive tax that unjustly affects employers, will have a major impact on small business and farm profitability, and will result in increased unemployment.
Your Petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Parliament to repeal the legislation establishing the Fringe Benefits Tax.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Film Hail Mary
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows that:

(a) the film ``Hail Mary'' (i.e. ``Je Vous salue Marie'') has been registered by the Film Censorship Board for public exhibition with a Restricted Classification; and is due to be screened in the forthcoming Sydney Film Festival;
(b) The film is a blasphemous and pornographic attack on Jesus Christ, the Blessed Virgin Mary, Saint Joseph and the Archangel Gabriel, as such is is extremely offensive to the undersigned.
(c) The film therefore breaches regulation 13 (1) of the Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House of Representatives call upon the Attorney-General, as the Minister responsible, to prevent the exhibition of the film in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Cowper Electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor government's productivity-superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of certain electors of Australia respectfully sheweth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Human Rights Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble Petition of certain electors of the Division of Cowper respectfully showeth:

That the Bill of Rights Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Bill, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Amendment Bill and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, if passed by the Parliament, will undermine human and civil rights in Australia; will attack the institution of the family in our country, and will destroy States Rights and the federal nature of our Commonwealth.

Your Petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament rejects these Bills; abolishes the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission and moves to withdraw ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Koalas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have the koala declared an endangered species and given the proper protection of the Commonwealth.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House declare that the koala may not be exported from this country and that urgent re-vegetation of their habitats be carried out. Your petitioners also humbly pray that Commonwealth Government funds will be made available for research into the disease Chlamydia Psittaci which is killing the koala.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Harp and Hooded Seals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of concerned people respectfully showeth their desire to have Harp and Hooded seals protected.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will propose Harp and Hooded seals to be listed on Appendix 1 of the Washington Convention (CITES).
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Australian flag symbolises the continuity between Australia's past, its present and the future;

That the presence of the Union Jack on the flag represents not a subservience to Britain, but a reminder of our inheritance of the fruits of hundreds of years of struggle for individual liberty against the forces of tyranny and oppression;
Nonetheless recognises the rights of Australians should they wish as a people to change the design of their flag.
Your petitioners humbly pray that no change be made to the Australian flag except with the consent of the people in a referendum.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: English as a Second Language Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned residents of Australia totally reject any move to cut funding to Australia-wide English as a Second Language programs in schools.
We request that the Australian Government restore funding to the 1985 level in the 1986-87 Budget.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
1. We the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
2. The impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug;

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2 fee on each prescription.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australian by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and its present justice system, nor in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
Persistent rumour suggests that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensuring no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Reviewing the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Richmond electorate respectfully showeth that:
There is an urgent need to up-grade and extend the facilities at the Northern Rivers College of Advanced Education.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to provide the necessary capital funding for the Northern Rivers CAE to ensure North Coast students have access to a tertiary institution capable of providing them with the skills they will need to meet the challenges of the future.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: SBS Television Services in Rural Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
(1) That in the past, because of their remoteness, citizens in rural areas have not been able to receive SBS (Multicultural) television through conventional means.
(2) That recently those citizens have been able to receive the SBS television service from the AUSSAT satellite by means of receive-only earth stations.
(3) Now express concern that by Government decision this service is to be terminated.
Your petitioners therefore urge that SBS television continue to be made available to citizens in rural areas of Australia by means of the AUSSAT 1 satellite and receive-only earth stations.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the Western Sydney State University as recommended in the Parry Report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:
