INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's failure to adequately explain the operation of its new taxing measures, including the Fringe Benefits Tax, and the resulting confusion and disincentive for business-big and small.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever we needed evidence of the complete disarray of the Government, we got it today from the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism (Mr John Brown) when he was responding to a question on a matter that he should have well and truly decided was dead. I think his is just another case of someone who is going bananas. The other evidence is the desperate efforts of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other Ministers to dress their draconian fringe benefits tax in new clothes. We are well aware of the Government's constant dissembling of the facts as to its economic performance, and it is up to the public to judge that.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter before us today is more serious. In the Government's attempts to present the fringe benefits tax as a mild and administratively simple tax, the Treasurer is misleading taxpayers into making incorrect returns and suffering future financial penalties. That is not good enough. It is fair enough that the Government tries to defend the disaster it has brought upon Australia, but it is certainly not fair enough to tell people things which are not true or accurate and which mislead them and turn them into tax evaders. Let me give honourable members some examples of this. Not long ago an article in my newspaper which circulates in Geraldton, the Geraldton Guardian, under the headline `Keating in bid to clarify tax', stated:
Mr Keating said examples of mis-information about the changes-
He was talking about the fringe benefits tax-
was a claim that farmers would be liable for tax on the food and lodging given to their children, if the children worked on the farm. `That claim is just rubbish' he said.
The `Fringe Benefits Tax Guide'-the pink book that is now hated by Australian business universally-states on page 23 under the heading `Housing Fringe Benefits-Types of Accommodation':
A taxable housing fringe benefit arises when an employee (including members of the employee's family)-
it says this in English; I understand that one has to fill out the forms in English-
is given by an employer the right to use a unit of accommodation as his or her usual place of residence.
The Treasurer has a few problems about the words `usual place of residence'. The quotation continues:

This includes the right to share occupation with others. A unit of accommodation includes a house, flat, or apartment; accommodation in a hotel, motel, guest house, bunkhouse or other living quarters in a ship or other vessel or floating structure, or a caravan or mobile home.

Honourable members should remember that this includes the right to share accommodation with others, including members of an employee's family. How could the Treasurer get that one wrong? What about the people of Geraldton who believe what they read in the Geraldton Guardian and make that mistake? The House of Representatives Hansard of 5 June 1986 reports Minister John Brown as saying, in answer to a dorothy dix question on whether the hospitality industry would be adversely affected by the fringe benefits tax:

It has never intended that the fringe benefits tax for employees would be calculated at the full commercial tariff of the hotel or motel concerned . . . I can assure the House that in this case the rent would be calculated at a figure which recognises the special circumstances surrounding the particular remote hotel or motel, discounted by 40 per cent, minus the board that would be paid.

It was suggested that the Nullarbor Motel, with 20 employees, would be up for $104,000. He said that was 800 per cent wrong, that it would be around $13,000 and not $104,000. I remind the Minister that that is a differential of $91,000. When the Minister advises people he must stop and think whether or not he has done them a good turn if they happen to get it wrong. He went on to say:

In the case of people living full time in a hotel or motel, or who have their meals in a restaurant where they work permanently, the value of the meal will be determined at $2 for an adult and $1 for a child.
But on page 24 of the FBT tax guide-that wonderful pink or purple document-under `Housing Fringe Benefits-hotel and motel accommodation', it says:
. . . broadly, goods or services-
Clearly, hotels are services-

supplied by an employer whose business it is to provide similar or identical goods or services to the public-the taxable value is reduced to 75 per cent of the market value, less the employee's rent etc. That will be the case, for example, if a hotel employee is provided with residential accommodation in the employer's hotel similar to that provided to paying guests.

I have been in the hotel industry a long time and honourable members can take my word for it that the accommodation is similar. Employees frequently just occupy an ordinary room; and they will be taxed at the market value. But the point I make is that there is now a bloke out in the Nullarbor Plain who has the option of declaring a tax responsibility on an amount of $13,000 or on an amount of $104,000. What happens if he gets it wrong? The Government will call him a tax evader. He will be the person who suffers and not the Government, which is trying to paint its fringe benefits tax as something it is not.
Yesterday, in answer to another dorothy dix question on the FBT and log books, the Treasurer said:

. . . for business purposes . . . Log books do not have to be filled in if owners of vehicles wish to use the statutory rule which has been provided by the Government. I do not have a copy of the precise rule with me-
He could not even remember his own tax laws-
but it means that the write-off is around 40 per cent for 5,000 kilometres-
That is a downright untruth. There is no evidence of that. He continued:

of vehicle usage, and for usage up to 25,000 kilometres it is about 75 per cent to 80 per cent. In other words, if a motorist wishes not to bother about the log book, he does not have to. He can fall back on the statutory rule if he so chooses. If, however, the owner of a business or a self-employed person wishes to claim 80 to 90 per cent, or something of that order-
Suggesting that it is only the top 10 or 20 per cent-

and substantiate to the kilometre the differentiation between private and business use, then the log books, quite properly and sensibly, are available for that purpose. All they need to do is to enter in the log book each day the private mileage and the balance is automatically designated as business mileage. It is not an onerous obligation. The notion that a person must fill in details of every trip that has been put about by the Coalition is, of course, nonsense.
Yet pages 8 and 9 of the Australian Taxation Office's Income Tax and Car Expenses booklet say `as per attached'. I have my hands on it, so can tell honourable members what it says. It says:
There are different methods you can use to prove your claim for car expenses.
Where you do more than 5,000 business kilometres a year you can claim:
Actual business expenses.
Receipts are defined as:
This method requires you to keep:
receipts, invoices or similar documents for all car expenses;
a detailed log book--

TALK.START.PARA: —Requires!
—Yes. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: A summary of kilometres travelled.

If you fail to use a log book one can have 12 per cent of the cost of the price of the car-12 per cent is his statutory rule-which is about $1,000 a year deductions for running a car, or one can have a third of the actual expenses. Of course, that again means full substantiation. So where does the Treasurer get all of this drivel I have just read out? Where does he substantiate that? He made it up because he is getting worried about his fringe benefits tax. But the point is that people will have heard him on the radio yesterday. Some of the newspapers actually published the rubbish he spoke. What happens to those people if they get it wrong? According to this Treasurer they are tax evaders.

Those rules apply just for substantiation because the Treasurer is mixed up because he has no knowledge of the laws he brings in here. He will give us all the rhetoric in the world but he cannot answer any substantial questions. He just tells us that he is not a computer. As I said this morning, we agree with that comment.

It is the other side of the question on which he was getting a bit mixed up, and that is the fringe benefits tax requirement for employees using vehicles. That is different too. That requirement states that if one uses a vehicle for less than 15,000 kilometres, one will be taxed on 24 per cent of the value of the vehicle; from 15,000 kilometres to 25,000 kilometres one will be taxed on 18 per cent of the value of the vehicle; from 25,000 to 40,000 kilometres one will be taxed on 10 per cent of the vehicle and for more than 40,000 kilometres one will be taxed on 6 per cent of the value of the vehicle. That is another statutory rule and it still has no relationship to the figures that the Treasurer threw around in here yesterday when he was trying to paint up his words. He even put out another Press release in response to the criticisms of the Opposition yesterday. He said that one can just make the odd entry in the log book but, of course, that is not what the legislation tells us. The legislation is very specific in what it tells us.

I became the owner of a log book printed by the firm Gillingham Printers Pty Ltd is South Australia. Written very clearly on that log book is `Approved by the Commissioner of Taxation Canberra'. I rang that firm to assure myself that it did get approval. The people there told me that they did. This is what the log book tells me I have to record for each journey: I have to record the date of the journey, the odometer reading, start and finish, the purpose of the journey and, contrary to what the Treasurer said yesterday, business kilometres travelled. I also have to record the name of the driver, the date of entry, which I presume is different from the date of journey, the name of the person making the entry, presuming that is different from the name of the driver, and I have to sign it. The Commissioner wants nine separate entries. That is what he has told the printers of log books and that is what we will have to fill in.

Let us take that another step. The Treasurer suggested we could have one entry for the day. If one leaves home by car and travels to work, they are private kilometres travelled. If one gets to work and the boss says, or you have notice from your secretary, that you have to go off and see someone, they are business kilometres travelled. If one returns to the office, one might do a couple more business trips. Then comes lunch. They are private kilometres travelled. After lunch, one starts business again, and then one goes home. If the Treasurer can work out how one gets all that into one entry, I would like to know.
What I am really on about is that the other thing the Treasurer has done is to change substantially the tax laws of Australia in terms of self-assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —His interest is pretty significant too.
—And they said tax was going to be the big issue.

—We are here to discuss taxation but honourable members opposite do not want to hear about it. They are too busy telling fibs. All they are interested in is winning the argument. They do not want to be confused by the facts. The reality is that in changing over to self-assessment, a draconian change has been made because they have removed some words out of section 170 (3). The section has been changed so that it now reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a taxpayer has made to the Commissioner a full and true disclosure of all the material facts necessary for his assessment, and an assessment is made after that disclosure, no amendment of the assessment increasing the liability of the taxpayer in any particular shall be made . . . after the expiration of 3 years from the date upon which the tax became due and payable under that assessment.
Some interesting words were taken out:
except to correct an error in calculation or a mistake of fact . . .

One can now be reassessed for any reason within three years, including the reason that one failed to make full and true disclosure. What about the people who have heard the Treasurer, Senator Walsh and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism lately? If that poor little motel operator believes the Treasurer and understates his taxation by $90,000 a year, it might be three years-in fact, it might be seven years-before he finds out, by which time he has a tax bill of $560,000 which he obviously cannot afford. Of course, he has not put his prices up to compensate for this burden. That is the message that the Treasurer and the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism passed out yesterday. When people previously sent in their return No. 1, they had the opportunity to have the Commissioner assess it and write back: `Look pal, you have got it wrong' but under self-assessment the Commissioner will believe them for the time being. They can receive a visit from a field auditor for anything up to seven years. The field auditor has carte blanche for three years on one ground but in fact I believe the Commissioner has every reason to argue that, if one has interpreted the laws and the rules of this very complex tax incorrectly, there has been a failure to make a full and true disclosure. So the Commissioner has seven years on him. Those people who listen to the Government listen to it misleading them, and misleading them dramatically, saying things that are absolutely contrary to what the laws say and absolutely contrary to what the pink book and the other books that have come from the Commissioner of Taxation say. The Government is trying to hose it down, but what is it doing? It is telling people to evade the tax, which is the very thing that it is accusing the Opposition of doing. The Government is saying that we are doing it; it is doing it by painting the tax as being something that it is not. The Treasurer even went to the trouble of putting out an extra release yesterday. He is wrong. The Act is quite clear. It is section 136 (1) of the Act which refers to relevant car documents and which requires all those things that I read out a moment ago.

Just on this occasion we will put up with honourable members on the Government side telling us all these stupid stories about the economy and about how the Government has it `dead right'. We know the operative word is `dead'. We will put up with that; we do not mind that, but, for goodness sake, leave the people of Australia alone. Honourable members opposite should not tell them untruths; they should not come in here and try to defend themselves from a political disaster and put over stories about the working of this tax to make it seem more moderate and to bluff people into becoming tax evaders under self-assessment. That is what they are doing, and they are doing it in other areas, too. That is a disaster and a disgrace. If the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) gets up and defends that attitude, I will make sure that his constituents know that he is prepared to mislead them, too. That is what we are complaining about. We are not complaining about the tax at the moment; we are complaining that the Government is misleading people in regard to its implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I issue an invitation to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to come by my electorate any time he wants. I am sure if he did so my majority would increase dramatically. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) have continually pointed out in this House that we welcome debate on taxation because we believe firmly, because it is a fact, that in the run up to the next election people will see quite clearly the facts of taxation and what this Government has done in contrast to what the previous Government, to which the honourable member belonged, did and in contrast to the proposals that the Opposition has put forward or is contemplating in relation to either taxation or eradicating proposals that this Government has already put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: In that instance, the Government welcomes the motion that has been put before the House, because it does not argue against the fringe benefit tax; it merely discusses whether we have explained it well enough. Talking about misinformation, if the tax has not been explained to people well enough it is mostly because of the misinformation that has been deliberately put forward by Opposition members who for many, many months have been running around the country completely misleading people about the facts-about what this tax is all about and about what it will do. It is a shameful indictment of this Parliament that honourable members on the other side have not been able to go forward and inform people of the facts, whether they are good or bad. The facts stand up. We have seen honourable members on the Opposition side of the House, including the honourable member for O'Connor, going around Australia and deliberately misleading people about what the changes to the taxation system are all about-the fringe benefits tax is one element. Indeed it is ironical to look back at a few of the quotes from the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). If one looks at what he has said in the past, one will see that he agrees with the fringe benefits tax. In 1980, when the Leader of the Opposition was the Treasurer of this country, he said:

Fairness demands that employees who are paid solely in cash-and most Australians are-should not be asked to pay more tax and thus effectively subsidise those whose income is obtained partly in cash and partly in the form of valuable benefits of other kinds.
That was a quote from the Leader of the Opposition when he was Treasurer of this country. Further, on 30 July 1986, on the Carleton-Walsh Report, the Leader of the Opposition said:

I said when I made the announcement about the fringe benefits tax that what we were going to do was get rid of Mr Hawke's fringe benefits tax and the abuses in that area-and there were some, are some, and would be some in the future-would be dealt with in another fashion.

That is what the Leader of the Opposition said. In effect he said: `We will get rid of Hawke's tax and introduce Howard's tax'. Members of the Opposition come in here and say that they do not agree with the fringe benefits tax; however their leader does not agree with them. Every week when we come into this House the Opposition is going to do away with some taxes, but then decides that it wants to keep them, and the next week it changes its mind again. What has happened about the entertainment tax? Is the Opposition keeping it this week or not? I believe the figure for a full year is $330m. There were squeals about the entertainment tax-restaurants on every corner were going to close-but not now. There was a lull in proceedings at some restaurants for a few months, I agree, but now they are as full as they ever were. The vast majority are back to making profits now that things are back on an even keel. The Australian people are not subsidising free lunches to the tune of $330m a year, as they were before under the Government to which Opposition members belonged.

It is interesting to look at the car tax. I have had a number of representations on this and have thought it quite ludicrous to believe that real estate agents, travelling salesmen or people whose work, shall we say, between 9 o'clock and 5 o'clock is totally business orientated on the road or whatever travel they do is for business must fill in numerous entries in their log books. I have said that to believe that is obviously quite stupid; there must be a simple answer to that. Of course, there is. The Government has pronounced it and the Australian Taxation Office has given a ruling that if a real estate agent, for example, drives to work at 9 o'clock and does a dozen trips in a day, all of which are for business, he has one entry for the day. As the Treasurer said yesterday, a number of people who are claiming 90 to 95 per cent for business trips could do it the simple way by merely deducting from the overall figure the small proportion of private use, which is probably to and from work. That is the simple method and it is the method that has been introduced. It has been ruled on not only by the Government but also by the Taxation Office.

Let us look at a few other taxation measures. As I said in this House in my speech on the Budget, it was interesting to note that the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Hunt), spoke about fuel taxes in his speech on the Budget. In 1980-81, the fuel tax was 8.9 per cent of total receipts; today it is 1.8 per cent. As has been pointed out in this House before, the Opposition when it was in government was the one that received the easy money. Nearly 9 per cent of total receipts came from the petrol tax. It is 1.8 per cent now. That shows that, no matter which party is in government, obviously there are budgetary problems if suddenly we lose easy money. The Government has overcome that; the deficit has come down to $3.5 billion. We have introduced a range of other taxes to compensate for the massive tax cuts, the largest tax cuts that this country has seen, which will be introduced in December and next July. We will be putting $1.5 billion into the system in December and another $4.5 billion into the system on 1 July next year, which is in the legislation which was introduced in this House. We shall see the top tax rate come down from 60c in the dollar to 49c and 40c. It is worth repeating that the Opposition had the stewardship of this country for 31 out of 34 years-not merely for a couple of years. When you left office the top rate was still 60c in the dollar.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman might address the Chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, it is still 60c in the dollar, and this Government will bring it down. The two top rates will be 49c and 40c.
—The 60c rate was the John Howard one.

—That is right. The John Howard rate was 60c in the dollar. The honourable member for O'Connor talked about small business but, apart from the car tax, he did not say how taxation was affecting it greatly. Company tax as a percentage of total Budget receipts varied between 10.8 per cent and 13.4 per cent between 1976-77 and 1983-84, which was the period of the Fraser Government. It then plummeted at the start of the Hawke Government's term of office to 9.1 per cent, and it has increased this year to 9.9 per cent. It is still below the percentage under the Fraser Government although it is rising. It is improving because of the profitability that has been introduced into the system under the present Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Business profits are back to the levels of the 1960s, which accounts for the rise in company tax receipts. However, they have still not reached the level that applied under the Fraser Government. Indeed, the following statement is made on page 360 of the Budget in respect of PAYE taxpayers:
Collections from other non-PAYE individuals as a proportion of total receipts fell in the 1970s, reflecting the relative weakness in primary producer incomes and increased recourse to tax avoidance.

As the Prime Minister said today, tax avoidance was the largest growth industry in this country during the present Opposition's reign in the 1970s and early 1980s under the Fraser Government. The Budget Papers tell us that there was `increased recourse to tax avoidance.'

Let us consider some of the promises that the Leader of the Opposition has given on behalf of the coalition parties. The Opposition says that it is going to institute income splitting, which will cost $2.7 billion. It says that it will have a flatter tax system, not a flat one. The Opposition's spokesman on Treasury matters, the honourable member for Mackellar has said that he does not agree with a flat tax system because-and at least he was honest-everyone earning less than $26,000 a year would be paying more tax. Under a flat tax system with a threshold of $5,000, we would need a tax rate of 33c in the dollar if we were to achieve the present result. At least the Opposition spokesman on Treasury matters addressed himself to that. As I have said, the Opposition wants a flatter tax system, whatever that means, and not a flat tax system.

Under a flatter tax system the top rate would be taken down to 40c, although some in the Liberal Party, including Andrew Hay, want a rate of 30c. That would cost $1.6 billion. The abolition of the fringe benefits tax would cost $325m. As I have said, the Leader of the Opposition still agrees with some form of fringe benefit tax. Apparently he would abolish capital gains tax. That would cost $5m. Abolition of tax on lump sum superannuation payments would cost $80m. When the honourable gentleman last spoke he argued for the reinstitution of entertainment expenses, and that would cost $310m. The reinstitution of negative gearing would cost $50m while the full flow-on of world oil price reductions would cost $400m. The abolition of sales tax on oils and lubricants would cost $66m. The abolition of tax on new oil would cost $165m. The provision of child care rebates would cost $108m. The restoration of income equalisation deposits and `in-out' tax averaging would cost $23m. The abolition of wine tax would cost $107m. All in, the cost would be $5.9 billion.

Apart from the assets test and a few other goodies such as Medicare-allowing the healthy to opt out and leaving the old and the sick to carry the can-the books will be balanced at a figure of $3.5 billion. All up, the cost will be $11 billion. We have not heard one word from the Opposition about where it will find that sum. That amount is in excess of two education budgets. From where will the money be found? If it is to be taken with one hand, it will have to be put back into the system with the other. That is fairly basic economics. Unless expenditure is cut to that extent-

TALK.START.PARA: —We will do that.

—The honourable member for Wakefield says that the Opposition will cut expenditure by that much. That means that the entire education and defence budgets will be cut out. That would be the consequence of the sums that the Opposition is talking about. It is talking about $11 billion. Opposition members talk in the chamber about cars and fringe benefits tax and about misleading the public. They are the ones who have misled the public.
—No, the Government did.
—You are the ones who have misled the public. You are the ones who have run around the country trying to confuse people. You are the ones who have done all that.

—Order! The honourable gentleman would serve himself well if he observed the Standing Orders. He must refer to the honourable members opposite by the seats that they represent. The honourable gentleman must address his remarks through the Chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is the Opposition that has confused the public. It has deliberately misled the Australian public in describing what the taxation changes that the Government has introduced are all about. The Government has introduced fairness to the system. When all the changes have been made, the people will see the fairness of the system, which was never seen when the coalition government was in office.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a lot of nonsense and drivel from the Opposition this afternoon, but it has failed to address itself to taxation. The Government welcomes the debate on tax. We shall pursue the issue and win it because the people of Australia will see through the Opposition's nonsense. Instead, they will look at the facts as presented by the Government, which will be a clear indication that the taxation system that is finally introduced by the Government will be one of fairness.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable gentleman's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the matter of public importance that was introduced by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). The honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles)-this will be my only comment on his speech-failed to answer the assertions made by the honourable member for O'Connor in respect of at least three extremely relevant matters that he wanted answered. One of those matters concerned a businessman who operates on the Nullarbor Plains. Do not tell me that that man is to be penalised by the Government after waiting for seven years because he has not received a correct answer from the Minister concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is a replica of the Whitlam Administration. It is living day by day. It has invoked policies, especially on taxation, without doing its homework. It has introduced these policies because of the pressure from the Australian Council of Trade Unions and from certain parts of the Labor Party, which have said that the Government must transfer money from the pocket of one person to that of another within Australia. That is the Labor Party's old tax cry. Measures have been adopted that are not sustainable. The Government knows that they will not be accepted by the ordinary Australian, especially businessmen and farmers, large and small, who do not want the extra costs, worry, and concern that were outlined by the honourable member for O'Connor.

Our minds must go back to the Tax Summit and to option C which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) suggested to the people of Australia at the time. That option may have been acceptable. It may have been adopted by the Summit. However, as everyone will recall, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) met the ACTU in the middle of the night and decided that another tax formula would have to be adopted for the people of Australia. I shall continue to repeat that we have in office a high taxing government. The Labor States of Australia are taxing to the utmost those to whom they should be giving relief and providing incentives to employ others so as to increase their trading turnover. I often wonder how this Government-and this has been borne out in the recent Budget-will continue to keep its social security commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Support the people.

—Yes, support to the people. The Government has already put off its commitments to the age pensioners and perhaps it will again put off its commitments to them in a mini-Budget early in 1987 because the economy cannot sustain those commitments. Let us look at what the impositions are. Not only do we have a fringe benefits tax we also have a number of new tax impositions such as the capital gains tax and the superannuation tax. The Government did away with negative gearing. Only last night in my speech on the Budget I explained the problems these taxes are creating for the very people the Government claims to be supporting. It should not blame the state of the economy on the fact that we do not have overseas markets for our products. The Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) is at present overseas participating in multilateral talks, trying to convince the parties that agriculture should come under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Agriculture may not come into the GATT while this Government is not facing up to its economic responsibilities in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a Prime Minister who in 1983 said to the people of Australia: `We will reduce the price of petrol by 3c a litre'. As the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) said today, the Government has increased the price of petrol by 13c a litre since it came to office. It has increased the tax on petrol from 5.8c to over 24c a litre, in addition to the imposition of fringe benefits and other taxes. These are taxes the Government has created and imposed upon the producers of Australia, whether they be in small business, industry, manufacturing, motor vehicles and components, or whether they are working on the farm. The Government is guilty and the people of this nation are the judge and jury who will decide in 1988, or whenever the election is held, whether the Government will be returned.

Mr Deputy Speaker, if you had watched television this morning you would know that, as one of our leading writers and commentators said, it is common knowledge that our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has lost his touch. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) is in the chamber. I will bet that many honourable members opposite would rather see him leading Australia today than the man they have. It is interesting that this afternoon in another place a question was asked of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) relating to the arbitrary limit of $150 for fringe benefit tax liability for a farm employee and the repercussions of non-compliance. The Minister for Finance failed to answer the direct question but made a vicious attack on the National Farmers Federation, the body under which all primary producers are united. He said that the NFF is the problem because Elders and the bigger farmers are involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are red raggers and anti-American.

—They are not red raggers. That is an untruth. The Minister for Foreign Affairs accuses National Farmers Federation members of being red raggers. That is what he said and every Australian ought to know what he has said about them. It is a darned disgrace to Australia for a member of the Cabinet to accuse members of the National Farmers Federation, Elders and other companies of being red raggers. These people were the pioneers of this country. They established themselves and cleared our countryside, and as a result we have the standard of living that we enjoy today. It is shameful that the Minister should attack the farmers in the way he does.

SPEECH.PARA: On the land there is a close relationship between the employer and the employee. It is something that many of us on this side understand because we are farmers and we come from the land. That relationship is very close indeed. A farmer likes his employee to live on the farm and he engages him and gives him certain concessions. He might not have to do that, but because he has the facilities he provides them. I know that milk and honey and meat and other things such as accommodation and power are provided to the employee on the farm. He gets the benefit of these concessions. About 30,000 farmers came to Canberra and stood outside Parliament House--

TALK.START.PARA: —Fifty thousand.
—Fifty thousand. They coaxed the Prime Minister to come out. He came out and he said: `I will look at the fringe benefits tax and we will give you certain concessions'.
—He never did a thing.

—As the Leader of the Opposition says, the only concession I know of is that meat will be assessed on its value at the sale yards. The Prime Minister did not respond as promised; just as he did not respond after having promised to reduce petrol prices by 3c. On Friday diesel fuel will go up by 5.8c a litre.
—It is not enough.

—There you are; the honourable member for Macarthur says that it is not enough. Is it any wonder that the Minister for Foreign Affairs gets up, because he is so embarrassed by this, and declares that the NFF members are red raggers. The truth of the matter is that the fringe benefits tax will cost the rural producers between $10m and $15m. Not only will there be a cost to the farmer, his wife and the employee, but they will also have the worry of filling out the log books, attending to the administration, and so on. They will incur an extra accountancy fee. These things have to be paid for. The farmer is not a person who reads every line in the Taxation Act. I think it is section 26c of the Act which states that the Government may tax the employee. It has the right now to tax the employee--
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition totally lacks credibility in raising this issue. I remind the House of the credibility of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), the former Treasurer. His Government ran the most disgraceful campaign in 1977 and suggested to the people of Australia that it would give them a fistful of dollars. It ran the campaign under the tag that Liberals give and Labor takes. I remind the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) that in 1978 the present Leader of the Opposition took away those tax concessions. The Opposition has a miserable record of performance in government. I quote an article from the Age concerning the taxation White Paper, made available to me by the Parliamentary Library. It states: `The opportunism and cowardice of successive governments have produced a hideously complex tax structure that is riddled with loopholes and inequities. The extent of the drift to unfairness can be seen in a few statistics cited in the paper's opening chapter. The marginal rate of income tax that is paid on every additional dollar for a taxpayer on average earnings has soared from 19 per cent to 46 per cent in 30 years'. The proportion of gross income paid out in income tax, has risen from 10 per cent to 25 per cent. Nearly 40 per cent of all full time employees now face a marginal tax rate of 46c compared to about one per cent in 1955. The effect has been not only to discourage the honest from making greater effort but also to produce a multitude of cheats and tricksters. In spite of the tougher policies adopted in recent years, tax avoidance and evasion have reached epidemic proportions. As the previous Government speaker, the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) pointed out in an excellent speech, for 31 of the last 34 years the Opposition has occupied the treasury bench.

SPEECH.PARA: What has been the role of the Opposition during this whole series of painful taxation reforms that this Government has had the guts to tackle? Have Opposition members sat on the sidelines and said, `This is such an important issue to all the people of Australia that we feel that we must support the process'? Of course they have not. At each and every opportunity they have sought to misinform or alarm the people of Australia. Indeed, the lead speaker for the Opposition today would win yet again the Michael Hodgman award for deceit, dishonesty and dishonour--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member is out of line insofar as he referred to the honourable member in a manner inconsistent with the Standing Orders. He also expressed it in terms that might invite a withdrawal.

—I withdraw unreservedly, but I draw to the House's attention the fact that it has been a consistent ploy of the Opposition to misinform people. The text of the matter is very significant to the debate. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's failure to adequately explain the operation of its new taxing measures, including the Fringe Benefits Tax, and the resulting confusion and disincentive for business-big and small.

TALK.START.PARA: —They agree with it.

—That is the point I raise. Are honourable members opposite disagreeing with the tax? Are they saying that they are violently opposed to the tax? Have they said in this debate that, if elected, they will withdraw the tax? My colleague has already quoted some words used by the then Treasurer, now the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), in 1980. Let me also quote some comments that he made in the Carleton-Walsh Report. This sheds some interesting light on whether or not the Opposition would withdraw the fringe benefits tax. On 30 July 1986 the Leader of the Opposition said:

SPEECH.PARA: I said when I made the announcement about fringe benefits tax that we were going to get rid of Mr Hawke's fringe benefits tax. That is, the abuses in the area-and there were some and are some and would be some in the future-would be dealt with in another fashion.

In other words, that bit of rhetoric means that those opposite will be happy to withdraw the Hawke fringe benefits tax. What they are not spelling out, although clearly it is their intention to do it, is that they will introduce the Howard fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —And hit the workers.

—And hit the workers, as the honourable member for Dobell has said. That is where their dishonesty and deceit comes in. They are not prepared to be frank with the people of Australia. I want to run through their appalling credibility problem on taxation measures. Their shopping list of taxation reforms-the things that they claim they will do-will cost $5.9 billion. Where will they get the money from? The abolition of the wines tax will cost $107m; the restoration of income equalisation deposits and in-and-out tax averaging, $23m; the provision of child care rebates, $108m; the abolition of tax on new oil, $185m; the abolition of sales tax on oils and lubricants, $66m; the full flow-on of world price reductions, $400m; the reinstitution of negative gearing, $50m; the reinstitution of entertainment expenses, $310m; the abolition of tax on lump sum superannuation, $30m; the capital gains tax, $5m; the fringe benefits tax, $325m; a flatter tax system, $1.6 billion; and the institution of incomes splitting, $2.7 billion. Honourable members opposite have outlandish spending commitments, and here we can see that they have outlandish taxation commitments. Where will they get the money from?

SPEECH.PARA: Our taxation proposals, of which the fringe benefits tax is an important part, will cost us $1.5 billion at December. From 1 July, they will cost this Government-we have laid the groundwork so that we can implement the system and we will deliver it-$4.5 billion. Where will the Opposition find this $5.9 billion? No wonder it does not have any credibility in relation to the fringe benefits tax. I want to outline the position in regard to fringe benefits. Let us take the highest-paid 11 per cent of wage and salary earners-not the ordinary people of the electorate of the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) or the preceding speaker's electorate or my electorate. These measures will not hurt them. Indeed, they are currently paying for it, as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said in 1980. Of the highest paid 11 per cent, one in six receives a private transport fringe benefit. One in seven receives an entertainment allowance. One-quarter have private telephone costs paid for or subsidised by their employers. One in 12 enjoys employer-provided or subsidised housing. One in 12 has his medical and/or hospital costs paid for or subsidised by his employer. I am not talking about the poor in the community or about those on average weekly earnings; I am talking about the highest-paid people in our community. One in 13 has his holidays paid for or subsidised by his employer. One in 20 has his club fees paid as a fringe benefit. One in 26 receives a share in the employer's firm as an employment benefit.

We can see from this that the Opposition is really asking that the vast majority of Australians who do not have access to these fringe benefits should assume in their tax burden the responsibility for giving these fringe benefits to the wealthiest-the top 11 per cent-in our community. As more and more people come to understand the fringe benefits taxation legislation, it is no wonder that they can understand the equity and justice behind our proposals. That is why we will get support every time we mount a public platform in support of the fringe benefits tax.

I wish to make a couple of quick points about this business of the log book. There is no legal requirement under the fringe benefits tax or the substantiation provisions for anyone to keep a log book. Taxpayers may do so, but in most cases they will find a satisfactory tax result by adopting the concessionary formula--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The discussion is concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 250th report of the Committee, relating to the Review of the Discontinuance of the Efficiency Audit of Australia Post-Administration of Counter Services, and I seek leave of the House to make a short statement in connection with the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chairman of the Committee will be delivering a statement in similar terms in the Senate. I make this statement on his behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: Report 250 details the findings of the Committee's Review of the Discontinuance of the Efficiency Audit of Australia Post-Administration of Counter Services. The efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of its counter services began in June 1980 and was discontinued by the then Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, in October 1984. It was one of the earliest and longest efficiency audits conducted by the Australian Audit Office. Subsequent to the discontinuance, an informal draft report of the efficiency audit was disclosed to the media without authorisation. This resulted in allegations about the motives of the Auditor-General regarding his decision to discontinue the audit. On 20 June 1985 the Committee announced that it would review the circumstances surrounding the discontinuance of that audit.

On 30 June 1980, after a feasibility study, the Auditor-General notified the Australian Postal Commission that an efficiency audit into the provision of services to the public through post offices would be undertaken. It was anticipated that field work would commence in July 1980 and that a report would be tabled in Parliament in mid-1981. The initial audit team comprised five staff. Australia Post was advised in May 1981 that further field work would be undertaken, that further information was required and that Mr D. Berthelsen would be the Audit Officer's project leader from June 1981. The staff on the audit was shortly after reduced to two and then to only one person.

From mid-1981 until late 1983, further field work was undertaken and considerable delays were experienced in the writing of the draft report. Several different drafts were submitted to the Committee, which indicated that there had been differing views on the report content. This informal draft report was a precursor to any formal draft to been seen by the Auditor-General. Under the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, the Auditor-General is required to issue a formal draft report to the audited organisation and to take the views of that organisation into account in his final report.

In May 1984 an incomplete informal draft report was sent officially to Australia Post. A non-specific response from Australia Post in July 1984 resulted in senior officers of the Efficiency Audit Division becoming increasingly concerned that, while this audit was the only audit outstanding from those commenced by the Efficiency Audit Division, considerable effort would be required to bring it to finality. These concerns were expressed to the Auditor-General in August 1984. The two basic problems brought to the Auditor-General's attention were: That the Australia Post efficiency audit had been running for some 4.5 years; and that for over two years there was only one officer, Mr Berthelsen, conducting the audit and reporting direct to the division head.

The Auditor-General discussed in late September 1984 the completion of the report with Mr Berthelsen and was given assurances that the audit report would be finished within four weeks. A month was allowed for completion. At the end of the month Mr Berthelsen requested a further six weeks to complete the report. In late October 1984 the then Auditor-General, Mr Brigden, decided to discontinue the audit. The Committee was presented with a list of some 19 occasions when completion dates for the report had been given by Mr Berthelsen. On 7 February 1985 the Auditor-General advised Australia Post that further work necessary to carry out the audit on Australia Post would not be undertaken. The Committee concluded that the decision taken by the Auditor-General to discontinue the efficiency audit was justified. However, the debate on whether the audit should have been continued was not put aside.

The issues were raised again by Mr Berthelsen with the new Auditor-General, Mr J. Monaghan, on 8 March 1985. In May 1985 the Auditor-General formally responded to Mr Berthelsen. The Auditor-General noted that the Australia Post efficiency audit suffered the consequences of a serious management failure. He found that the audit groundwork was not sufficient for the previous Auditor-General to judge that the draft audit conclusions could be sustained against Australia Post's likely rebuttals. The Auditor-General advised Mr Berthelsen that he would not be reviewing Mr Brigden's decision further. However, the debate continued, including claim and counter claim as to the worth of continuing the audit to its final conclusion of reporting in detail to the Parliament. This occurred both within the Audit Office and later before the Parliamentary Public Accounts Committee. As part of the Committee's review, advice was sought from the Attorney-General's Department, the Committee's legal adviser, the Auditor-General, and Mr K. Brigden, the former Auditor-General, as to the basis of the Auditor-General's legal power to discontinue an efficiency audit. These advisings are documented in the Committee's report.

On this matter the Committee concluded: Firstly, the former Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, had the discretion to discontinue the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services under section 48e (1) of the Audit Act 1901; secondly, the former Auditor-General, Mr K. Brigden, failed to present a report on the efficiency audit of Australia Post under section 48f (1); thirdly, the Auditor-General, Mr J. Monaghan, complied in part with section 48g (1), when he reported the discontinuance of this efficiency audit in the Annual Report of the Auditor-General 1984-85; and, fourthly, the Auditor-General should comply with section 48f and 48g of the Audit Act 1901 as is relevant to the efficiency audit of Australia Post's administration of counter services.

The Committee also examined the management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post in the Efficiency Audit Division. The first head of that Division, Mr J. Jones, told the Committee that he decided to delegate responsibility to others to manage projects and, as Division head, to develop methodology, select topics and maintain quality control. Mr Jones stated that this `option, had its risks, because when people are allowed to learn by doing they make mistakes'. Mr Jones accepted responsibility for the fact that-he conceded it was so-the management of the Australia Post audit was deficient. Mr Jones claimed that he had difficulties working with the former Auditor-General, Mr Brigden. Mr Brigden was aware that relationships generally were not harmonious between that Division and the rest of the Audit Office. He also said that, throughout the Division's existence, problems with the major audits undertaken remained the same. Audit scope was not defined and maintained with precision and audits were not managed firmly or documented properly.

Mr Brigden told the Committee that considerable pressure was brought to bear upon the Division head with a view to having all 16 of the audits originally undertaken by the Division completed by the end of 1983, but these efforts were by no means successful. Only seven had been completed-since 1978-when the head of the Efficiency Audit Division proceeded on leave early in 1984. In an endeavour to expedite the completion of the remaining audits, major changes were made to long standing administrative and reporting arrangements within the Audit Office. In May 1985 the Auditor-General, Mr J. Monaghan, decided that all major project audits directed to efficiency and operational effectiveness issues would be formally designated as efficiency audits. The aim was to achieve an average turnaround of approximately nine months from designation to tabling. He expected that, on this basis, some 20 to 30 efficiency audits per year would be conducted. The Audit Office has introduced revised management practices to ensure that management objectives, including improved reporting objectives for efficiency audits, are achieved. There is some evidence that the aims of both Auditors-General-Mr K. Brigden and Mr J. Monaghan-to make efficiency auditing much more timely have been achieved. Overall, the Committee found:
The efficiency audit of Australia Post was not well managed, resulting in a lack of concise and timely reporting;

There were serious communication problems regarding the efficiency audit of Australia Post within the Efficiency Audit Division; between the Auditor-General (Mr Brigden) and the Efficiency Audit Division; and between the Efficiency Audit Division and the rest of the Audit Office; and
The scope of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was not well defined and maintained;
The Committee concluded:
The management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post-administration of counter services, was deficient;
The ultimate responsibility from 1981 to 1984 for the management of the Efficiency Audit Division and of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was the Auditor-General's;

The management of the efficiency audit of Australia Post was not in keeping with the Australian Audit Office's goals, that is, that the Australian Audit Office should be exemplary as regards accountability for its functions and the efficiency, economy and effectiveness of its operations;

The Australia Post audit was not only the longest but also the costliest efficiency audit. The Committee anticipates that the Auditor-General will provide the total cost of the efficiency audit of the administration of Australia Post's counter services in his next annual report.

The issue of stamp security was also raised before the Committee. Amongst other matters, it was alleged that the Auditor-General may have misled the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) on the issue of postage stamp thefts. The Committee concluded:
stamp security within Australia Post was not related to the decision to discontinue the efficiency audit of Australia Post-Administration of Counter Services; and
further detailed investigation of the security of stamps and other negotiable paper by the Auditor-General is warranted.

I would like to express the Committee's appreciation to the Auditor-General and his staff, the former Auditor-General and the staff of Australia Post for their co-operation provided throughout the review. The Committee thanks its legal adviser, the Hon. Mr Justice Paul Toose, and members of its own Secretariat for the support given during this very difficult inquiry. I commend this report to honourable members.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Dr Blewett, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Bill before the House makes a number of important changes to areas within the Health portfolio. Most of these changes have already been announced by the Government as part of the Budget and are, in the main, measures which will provide substantial reductions in government expenditure. Honourable members are aware of the difficult economic circumstances which necessitated a rigorous scrutiny of all areas of government expenditure. Clearly, the Health portfolio had to play its part, but the Government has been concerned to ensure that any changes should be made in the fairest possible way.

The amendments in this Bill are part of an overall package of measures within the health area which achieves the Government's Budget objective of restraint with equity. In relation to Medicare, the Bill will increase the maximum gap payment between the Medicare rebate and the schedule of fees from $10 to $20 from 1 November. Complementary changes not requiring legislative amendments are the deferral of schedule fee increases until 1 November and the 25 per cent reduction in schedule fees for 18 pathology tests, which has applied since 1 August.

These changes, together with the increase in the Medicare levy to 1.25 per cent, have enabled the Government to preserve its commitment to a universal health insurance scheme based on the principles of equity, simplicity and cost efficiency. Importantly, by adopting this particular strategy, the Government has been able to maintain the Medicare rebate at 85 per cent of the schedule fee, thereby ensuring the continuation of bulk billing which overwhelmingly works to the benefit of pensioners and the disadvantaged. Since 1 July this year nearly 52 per cent of all medical services under Medicare have been direct billed and the vast majority of these were for services provided to pensioners and the disadvantaged. In addition, the maintenance of an income related levy ensures that the burden of paying for health care is spread across the whole community on the basis of ability to pay rather than simply on the sick.

Other major amendments included in this Bill are the establishment of a new pharmaceutical benefits scheme which will provide assistance to those with chronic illnesses and other high volume users of prescription drugs. The isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme is to be abolished from 1 January 1987, although the Commonwealth will continue to fund replacement arrangements administered by the States. Commonwealth controls over the approval and categorisation of private hospitals are to be removed. This latter change accompanies the announcement in the Budget that Commonwealth subsidies to private hospitals will cease from 1 October 1986.

I turn now to a more detailed explanation of the major features of this Bill. Clause 5 of the Bill provides for an increase in the maximum patient contribution between the Medicare benefit rebate and the schedule of fees from $10 to $20 to take effect from 1 November 1986. This is the first increase in this gap since it was introduced in 1978. The increase takes into account the effects of inflation over the past eight years. However, the change will only affect those Medicare services costing more than $67. Therefore the increase will not affect the vast majority of items involving consultations, which are by far the most common type of services.

While the maximum gap payment will increase, the Government will continue to maintain safeguards for people faced with substantial out of pocket expenses for medical services. The $150 maximum annual total gap between benefits and schedule fees will be maintained, which means that once the ceiling of $150 has been reached, Medicare benefits are payable at 100 per cent of schedule fee levels. Private patients in hospitals will continue to have gap payments for medical services covered by their private hospital insurance organisations. In addition, as I have already noted, the Government has retained the 85 per cent rebate level which will enable practitioners to continue to direct bill for pensioners and the chronically ill.

Clause 7 of the Bill repeals provisions in the Health Insurance Act dealing with the approval and categorisation of private hospitals. These amendments will deregulate controls over private hospitals. An associated measure, also announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his Budget Speech, is the removal of government subsidies to private hospitals from 1 October 1986. As a result of this measure, private health insurers will incur additional benefit liability but it is not expected to impact significantly on contribution rates. The exact increases in contribution rates will vary from fund to fund and State to State but, as most funds have accumulated significant levels of reserves, increases should be moderate.

Deregulation of private hospitals is part of the Government's overall strategy of streamlining government and assisting the private sector by removing overlapping and unnecessary layers of bureaucracy. Deregulation also fulfils the undertaking given by the Government to the Australian Medical Association in April 1985, as part of the settlement package for the New South Wales doctors' dispute. The Government has long held the view that the regulation of private hospitals is more appropriately a State responsibility. Only the States have the detailed knowledge required for the rational planning and provisioning of both public and private hospital services. On the other hand, the appropriate role for the Commonwealth is to develop national health policy objectives-not the detailed administration of controls that the States should be administering.

The devolution to the States of Commonwealth controls over the approval and categorisation of private hospital accommodation was an integral part of the original Medicare proposals and is a logical corollary to withdrawal of the subsidy. These controls, while required to prevent unnecessary Commonwealth expenditure, in practice, simply duplicated State controls. The associated abolition of the present government subsidy will not mean a loss of revenue for private hospitals because basic table fund benefits will be increased by the amount of the subsidy. Indeed, hospitals will save in administrative costs by removal of the Commonwealth from the claims and payment process.

At the request of the private hospital industry the current system of paying hospital fund benefits according to the categorisation of private hospitals will be continued as an administrative arrangement for an interim period pending introduction of revised patient classification arrangements from March 1987. As from 1 October 1986, I will declare a new basic hospital table which will ensure that each private hospital receives benefits for insured patients at least equivalent to the sum of the fund benefits and Commonwealth bed day subsidy that were applicable to patients of that hospital on 30 September 1986. In addition, the Bill provides for the continuation of applications and cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal commenced before 1 October, if this is the wish of the applicants.

As a transitional arrangement, the Commonwealth will consider assisting certain private charitable, religious and community hospitals which historically have cared for needy uninsured patients and whose viability has been reliant on that subsidy. The assistance will be in the form of specific purpose lump sum grants to eligible hospitals for the remainder of this financial year. Longer term considerations for these hospitals will be discussed between the Commonwealth and the States. To be eligible, hospitals will have to demonstrate that they have a history of caring for uninsured patients and that a grant to maintain financial viability is necessary to enable continuation of existing services.

While dealing with the amendments that the Bill makes to the Health Insurance Act, I refer honourable members to two minor but important changes. Sub-clause 4 (3), which amends the definition of prescribed `dental patients', will enable the Minister, by determination, to extend Medicare cover of the cleft lip and palate scheme, to include children with other facial deformities, as was originally intended by the scheme. Clause 9 of the Bill amends the secrecy provisions of the Health Insurance Act to further limit the permissible disclosure of information under the exceptions to this provision. In its seventy-ninth report, the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances raised some concerns about certain possible disclosures of information, and this amendment is designed to meet the Committee's concerns.

Part III of the Bill contains amendments to the National Health Act 1953. The amendment made by clause 15 is included to enable the Government to proceed with its proposal to introduce a new program designed to reduce the incidence of hepatitis B among new-born babies most at risk of contracting the disease. This is achieved by including in section 9B of the Act a capacity to expand by regulation the list of diseases for which vaccines may be provided. This approach has the advantage of enabling a quick response to future needs.

I now turn to clause 16 of the Bill, which repeals the provisions of the Act establishing the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme-IPTAAS. As previously announced, this repeal is intended to take effect from 1 January 1987, although the Bill preserves the rights of patients who have commenced journeys to seek medical treatment before that date. As in the case of private hospital deregulation, the abolition of IPTAAS represents a rational streamlining of an inappropriate Commonwealth activity and therefore should be welcomed by all honourable members. Indeed, as many of the criticisms of the current IPTAAS arrangements have come from members opposite. I would be very surprised if the abolition of the scheme in favour of funding to the States does not receive bipartisan support.

I recall that in the second reading debate on the introduction of IPTAAS some years ago I expressed concern about the monstrously bureau- cratic arrangements associated with the administration of the scheme. Unfortunately that concern has proven to be fully justified. Since I became Minister for Health I have received numerous representations which, whilst supporting the basic principles and objectives of the scheme have nevertheless criticised many of its aspects. The criticisms have come from a wide range of sources, including State Ministers for health, Federal and State members, the Commonwealth Ombudsman, groups representing specific classes of patients, groups representing rural patients, social workers associations, and individual patients. The scheme has also been criticised by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The States and Territories are, of course, responsible for the planning and provision of health services and for the actual provision of specific patient transport services such as land and air ambulances and inter-hospital transfers. In superimposing IPTAAS the Commonwealth inappropriately stepped into an area of State and Territory responsibility and effectively distanced the States from valuable planning information on the effectiveness and distribution of their own services. Moreover, the Commonwealth is poorly placed to administer any scheme of this nature, having no suitable delivery and processing mechanism outside the capital cities and at best only a second-hand knowledge of available services. On the other hand, State hospital and welfare delivery networks are well established and some already provide cash advances to the needy in anticipation of IPTAAS benefits. Accordingly, the States and Territories are well placed to develop and administer more flexible and effective measures for those in need.

In deciding to abolish IPTAAS, the Government was particularly conscious that, despite its faults, the program has provided a tremendous amount of much needed support to patients in rural and isolated areas and that the needs of those people must be protected. Accordingly, the Commonwealth will continue to provide substantial funding for patient transport assistance. Funds for the States and the Northern Territory will be provided through special revenue assistance grants. On a full year basis this funding represents a 26 per cent increase over IPTAAS benefits paid in 1985-86 and the funds will be distributed among the States and Territories in proportion to the actual distribution of IPTAAS benefits in that year.

This generous increase in funding will be more than sufficient for the States and Territories to provide effective patient transport arrangements or to provide a greater frequency and range of specialist services to people in remote areas. It will also enable them to meet any demands that might arise for interstate transport, including from capital city residents, for highly specialised services such as liver and heart transplants, magnetic resonance imaging and lithotripsy. I emphasise, however, that the new arrangements are a matter for each State and Territory to determine, having regard to its own distribution of specialist services and the specific needs of its rural population.

On 1 September last year, benefits were introduced to the basic hospital insurance table for day surgery and for the cost of surgically implanted prostheses in public and private hospitals. Sub-clause 14 (1) of the Bill extends these benefits to apply to prostheses supplied in approved free-standing day surgery facilities. There are now five such facilities in Australia. I believe that the continued development of new surgical and anaesthetic techniques will enable many more surgical procedures to be safely completed without the need for an overnight stay, greatly reducing hospital costs and disruption to patients. I take this opportunity to endorse the work of the pioneers of day surgery in established hospitals and new specialised facilities and hope that the health insurance industry will recognise the potential savings by offering greater cover on their supplementary tables to further encourage this development.

The next major changes made by the Bill concern pharmaceutical benefits. Clause 21 of the Bill provides for an increase in the maximum general and concessional patient contributions for pharmaceutical benefits. These changes will be effective from 1 November 1986. General patients will pay a variable amount up to a maximum of $10 per prescription for the supply of a pharmaceutical benefit. Whilst the maximum a patient will pay is $10, the Government estimates the average patient contribution will be about $7.30. The concessional patient contribution will increase from $2.00 to $2.50. This will be the first increase in the contribution since its introduction on 1 January 1983 and is broadly in line with movements in prices and incomes since then.

As in the past, pensioners holding a pensioner health benefits card and their dependants, and sickness beneficiaries holding a health benefits card and their dependants, will not be charged for pharmaceutical benefits. In those few cases where a special patient contribution applies, patients will continue to pay that special patient contribution as well as the standard charge, if applicable. This also applies to pensioners. From 1 November 1986 pharmaceutical benefits for war widows and their dependants will not be available through the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Instead, pharmaceutical benefits will be available to these persons free of charge through the pensioner pharmaceutical benefits scheme. This change will result in improved efficiency of administration.

A major feature of the amendments is to incorporate a safety net which will apply to the supply of pharmaceutical benefits to general and concessional patients. The amendments provide that, from 1 November 1986, no individual or family, including concessional beneficiaries, will have to pay for more than 25 pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescription items in any calendar year. In the first instance the `safety net' will run for 14 months, from 1 November 1986 to 31 December 1987. After that, the scheme will apply for each calender year.

After 1 November 1986, individuals or families will be able to obtain a prescription record form from their pharmacist. This is provided for in clause 19. The pharmacist will enter on the form a record of each prescription supplied. After 25 entries, the pharmacist will issue the individual or family with a pharmaceutical benefits entitlement card which will allow them to receive free pharmaceutical benefits for the remainder of the entitlement period. It is not anticipated that the administrative workload on individual pharmacists will be significant and agreement has been reached with the Pharmacy Guild of Australia on payments to pharmacists for issuing pharmaceutical benefits entitlement cards.

I point out to honourable members that this scheme has been developed with the full co-operation of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. Indeed, the Guild's assistance has made the task that much easier and I would like to place on record my appreciation of the valuable contribution made by the Guild in the development of this new pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In addition, my Department and the Guild will continue to monitor the impact of the new scheme upon the community to maximise its effectiveness and ensure that there are no abuses of the new arrangements.

Clearly, the Government had to rein in costs during a time of economic restraint, but in doing so we have been able to increase protection for high volume users of pharmaceutical benefits scheme drugs. I believe this is a long overdue reform and one which should have the support of both sides of the House. I also remind honourable members that, as part of the Government's changes to assist those with chronic illnesses, arrangements have been made to pay an annual grant to the Australian Diabetes Foundation to provide diabetics with essential supplies, including insulin syringes and needles. This is an important element of our chronic protection plan and one which has been welcomed by the diabetes organisations.

Part IV of the Bill contains amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act 1966. That Act was amended in 1981 to introduce a batch release system for biological therapeutic goods, such as vaccines, so as to enable the quality of products to be assessed before release to the public. Clauses 41 and 42 of the Bill insert new sections 23da and 23ea into the Therapeutic Goods Act. These are machinery amendments intended to correct legal inadequacies in the earlier provisions. Under the new provisions the Secretary to my Department will be empowered to obtain specific information from a manufacturer and to have official tests performed on samples before a specific batch can be released for use. The amendments will ensure that the batch release system provides an effective mechanism for preventing the marketing of unsafe or ineffective biological products.

Clause 44 of the Bill inserts into the Therapeutic Goods Act a new regulation-making power to provide, amongst other things, for the inspection of manufacturing companies operations and procedures which will ensure the Australian public is supplied with therapeutic goods that meet quality, safety and efficacy requirements. The Bill also contains a number of minor drafting amendments.
Financial Impact Statement

The increase in maximum patient contribution payable for Medicare services from $10 to $20 will result in savings of $18m in 1986-87-with introduction from 1 November 1986-and $29m in a full year. The increase in patient contributions for pharmaceutical benefits, together with the introduction of the safety net measures, is expected to reduce government pharmaceutical benefits scheme expenditure by approximately $56.6m in 1986-87 and approximately $67m in 1987-88.

The abolition of the isolated patients travel and accommodation assistance scheme and the provision of alternative funding to the States and Territories will result in a total Commonwealth expenditure of $24.2m for patient transport assistance in 1986-87. The sum of $13.3m will be provided for the remaining life of IPTAAS and takes into account the backlog of claims and the lag in submitting claims after the abolition. The sum of $10.9m will be provided to the States and Territories for the first six months of 1987. The full-year equivalent of $21.8m will be indexed in future years.

No expenditure arises under this Bill from the change to allow regulations under section 9B of the National Health Act. However, the cost of providing for a new program of hepatitis B immunisation for at-risk babies is estimated at $2.8m in a full year. The deregulation of private hospitals is expected to result in savings of $0.25m in 1986-87 and $0.5m in a full year. These savings should be considered in association with the abolition of the private hospital subsidy which will save $90m in 1986-87 and $143m in a full year.
Business Impact Statement

The repeal of legislative controls over private hospitals is a substantial deregulation initiative and is in keeping with the Government's resolve to reduce regulatory controls over private industry. Care has been taken in the development of the new pharmaceutical benefits scheme to minimise the administrative input by pharmacists and to adequately compensate them where additional work is unavoidable. Pharmacists will be required to enter prescription details on the prescription record form, issue pharmaceutical benefits entitlement cards and to satisfy themselves that individuals have an entitlement to the benefits being claimed.

The new arrangements will also provide the opportunity for pharmacists to develop a closer and more professional relationship with individual patients with the obvious potential for increased business activity. They will also be relieved of the administrative work load associated with making claims on the Commonwealth for the 40 million prescriptions which will no longer attract a government subsidy. Their cash flow will improve significantly as they will receive immediate payment for these prescriptions rather than waiting for reimbursement from the Commonwealth. The amendments to the Thera- peutic Goods Act will not affect the normal manufacture of satisfactory batches of biological products. Every effort will be made to avoid any delays by performing the necessary tests at the same time as they are being performed by the manufacturer. I commend the Bill to the House. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Porter) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill proposes a number of amendments to the Customs and Excise Acts. The principal amendment is at clause 9 of the Bill and proposes to give effect to the Government's decision to introduce revised excise duty rebate arrangements on exports and domestic free market sales of Bass Strait crude oil. These new procedures, which I will detail shortly, are being introduced to allow more timely settlement of rebate claims and thus increase the attractiveness of free market sales to the Bass Strait producers. The Bill contains a number of other amendments of a technical or administrative nature and I will provide brief details of the more important of these in a few moments.

The new mechanism for the payment of rebates of excise duty on exports and free market sales of Bass Strait crude oil is part of the Government's initiatives announced in July this year to stimulate domestic production and encourage exports of crude oil produced from Bass Strait.
