Since the beginning of 1986 the unsettled international oil market has had a significant and adverse impact on the Australian oil and energy industries. With the downward trend in world oil prices, Bass Strait crude oil production and Australian crude oil exports sourced from these production areas have dropped dramatically. The Government, concerned with the revenue and balance of payments effects of reduced oil production reflected in low domestic free market sales and the gradual cessation of export shipments, announced in July a package of measures to stimulate domestic production and encourage crude oil exports.

One of the measures introduced on 1 July 1986 was to reduce the effective top rate of crude oil excise on free market sales of old oil by a sliding scale ranging from 65 per cent at $12.50 or less per barrel to 87 per cent at $35.00 or more per barrel. By the end of July however, Australian crude oil prices had fallen to their lowest level since 1979 and this naturally had serious ramifications for the cash flow and financial viability of the Australian oil industry. In order to further encourage the resumption of free market sales, the Government also decided that from 1 August 1986 the top marginal excise duty rate for old oil would be reduced from 87 per cent to 80 per cent subject to certain review provisions. I should mention that excise duty rebates have been paid on exports of crude oil since 1984. These rebates have been implemented by excise regulations made approximately every six months.

To provide the necessary market stimulus it is now necessary to introduce a mechanism for the payment of the export rebates and rebates on domestic free market sales on a monthly basis. The Government believes that the most suitable and expedient method to achieve this is to have the Minister for Resources and Energy determine by notification in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette the rebates of excise duty payable on exports and domestic free market sales of Bass Strait crude oil. This should ensure that a monthly settlement of excise duty rebates can be accommodated, thereby increasing the attractiveness of these sales and exports to the Bass Strait producers.

The provisions of clause 9 of the Bill provide that similar to regulations the proposed Gazette notices are to be subject to tabling and disallowance by the Parliament in the usual way. This mechanism is proposed in order to preserve the Parliament's important scrutiny over this administrative tool. As evidence of the timeliness and efficacy of the Government's policy initiatives aimed at increasing production and crude oil exports, there were only 10 export shipments in the first half of 1986 and Bass Strait productions averaged only 320,000 barrels a day in the second quarter of 1986. By contrast, since 1 August 1986 nine export sales have been completed, valued at about $106m. More significant, however, is that Bass Strait production levels are currently running at 480,000 barrels per day and the Bass Strait producers are confident of achieving export sales averaging 70,000 barrels per day in the current financial year.

I turn now to the important amendments of a technical or administrative nature contained in the Bill. Clauses 4 and 12 effect minor amendments to the provisions in the Customs and Excise Acts respectively, relating to the obligations on ship and aircraft owners to provide information relating to ship's or aircraft's stores, including drugs, which are on board on arrival in Australia, or are taken on board while in Australia. The proposed amendments update the administrative requirements for the provision of this type of information, to facilitate and accommodate the use of modern media to transmit this data.

Clause 5 effects a technical amendment to section 151 of the Customs Act, to transfer from the Minister to the Comptroller-General of customs the power to treat goods as the manufacture of a forum island country, for the purposes of determining duty under the Customs Tariff Act. This transfer of power is consistent with the general transfer of administrative functions from the Minister to the Comptroller-General in customs legislation, as implemented by the two Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Acts of 1985 and 1986. The transfer of powers vested the day to day administration of the customs in the Comptroller-General, and the proposed amendment in clause 5 continues that theme.
The other technical and drafting amendments are explained in the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Financial Impact Statement
The provisions of this Bill have no direct financial implications. I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SCIENCE AND INDUSTRY RESEARCH LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill concerns the future directions of one of Australia's most important resources-and I am not now talking of iron ore, coal, bauxite or uranium, but of the intellectual resources within the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Just how much depends on CSIRO's performance over the next few years is, I believe, not widely enough understood in the community, because Australians still tend to define resources in purely material terms, and rarely relate it to intellect and human capacity. This attitude contrasts markedly with attitudes in countries such as Switzerland, Holland, Belgium, Sweden and Israel, to mention countries with populations smaller than our own, where human skills are invariably recognised as being of paramount importance.

Australia has no option but to develop similar attitudes if it is to survive economically for the remainder of this century. Australian business management, in particular, will have to change direction radically, and devote a far greater degree of attention to human skills than it has in the past. This will inevitably mean making use of CSIRO, because CSIRO is the single greatest reservoir of the technological skills and knowledge this nation possesses. In most other Western nations, government-funded research and development is paralleled by a strong private research and development capacity, but the Australian private sector, outside agriculture and mining, has for decades all but ignored the need for research and development, with the result that government has been left to shoulder the task of fostering scientific talent and expertise.

In examining the future of CSIRO, the Government was conscious that it would be setting the directions and structure for the Organisation for some years to come. Furthermore, CSIRO's role in performing longer-term, strategic research means that it is necessary to consider Australia's future, to ask where we as a nation are headed, when setting the context for decisions on CSIRO's future. There has been a profound change in perception over the last year or so of Australia's place in the world. In 1984-85 there was a prevailing euphoria about the state of Australia's economy. After all, it was reasoned, if we had the world's strongest economy and the world's highest growth rate, then structural improvements in the economy hardly seemed necessary. I was deeply conscious that my concern about the inadequacy of Australia's scientific and technological base was not popular in 1983 and 1984.

Underlying the Government's decision on future directions for CSIRO was a belief that Australia must develop as a nation that makes much greater use of its intellectual resources. If we are to arrest the relative decline in Australia's standard of living, Australia must become a more intellectually active scientific and technological culture. However, simple adoption of technology from overseas at a greater rate, or more effectively, will not create the required environment in Australia for acceptance and development of new technologies. A strong local capability in research and development, directed to the opportunities of the future, not the past, is essential. This will be the fundamental role of the restructured CSIRO resulting from the Amendment Bill before the House today.

To provide context for the future directions which the Government has identified for CSIRO, I would like to look briefly at our past. By 1900 Australia was a world leader in technology and its per capita income was the highest in the world, followed by Argentina. Our prosperity was based on our agricultural output and our natural resource endowment. Technological developments, spurred by the need to be competitive, were responsible for our pre-eminence in the world economy of the time. However, we have not used our initial success as a springboard to industrial growth. Instead, we have relied on our efficient agricultural and mining industries while our manufacturing and other industries remained poorly developed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Menzies, McEwen and Anthony.

—Exactly. Agriculture and mining, employing just 7 per cent of our labour force, account for more than 80 per cent of our export earnings, if we include the value of secondary processing. This is not a sign of strength, as the fastest-growing sector in world trade has been in high value-added, brain based goods for about 15 years. Theoretically, that 80 per cent plus figure could increase to 100 per cent as some farming and mining groups have urged. If it did, this would be a catastrophe, putting us at the mercy of declining world commodity prices, providing a disincentive to restructuring and updating our economic and technological base. Our urban society would be a mere appendage to the rural and mining base. Australia produces large volumes of raw materials, high bulk, low-added-value goods, at a time when alternative suppliers are coming on stream, and where traditional markets are either becoming self-sufficient or are adopting trade policies which are adverse to us.

SPEECH.PARA: In the fastest growing areas of world trade-low bulk, high-value-added, brain based or brand-name goods-we are very small producers, having left our run extremely late. In technology-based goods, of the 24 Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development nations, Australia ranked twenty third in 1984 in the imbalance between the value of imports and exports. Only Iceland had worse figures. There are serious, long term and-in my view-irreversible problems in agriculture, complicated locally by drought, but also by our national preoccupation with the short term, and failure to grasp long term trends.

The most productive year in the history of world agriculture was 1985, with outputs 12 per cent higher than ever before. A green revolution has swept Asia in the past 15 years. China is now largely self-sufficient in grain. India now has a grain surplus of 35 million tonnes, locked away in silos. Indonesia, for the first time in many years, is now a grain exporter. Britain, still a major farming nation, has had unusually good harvests.

The minerals situation is similar. The overheated minerals boom that began in the 1960s and continued through the early 1980s was based on heroic assumptions of a continuing world-wide growth in demand for base metals we could produce in large volume and with steadily rising prices. These assumptions have not been fulfilled. Other sources of supply-notably Brazil-are now selling at a lower cost, while the technological revolution has brought an era of parsimony in the use of natural resources.

The latest preoccupation of Australian politics and the media-the emergence of the so-called New Right-is a relatively insignificant part of a much greater problem. In passing, I must comment that a leading member of the New Right, as late as 1979, was positively advocating a reduction in Australia's manufacturing capability and exports in order that our dollar would not be upvalued too much by the large forecast increase in mineral exports and capital inflow to the minerals industry. The strategies of most other western nations during the 1950s and 1960s were quite different from our own. The companies of Japan, Europe and the United States of America, attracted by the economic growth prospects of most economies, spread out across the world, opening up new markets with new products and processes. This competition spurred heavy research and development investment, innovation, product and overseas market development, yielding handsome returns and an economic resilience which allowed them to survive the economic recession of the 1980s better than most.

The major factor in the rise of resource-poor nations has been the proportion of export earnings directly attributable to intellectual input: Invention, research and development, product innovation, design, patents, royalties and copyright. More than 60 per cent of the annual export earnings of Japan, France, Sweden, the Netherlands and Italy depend on brain based industries, while Australia's figure is probably less than 5 per cent. The skill based earnings of our industrial contemporaries will grow. Ours will contract unless we make a fundamental change in direction.

The most important political issue we face is how to bring Australia up to date, how to come to grips with the social and political significance of the technological revolution that has swept the Western world in the past 25 years. Australia missed the bus on being an active participant in that revolution, and is now paying the price for its low level of intellectual vitality and for remaining in the mental world of the 1960s. We still have to learn the lesson that the world does not owe us a living. It is dangerous for us to conclude that all other nations are out of step and they must learn to march with us.

What Australia must do is also what CSIRO must do. CSIRO has made enormous contributions towards the success of our agriculture and minerals industries. I believe CSIRO's most important role over the coming years will be to work with those industries in which research and development plays a central role. In particular, CSIRO will play a major role in contributing to the Government's program of restructuring and revitalising high-technology manufacturing, and in supporting the emerging information and space technology industries.

The scientific work of CSIRO will, of course, continue to benefit the resource based primary industries, particularly by adding value to products before they leave our shores, and by tailoring them to meet specific overseas market needs. The present level of private sector industrial research and development in Australia must be increased. This is the most critical factor in achieving a more internationally competitive and skill-based industrial capability in Australia. CSIRO will have an important supportive role in achieving this goal.

Over the past few years, CSIRO has substantially improved its interactions with manufacturing industry. The trend started in 1980, with the establishment of the new Division of Manufacturing Technology. The number of professional staff engaged in manufacturing-oriented research has grown by nearly 100 since 1981, an increase of some 15 per cent. Research in manufacturing new accounts for 27 per cent of professional staff. Growth in the manufacturing effort is a trend I expect to continue, and work for the information industries is also growing rapidly. CSIRO's international standing as a research establishment is beyond dispute. It is certainly higher than its national standing, at least in some sectors. Ironically, the Bell Laboratories, world leaders in communications technology, have a higher opinion of CSIRO's research capacity than the local competitor, AWA, has.

CSIRO has collaborated with industry in the development of many products which are being exported, or are about to be. These range from the high-speed vision processor, a major advance in the field of robotic vision, to the extremely strong ceramic called `partially stabilised zirconia', which has a wide range of potential applications. The Government is looking to CSIRO to play a role in assisting industry to a much greater export orientation, as well as to continue support for our more traditional industries. This is vital to Australia's future prosperity. It is precisely because the Government places great store by CSIRO and has great expectations of it that we are introducing this new legislation aimed at carrying the Organisation into the next decade in the best possible shape.

In May 1985 the Government requested the Australian Science and Technology Council to conduct a total review of public investment in research and development. ASTEC published its report `Future Directions for CSIRO' in November, and the Minister for Science announced in June that the Government had accepted the broad thrust of the ASTEC recommendations. This legislation is based in part on those recommendations, and provides for CSIRO to be maintained as a single entity, in order to achieve maximum efficiency and flexibility in responding to changing national research priorities. The Government considers that CSIRO's primary role should continue to be applications-oriented research in support of major industry sectors and selected areas of community interest, with a commitment to the effective transfer of its results to users.

To help CSIRO place more emphasis on the application of its research, the organisation is being encouraged to take on more short term problem solving projects, to be paid for largely by the individual companies concerned. An important objective of this is to gain a better knowledge of industries' needs, and to foster mutual respect and confidence. It is not intended that CSIRO substitute for industry performing its own research and development, but rather that it back up and stimulate industry to do more for itself. The major emphasis for CSIRO with its own funds will remain, where it should, on contributing to future industrial development by longer term `strategic' research.

The Government will give clear guidance to CSIRO about Government policies and priorities. As Minister, I will issue guidelines to CSIRO from time to time setting out policies and priorities which the Government wishes CSIRO to follow. In addition, CSIRO will continue to prepare three-to-five-year strategic plans, which will be submitted to me, and annual operating plans. I will retain a statutory power of direction.

Changing the top structure will be an important element in building closer links between CSIRO and industry and the community. The legislation clearly separates the top-level policy body-the Board-from management functions. The former Executive will be replaced by a board having a part time non-executive chairman and six to eight part time members appointed for their personal abilities, not as representatives of sectional interests. The Chief Executive will be the only full time member of the Board. The Board will be responsible for setting the broad policy directions within the general policy context established by the Government. The Board members, including the Chief Executive, will be appointed by the Governor-General in Council for a maximum period of five years, but will be eligible for reappointment. The Chief Executive, who will be the most senior member of the organisation, will have responsibility for the management of the activities of CSIRO within the directions established by the Board.

The Government has decided that CSIRO should be able to retain its earnings from outside sources without this leading to a decrease in appropriation. Although future levels of funding will continue to be determined in the annual Budget context, this decision should provide a major incentive to CSIRO to strengthen its links with industry, and the application orientation of its research.

Although the Advisory Council and State and Territory committees have provided valuable advice and direction to the Executive, it is clear that the structure has not been ideal. The Government has therefore decided to repeal that section of the Science and Industry Research Act which establishes these bodies, and to empower the incoming Board to set up non-statutory channels of advice from industry and the community. Representations from the outlying States of Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania have all expressed concern at this provision, but the special needs of these areas outside the Sydney-Melbourne axis are recognised and I am confident that the proposed non-statutory channels of advice will give appropriate and effective State representation.

The Government is also proposing to establish a House of Representatives standing committee on science and technology, which I believe will be a major step in improving CSIRO's interaction with and responsiveness to Parliament. The present CSIRO Consultative Council, which comprises staff and management representatives, will be retained to provide an effective forum for the representation of staff views within the management structure. The ASTEC report on CSIRO raised a number of other important issues concerning use of resources, conditions of service for research staff, funding and financial arrangements. ASTEC's recommendations on these matters will be subject to consideration, in the first instance, by the incoming Board, and subsequently by me in consultation with other Ministers as appropriate. The Bill also provides that the Chief Executive should administer the Science and Industry Endowment Fund, a fund used to support scientific endeavours which do not have access to mainstream funding.

The changes to CSIRO embodied in the new legislation are complementary to other initiatives introduced by the Government aimed at transforming the research and development climate in Australia. These initiatives include the grants for industry research and development scheme, the 150 per cent taxation concession, the National Industry Extension Service and revised offsets arrangements. The legislation also incorporates and formalises a number of changes that were under way within CSIRO at the time of the ASTEC review, particularly the five-year strategy for development aimed at improving the focus, management and use of the Organisation's research.

I am very optimistic about CSIRO's future. This legislation will give impetus to the positive changes that have already taken place within the organisation, and will also reflect the Government's desire to enhance CSIRO's responsiveness to community needs. I commend the Bill to the House and I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lloyd) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87. In many ways it gives me pleasure to speak after the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones) who has just made a second reading speech on the Science and Industry Research Legislation Amendment Bill. The Minister identified in his speech a number of the problems that I intend to address. However, I must admit that I am a little disappointed that the Minister is a member of a government which, in my opinion, has not addressed these issues significantly enough and has missed an opportunity for which Australians will pay for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been said by a number of Ministers that the Budget is a tough one and that it was brought down at a critical time in our economic life. We heard that even today from the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). First, I want to address the current issues facing the Government, which seem to be the major items that it addressed in its Budget. Secondly, I wish, like the Minister for Science did a moment ago, to address some of the historical problems that Australia has faced and is continuing to face. Thirdly, I would like to address a couple of the key issues which I believe should have been addressed more fully in the Budget. Finally, I would like to consider exactly how the Budget responded to the historical problems and the key issues which had been missed.

The current issues facing the Government have probably been illustrated by a number of the headlines that have appeared in newspapers over the past six to eight months. One of the issues was undoubtedly the fluctuation in our exchange rate. In many ways it is ironic that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has been hoisted with his own petard. Following the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System and the movement already set out by the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), it was the Treasurer who took Australia to a deregulated financial market and a deregulated exchange rate.

When the Government assumed office in March 1983, Australia had a trade weighted index of 81.7. On the Monday immediately after the 1984 election the exchange rate was still, on a trade weighted index basis, in the 80s. In fact, it had increased slightly to 83.1 Yet by the end of 1985 we had recorded an historical low, when the index was down to 59.2. By the end of the year it was still hovering around the 60 mark and the Australian dollar in terms of the United States dollar was trading at 68c. In 1986 we saw quite wild fluctuations and a continued fall of the Australian dollar. By the end of July 1986-certainly just before the finishing touches to the Budget were being made by the Government-we had a new trade weighted index low and a new historical relationship between the Australian and United States dollars.

It is undoubtedly true that the Government was concerned, as the Treasurer has admitted on a number of occasions, about the current account balances. We are one of the few major Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries with a deficit. Australia has the highest deficit, as a percentage of our gross domestic product, of any of the OECD countries. In fact, we have a current account deficit which is nearly twice that of the United States of America on a percentage basis. In absolute terms, I believe that it is the second highest deficit of any OECD country.

The third problem facing the Government and the Australian community is the increase in Australia's gross foreign debt. It is true that at some time in August it was about $86 billion, which represents a little over $5,000 per head, or something like $22,000 per family in Australia. This must be paid for by Australians. Not all of this is government debt-some is private debt. But whether it be government or private debt the only way to repay it is through overseas export earnings. In essence, it can be repaid only in that way. This repayment involves a high percentage of our export earnings. In fact, an amount equal to about 34 per cent or 35 per cent of our exports every year is needed to pay the interest and capital on our debt. About 15 per cent of our export earnings is required to pay the interest alone on our foreign debt. The Government is faced undoubtedly with an increasing overseas debt commitment and the Budget was meant to address that issue.

The fourth issue facing the Australian community-it is one of particular concern to consumers and businessmen alike-is the current inflation rate in Australia compared with the inflation rates of our overseas competitors. The latest edition of the Economist in the Parliamentary Library dated 6 September 1986 demonstrates that Australia has a major problem with its inflation rate. For example, wholesale prices are a precursor to future changes in retail or consumer prices. In the past three months Australia's wholesale prices have increased by an average of 6.6 per cent. Virtually every other country with which the Economist compares Australia has had negative wholesale price rises. In other words, wholesale prices in other countries have been falling.

Consumer prices were still falling in Japan and West Germany in July. Japan's consumer prices have fallen by about 0.3 per cent in the past three months and there has been a minor rise of only 0.1 per cent over the past 12 months. West Germany had a fall of 0.2 per cent. Belgium wholesalers have cut their prices in the year to the end of July by 7.2 per cent. In the last three months the Belgans have cut their prices by 5.7 per cent. There are similar movements in Canada, France, West Germany, Holland, Italy and Japan. Indeed, Japan saw a massive fall of 13 per cent in wholesale prices in the past three months. There was a slight increase in Sweden. Wholesale prices showed a negative movement in Spain, Switzerland and the United States. Only the United Kingdom has experienced a significant increase such as our own. Inflation is a problem; it is one that is increasing for Australia. That was the position facing the Government.

The Treasurer has argued that Australia has had an historical problem. A moment ago the Minister for Science indicated the extent of the problem in terms of our relative export position in the world, which has fallen from a fairly high ranking 30 years ago to a relatively low one in terms of OECD countries. We rank about twenty-second or twenty-third in the list of major exporters. It is undoubtedly true that one of Australia's problems over the last 30 years has been that we have tended to concentrate on agriculture and minerals to the exclusion of manufacturing. When we compare Australia with the rest of the world we see that in 1953-54 something like 87 per cent of our exports were in minerals, fuels and agricultural products. Even in 1983-84 that figure was somewhere around 74 or 75 per cent. Whereas in 1953-54 the rest of the world had something like 70 per cent of exports in agriculture and minerals, currently it has less than 40 per cent. Nearly 60 per cent of the world's exports are in the manufacturing area. Whereas only some 20 per cent of Australia's exports are in that area, the Minister for Science was right in identifying it as a major problem.

The Treasurer, of course, has tried to indicate that the major issue facing Australia recently, because of our concentration on agriculture and minerals, has been the terms of trade. The Treasurer in his Budget Speech said:

Many Australians have wondered why the economy was doing so well in 1985 and yet, apparently, doing so poorly in 1986. The answer lies in the dramatic collapse of world commodity prices since late last year.

The Treasurer ought to read some of the things put out by the Economic Planning Advisory Council, of which he is a member. In EPAC's statement No. 8, made earlier this year, on page 3 he will see a chart which sets out our terms of trade index, not just over the last year but since 1950. The terms of trade have been going against Australia since 1951. Our terms of trade fell more dramatically in the early 1950s and throughout the 1960s and 1970s than has been the case over the past year. Except for the mineral boom in the mid-1960s and the energy boom in the 1970s, during the last Whitlam Government, the terms of trade have gone consistently and dramatically against Australia for a long period. Yet under the Menzies Liberal Government we had continued expansion in our trade and a continued increase in our standard of living. If Australia's terms of trade had gone against the Whitlam Government in the way they did against the last coalition government, Australia would have been in a far worse position at the end of the Whitlam Government than it was. Most Australians look back on that period and think that Australia was in pretty bad shape. We were lucky because Australia was a net beneficiary of the high oil prices during that period.

The terms of trade going against Australia is nothing new. Australia has had to face this for some time. It was no good for the Treasurer to wake up one morning and say: `Heck, we have a banana republic. The terms of trade have gone against us'. They were going that way before he became Treasurer and before the last Whitlam Government; they have been going that way since 1951, when we had a wool boom during the Korean war.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was an election that year.

—We had an election year and we beat them. The critical issues facing Australia have also been identified in some of the Government's own publications. I can refer to no better source than EPAC's statement No. 10 on page 5, where we see details of business investment in Australia. Business investment in Australia peaked in 1971, just before the last Labor Government. It fell dramatically during the Whitlam Government, and for good reason. Australian business did not trust a Labor government. Investment did not start to rise again until the end of the last Liberal Government, and it fell dramatically again once the Labor Government took over in early 1983. The Budget forecast a further fall of one per cent in business investment in Australia in 1986-87, and we have seen business investment falling on a quarterly basis since June 1985.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government knows the major problem. We cannot have a continual increase in the standard of living, we cannot have an increasing rate of employment over a long time, unless we re-invest in ourselves. The Minister for Science recognises that. He recognises that it is important to reinvest not only in plant and equipment but also in ourselves as individuals. I will address that issue briefly. One of the problems facing Australia is that after-tax returns have fallen dramatically. One would have hoped to find in this Budget some stimulus for investment in plant and equipment and for investment in ourselves. One would have hoped that this Government would have addressed the issue of how to get Australians to re-invest in our country. We did not find that. We saw in this Budget exactly the opposite. We saw an increase in government charges through excise duties which will reduce after-tax returns for businesses. We saw increases in personal and company taxes. We saw a reduction in subsidies to business, which will increase their cost of production. We saw increases in outlays of a substantial nature in virtually every area except the subsidy area, which will increase the cost to business. This Government had the opportunity to bring down a Budget which would set the picture for Australia for the next decade but it blew it. The Government did exactly the opposite to what it should have done, and it will pay for that at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown Mr R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—A good member, and a good name.

—That is a very perceptive interjection. The Budget the Parliament is in the process of considering now represents unquestionably the most important legislation that comes before the Parliament at any time. It probably represents the most important document which would come before any authority or institution in Australia at any time. I was interested to hear Mr Deputy Speaker confirm that apparently an amendment has been moved to the Budget by the Opposition. That is particularly interesting because presumably it indicates some desire by the Opposition to put into place one of its alternative budgets. Perhaps it will be one of those Budgets for which the Opposition was responsible during those seven disastrous years between 1976 and March 1983, when they were finally thrown from office.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I deal with particular aspects of the Budget, and incidentally do one of those things that I rejoice in having the opportunity to do, that is to refer to the record of the coalition when it was in government, I will try to put to rest one of the claims made by members of the Opposition and by their conservative henchmen around Australia about the national debt. It is true that in June this year Australia's net foreign debt stood at $65 billion. It is true that that foreign debt had increased from something in excess of a relatively low amount of $9 billion at the end of June 1981. But one of the things that is never referred to by the Opposition is the fact that of that foreign debt only 35 per cent is public debt. Of the total debt of $65 billion, less than $14 billion represents Commonwealth debt. What we need to keep in mind is that one of the fundamental reasons for the increase in the aggregate value of that foreign debt is the very significant borrowings from overseas by the private sector in Australia-not by the public sector at all.

One of the greatest things that has happened in the Australian economy in recent years is the very significant devaluation of the Australian dollar, which has restored the competitive edge to Australian manufacturing and made it possible for Australia to stand erect as a commercial participant in a commercial world. Yet that devaluation itself has been responsible for about 20 per cent of the total component of that aggregate foreign debt. Let us hear no more nonsense about it from Opposition spokesmen and their conservative henchmen.

Let me say one thing before I leave that matter. The alternatives are simple. Either we allow the inflow of capital or funds from overseas in the form of debt capital, which we will have the opportunity to repay in the future, or it will come in as equity capital, which means that foreign interests will progressively buy up more and more of the Australian economy, as they did when the coalition was in government. The prospect then is that, in the disposal of all those assets of the Australian people, there will be few opportunities in the future for them to be brought back into the ownership and control of the Australian people. They are the sorts of choices that we can make. Whenever those circumstances are misrepresented, quite deliberately, by members of the Opposition, we will need to continue to refute them and to continue to clarify them, and we will do precisely that.

We should not lose sight of the fact that this Government has been in office for only 3 1/2 years. Nor should we lose sight of the economic circumstances that the Hawke Government inherited. One of the fundamental reasons why, in March 1983, hundreds of thousands of people turned their loyalty, support and allegiance to the Australian Labor Party was the devastation of the Australian economy which had been wrought by those who purport to be economic managers. They tore the economy apart, and their insane policy of maintaining an overvalued Australian dollar as their sole anti-inflationary weapon was responsible for devastating Australian manufacturing. That was one of the fundamental reasons why, when the Australian dollar was devalued with the floating of the dollar, Australian exporters were unable to respond. Australian import competitors were unable to respond or to take advantage of it because they had been devastated by the previous Government. Industry after industry and firm after firm were smashed against the wall as a result of that Government's economic policies--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is happening in Queensland now.

—Exactly, because the Hon. Sir Johannes Bjelke-Petersen is still applying on a State level what those economic vandals put into place on a national level. All those people who talk about the great achievements that have been made in the Queensland economy under the National Party Government should examine the facts. The performance of the Queensland economy is one of the worst, if not the worst, performances of the Australian States. People say: `The Premier might be a bit senile and he might be losing his marbles, but has he not been able to bring about development?'. He did nothing of the kind. He came in the wake of private development because of the resource-rich nature of that State. Whenever the Queensland Government has deliberately intervened, it has brought about the same type of economic vandalism that was brought about by those people opposite. (Quorum formed)

—Order! Before the honourable member resumes his speech, I draw attention to the fact that the honourable member for Hindmarsh left the chamber during the ringing of the bells. It is inappropriate for honourable members to do that.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I made it quite clear when I came in that I had gone to pick up a copy of Hansard. I had not left the chamber.
—For the information of honourable members, the alcove is not regarded as part of the chamber.

—I appreciate immensely the fact that a quorum was called by the Opposition Deputy Whip because it has provided me with a very intelligent-looking audience. Previously, intelligent people were listening in the gallery and I had those who were present on the Opposition side, and now I have an intelligent audience on this side. I thank the honourable member for calling that quorum.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying that we should not lose sight of the fact that it was only three and a half years ago that we inherited a devastated national economy which we were responsible for pulling back together. I said, too, that the Opposition had deliberately maintained an overvalued Australian dollar as its chief anti-inflationary weapon, which had the effect of devastating Australian secondary industry.

The members of the Government certainly have not forgotten those circumstances, and the memory of the Australian people is much longer than members of the Opposition give them credit for. The Australian people remember absolutely that during the previous Government's last 12 months unemployment in Australia increased by a quarter of a million, or by 750 people every day for 12 months. Not only that, but for the first time in 30 years honourable members opposite had brought about a situation in which economic growth was actually negative. There are a number of extremely important aspects of this Budget, many of which will be resolved only with the passing of time. I make very brief reference to them. The first is the growth forecast. It is important that we achieve the growth that has been forecast, otherwise there could be a detrimental effect on the comparatively high level of employment which this Government has been able to bring about. We indicated before the March 1983 election that we would be attempting, within our first three years, to create 500,000 new jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many did we get?

—We created 630,000 new jobs in three years. We achieved that 500,000 target with five months to go. Honourable members will remember the way in which the Opposition responded when we gave that undertaking, that firm commitment, that promise to the Australian people. Opposition members laughed at us because their experience in their last year in government was to create additional unemployment of 250,000-a quarter of a million-people. Not only that; we know that during the Opposition's seven years in government the number of people living in comparative poverty in Australia increased to 3 million-one person in every five-including 800,000 children. What a record.
—Shameful.

—What a shameful record. I thank the honourable member for Grey for that perceptive interjection. These are the people who, presumably, will shortly be going around the Australian traps appealing to the Australian people once again to show them some loyalty, some support, some allegiance, and they will be rejected again, as they were before. The Australian people know that as a result of the very sound, constructive, coherent and effective economic policies that this Government put into place, we reversed that state of free-fall that the Australian economy was in prior to March 1983. In our first three years we achieved an increase in the level of growth, from negative growth to a 5 per cent real growth level. Everyone has been complaining about the deficit on the current account. One of the fundamental reasons for that is because of buoyancy-this tremendous surge in growth-in the Australian economy, domestic demand increased to such an extent that we were dragging in imports. Our trading partners-Japan, the United States of America, countries around the Pacific rim and countries in the EEC-did not achieve a rate of economic growth equal to ours, with the result that they were not buying our exports. But this dramatic growth that took place within Australia meant that we were buying goods from them. That is one of the fundamental reasons for the deficit on the current account. That is one of the fundamental reasons why, in this Budget and in the Government's general economic strategy, we have to gear back on the rate of economic growth in Australia. The Opposition, when in government, was flat out trying to lift it and we are trying to gear it back. I have reservations and concerns about that, but that is the interpretation which the Government has placed on our domestic economic circumstances, and that is the approach which the Government is making.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to make a comment, too, about the references that have been made to the necessity for the burden of this hardship to be spread equitably over the Australian community. There are two particular things which indicate that, in fact, whether we like it or not, there has been a reduction in the real standard of living of the Australian people. This is not as a result of anything which this Government has done, and this point has been made before. If we were able to secure today the same prices for our exports as we were achieving at the end of 1984, our exports would be earning, on an annual basis, $6 billion more-$6,000m more. If, as a result of that, we had been able to reduce the current account deficit from $14 billion to $8 billion, that would still have left a deficit of some concern but it would have been of almost minimal concern compared with the deficit we have at the present time. That means that the products that Australian workers, Australian factories, Australian farms and Australian mines have been selling overseas have had ripped off them, by that collapse of world prices, $6,000m on an annual basis. So the capacity of Australia as a nation to earn has been reduced by $6,000m.

Let us see what this means in terms of each Australian household. There are about five million households in Australia. If we divide that five million into $6 billion the answer comes out something in excess of $1,000. That means that, on average, every household in Australia has had a reduction in its real income, as a result of that collapse of world prices, over which we have no control, of something in excess of $20 a week. But when the Government says, in all sincerity and honesty, that there is a burden which must be spread equitably, and it puts into place a Budget which is designed to do that, we hear the sort of nonsense we have been hearing from members of the Opposition. No wonder we become a little impatient with them. I do not mind people adopting a political position-of course, we are going to continue to do that-but I would prefer if it could be adopted with a marginal degree of honesty and integrity. Of course they are two things that are lost to members of the Opposition. Integrity and honesty have never been part of their political armoury. Misrepresentation and attempts to make people afraid, attempts to confuse people--

TALK.START.PARA: —Scaremongering.

—I thank the honourable member for Moore, who reminds me that another part of the Opposition's armoury is scaremongering. I could go on, but the amount of time available to me has been significantly affected. Let me say that one of the leading economic commentators, before the Budget, said this:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the market should be happy with a projected Budget deficit of around $4 billion.
It was $3.5 billion. That same person said:
The market . . . will want to see the lower deficit achieved by axing rather than taxing.
The axing provided $2.5 billion and the taxing provided $1.5 billion. He said:
From the market's point of view, the forecast for GDP will need to be below 3 per cent to be credible . . .
It was 2.5 per cent. He continued:
. . . the market will be looking for an average CPI inflation rate for the year of about 8 per cent.
It was 8 per cent. So, on all those measures, the Government has been remarkably successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Adermann The Hon A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is almost a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), because he is a pleasant, likeable fellow. He was vainly going along the path of trying to dig up ghosts from the past and valiantly, and very theatrically, trying to defend a Budget which is entirely indefensible. But if nothing else it was a very pleasant interlude in an otherwise dreary day.

SPEECH.PARA: On the admission of the Government and the Treasurer (Mr Keating), Australia is facing extremely acute economic difficulties, and one would have hoped that this Budget would have been directed to remedying many of those ills. That it has failed to do so, and the necessity for the presentation of a supplementary mini-Budget to implement cuts in expenditure which were not made in the Budget, is now patently obvious. It is perceived by even a cursory analysis that the Government has resiled from addressing expenditure cuts which are necessary and, in its coming up with the hypothetical figure of a deficit of $3.5 billion, we have been subjected to a gigantic subterfuge. This was, of course, comprehended, if not by the honourable member for Charlton by economic analysts, by overseas and Australian money markets and by such important and critical judges as Moody's Investor Services Inc. The whole thrust of the exercise was a succession of additional taxation imposts and a deferral of promised expenditures and expenditure foregone.

Let me deal with those two matters. The Government has complained that recovery is inhibited because business will not make the investment deemed desirable by the Government. Business cannot and will not make this investment until the prevailing mood of uncertainty, depression and lack of confidence can be dispelled. It cannot and will not increase investment unless it can see some prospect of stability and profitability. On top of disastrous and indefensible taxes, such as the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax, which are crippling small business, the increased load of indirect taxation-and the bureaucratic regulation which goes with it-imposed under this Budget will be a mammoth disincentive to already struggling business to adopt any investment decisions. Every new and increased cost, every new and increased taxation impost which is loaded on to the small business sector puts any hope of recovery further away and makes the degree of inevitable recession confronting us even more intense. I have never, in 14 years in this Parliament, detected throughout our nation such a feeling of despondency as I detect today. I have never heard so much talk of recession as is now abroad.

This Budget is certainly the catalyst in such a scenario. Was it a tough Budget? It was tough on pensioners, the unwilling beneficiaries of measures such as the assets test. It is a tragedy that their pension increase was substantially delayed. The deferral of their increase means that our most disadvantaged and needy group of Australians, faced with an intolerable and rising inflation rate and with no capacity to increase their meagre income, have been betrayed by a government which gave them assurances of sympathy. The Budget was tough on Australian business and taxpayers, who have been waiting since September last year for promised income tax cuts. They are now told that they will have to wait even longer for those cuts. The supposed tax cuts have been negated by major increases in virtually every other area of taxation.

The Budget was tough on war widows and repatriation beneficiaries who have already been persistently attacked by earlier government measures. It was tough on small business which, after all, must provide the employment and increased production which the Government professes to espouse. But it was not tough in the areas in which it should have been tough. The Australian Council of Trade Unions knows that the discounting of wage increases to encompass a depreciated dollar, increased excises and indirect taxes will not happen. It knows that it can press for productivity increases, shorter hours and over-award remuneration with impunity. It cares little that businesses will go into bankruptcy and unemployment will escalate.

The Budget was not tough on government expenditure and wastage. Without a mini-Budget to remedy this situation, we are up the creek without a paddle. Indeed, if the Government could find a way to plot a course which is directly opposite to what Australia needs to achieve recovery, it has done so in this Budget. It is no wonder that Moody's has downgraded our credit rating and the world's economists condemn our performance. Forecast expenditures in the Budget reveal that, after social welfare and payments to the States and local authorities, our next highest head of expenditure is interest on public debt-an unbelievable and unacceptable figure of over 10 per cent of our national expenditure. Worse still, I believe that this figure is understated. The projections on which this Budget are predicated are unattainable. The growth in gross domestic product is overstated. Inflation growth is understated. Projected interest rates are understated. So the deficit of $3.5 billion, even with all of the manipulations to which I have already adverted, will end up being considerably higher-just as last year's projected deficit blew out by a net figure of well over $800m. So our indebtedness will increase beyond the Budget projections.

However, it is not merely the absolute amount of our national debt which most concerns me. It is not just how much we are borrowing, but what we are borrowing for, that concerns me. If we are borrowing for capital investment so that industry can expand, and we can see that borrowing leading to increased production, income and wealth, that is possibly an investment which is not entirely to be condemned. It can provide profits, increase jobs and raise our standard of living. Of course, it still requires wise management and control. However, more and more, this Government is borrowing merely to pay the housekeeping bills-for consumption. We are borrowing to pay our pensioners and public servants, to prop up a standard of living which we cannot afford, and that is the road to disaster.

TALK.START.PARA: —A tragedy.

—It is a tragedy. That will not achieve one scintilla of production, one job, or one step along the road to recovery. Indeed, it will inhibit production, destroy jobs and produce recession. Simply and plainly, we cannot proceed along this path of folly. We cannot increase our borrowing to pour more and more into totally non-productive consumption areas, as we are now doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The world thinks we are mad. We are living beyond our means. We are paying Australians more not to work than to work. With holiday loadings, penalty rates, flexitime and reduced hours, a mass of paid holidays, and the consequent compounding costs of workers' compensation, fringe benefits and a host of other on-costs, we have departed from all reason and common sense. If one mentions to this Government measures such as the removal of the holiday loading, the peculiar penalty imposts on the tourist industry, a return to a 40-hour working week, the requirement of some community service in return for unemployment benefit, it goes into a frenzy of vitriolic abuse. It cheerfully supports the blackmail by unions of business after business, industry after industry, for so-called productivity-superannuation handouts. I thought that productivity increases were somehow linked to increased efficiency and productivity. But in Australia today, even when we have negative GDP growth, unions unashamedly call for increases due to productivity. No wonder the world thinks we are mad. No wonder our credit rating has gone down and the world's economists put us way down the list of responsible economic managers. No wonder we hear talk of recession. No wonder there is such despondency abroad in business and in the community.

Over 14 years I have discerned a trend in this country. A philosophy has developed which dismays me. Let me say at the outset that I love art and I value greatly our environment. I have actively participated in and encouraged sport. I have always encouraged groups who work to redress injustices and improve the lot of the disadvantaged and the handicapped.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be in the Labor Party.

—Wait for it. I love to see within the community endeavours to improve and beautify our surroundings. Therefore, what I now say is not aimed at any particular endeavour or sector. I refer to an attitude which pervades almost every section of our daily life. I have seen governments of all persuasions-this Budget reinforces what I say-pandering and bowing to vocal militant pressure groups. I have seen a departure from the healthy philosophy of people working in the community to raise funds and promote the sorts of things about which I have spoken. More and more, special interest groups demand that the Government-that is, the taxpayer-promotes and pays for their particular requests. Less and less do we go out and raise funds, sweat a little, sacrifice a little, to make our nation a better place. We look for grants. We look for increased funding and the like. We seek recognition and fame, not because of our hard work and endeavour, but as the leaders of groups who have coerced government into picking up the tab. As a result we have lost the compassion and concern that we should have. The old community spirit and involvement is gone. We cry `give me', rather than go out and spend ourselves in order to achieve and attain.

SPEECH.PARA: In this Budget, as in Budgets for many years, the taxpayers of Australia are increasingly being required to fund the desires of militant pressure groups. We are becoming lazier and lazier. There does not seem to be any sensible, rational priority about it. Those who shout loudest, parade most often and carry the most placards, seem to receive the largest handouts. This Budget and its predecessors fail miserably to deal with this matter, which should be of real concern. The Budget reinforces and accelerates a trend which must be regarded as undesirable. Many boards and bodies have sprung up, adept at asking for, receiving and spending increasing amounts of funds. How much money which is designed to achieve an aim is being dissipated and wasted? If citizens care, if they really believe in a cause, if they have a vision, let them put their hearts, minds and energy into that cause. If we care enough, we surely should not merely demand that governments do for us what we should be doing for ourselves. If I want to achieve a goal or acquire an asset, I work for it. If I want it greatly, I work harder for it. Governments have discouraged that community spirit. We get less for our money and, as a consequence, an inferior result.

This Budget ought to encourage community pride and call on us to do something for the nation because we are Australians and because we care. It fails. Our boards, bodies and handouts proliferate and appetites become more insatiable. This Budget should have given direction into the future; instead it produced palliatives and band-aids. It should have provided encouragement and incentives; instead it stifled enterprise. It should have given sure and certain evaluations and responsible accounting; instead its projections are suspect and its conclusions are unreliable. It should have rallied our national spirit; instead it has plunged us more deeply into despair and despondency. It should have encouraged us to work to make our nation a better, richer place; instead it rewarded the strident demands of those who cry `Give me', and it frustrated and disappointed those who would work and sacrifice to make their vision a reality. Therefore, this Budget fails miserably on every objective test we can apply to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Simmons Mr D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again this evening we have heard the usual National Party rhetoric that we have grown accustomed to over many years. It is a typical line where National Party members in particular urge us to cut government expenditure, with the exception of this, that and the other. Once more the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Adermann), in common with most of his colleagues, particularly those from the National Party, repeats this line. As I said, we have come to expect in this House the usual line of the National Party about socialising one's losses and capitalising one's profits.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Fairfax talked about the so-called impost of fringe benefit taxation, capital gains taxation and other taxation measures that were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on the night of 19 August. The total figure to be collected by those measures amounts to about $1.5 billion. However, what the honourable member for Fairfax did not care to state was that that $1.5 billion was revenue neutral. In other words, with the taxation reductions that will take place in two stages, commencing on 1 December 1986 and 1 July 1987, not $1.5 billion but three times that amount-$4.5 billion-will be returned to Australian taxpayers by way of taxation reductions. For every dollar collected by the Government in taxation at this time $3 will eventually be returned over this financial year. As the Treasurer has indicated on many occasions, this is the most significant taxation reform this country has seen in many years. We are scrubbing those lurks and perks. We should not be calling it a fringe benefit tax; we should be calling it the abolition of the lurks and perks, the sorts of measures that honourable members on the other side of the House have been protecting for years.

I find it absolutely incredible that once more we hear condemnation of the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax and other measures but we never hear about the positives. How many Opposition speakers have pointed to the imputation system that will commence from 1 July this year whereby we will end the process under which companies are taxed at the company tax rate and individuals who have received dividends are again taxed? Surely that reform is long overdue and it is part of the overall tax package, a package that was announced in legislation on the night of 19 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —You won't hear them complaining about that.

—As the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism said, it is interesting that we do not hear many comments about that from the Opposition. All we get is the incessant claim about the fringe benefits tax, the capital gains tax, this, that, and the other tax. What the Opposition is doing-it is a legitimate political tactic-is pointing out some of the negatives, and in any taxation system there will always be negatives. Government members are here to make sure that the positives of the package are also put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The other interesting point about the debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1986-87 that causes me to laugh from time to time is that honourable members opposite seem to forget that since 1949, with the exception of about six years, the conservatives-the Liberal Party and the National Party and its predecessor, the Country Party-occupied the treasury bench for well over 30 years. If they were so concerned about issues such as the 17 1/2 per cent holiday leave loadings, penalty rates, wage flexibility, this, that and the other, for heaven's sake why did they not do something about them when they were in government? I guess everyone has the luxury when in opposition of being able to bleat about some of these points without having the responsibility of doing anything positive about them.

Opposition members have glossed over some of the wage flexibility that has existed in this country over the last three years or so. People seem to forget that we have had a great deal of wage flexibility because we are the only government in recent times that has had a wages policy. The significant difference in fiscal policy separating the Opposition from the Government is the fact that the Government can reach an accommodation with the trade union movement in this country to do something about a genuine wages policy that is agreed on with the trade unions. The 17 1/2 per cent holiday leave loading about which we have heard again this evening-the old chestnut-contributes about 1 1/2 per cent of total labour costs. Yet in the past 12 months, under the processes of the accord, this Government has achieved wage flexibility by way of a 2 per cent wage discount in respect of the consumer price index. That amount is significantly greater than would have been achieved had the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading been abolished.

We seem to forget that we now have, as a result of the policies that have been pursued under our Government for the last 3 1/2 years, a wages outcome that puts wages back to a relative position against profits within the community. Profits are at an all-time high. In the context of these debates we forget some of the positive achievements that have been part of the accord during the past three years. (Quorum formed)

I am very much indebted to the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) for allowing my parliamentary colleagues to hear the comments I was about to make on some of the positive outcomes of the accord during the last three years. I was about to say, before I was interrupted by the honourable member for Wakefield-

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look at the number of Liberals in here-there are hardly any at all.

—As my colleague the honourable member for Melbourne points out one can almost count the number of Liberals in here at present on one hand and have four fingers left. They are not interested in hearing about some of the positive achievements-
—Order! I would not pick up the comments of the honourable member for Melbourne, as they were quite disorderly.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, but they were a valuable observation. Under this Government the rate of economic growth in Australia has been the fastest of any of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. The last three years has been the most consistent period of sustained and high level growth since the early 1970s. Australia has experienced the fastest employment growth in the world and is the only OECD country projected to have a further fall in unemployment. The quality of Australia's employment growth also stands out amongst the OECD countries. More than two-thirds of our job growth is in full time employment. Almost 90 per cent of jobs now derive from the private sector and 57 per cent of the new jobs have gone to women. The rate of inflation prior to the devaluation has been more than halved. Whilst it is currently high compared to some of the OECD countries, it has to be seen in the context of high economic and employment growth, as my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) pointed out in his valuable contribution a few minutes ago.

SPEECH.PARA: Inflation is not the measure of competitiveness. The devaluation and the level of unit labour costs are very critical factors. Profitability as a proportion of gross domestic product has been raised significantly from about 11 per cent to 15 1/2 per cent. Industrial disputation, the concern of the Opposition, is at its lowest level for 18 years-despite the comments we hear from the Opposition all the time. My friend the honourable member for Charlton in his contribution pointed to the fact that many of the measures the Government has been forced to take as a result of external factors have been brought about by the collapse of world commodity prices. It is illuminating to point out exactly how severe that collapse has been. In the case of coal, between 1981-82 and the fiscal year just ended the collapse was 28 per cent. In the same time scale the collapse in wheat prices was 27 per cent. In the case of iron-ore, it was 26 per cent and significantly, in the case of sugar, between 1978-81 and 1985-86 the decline was more than 68 per cent. So we are not just talking about insignificant declines in our commodity prices. We are talking about devastating declines which, as the honourable member for Charlton pointed out, have meant that our trade has suffered to the extent of $6 billion.

Significantly, this Government has responsibly responded with a Budget that takes into account the external factors that have been forced upon us. What did the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) have to say in his response-a most pitiful response-to the Budget a few days later? But it is not a matter of what I think, or what my colleagues think, of what the Leader of the Opposition thinks. It is significant to point out that the Sydney Morning Herald, that free-thinking newspaper, on 22 August, the day after the Budget, made the following commitments:

While criticising the Government for not making deeper and more permanent spending cuts in this week's Budget, he again failed to say which government programs he would cut. His failure will undermine the credibility of his promise to hold government spending at zero real growth for three years, and therefore his promise to cut taxes.

That is what the Sydney Morning Herald thought of the Budget comments by the Leader of the Opposition. No one really takes the comments of the Leader of the Opposition very seriously at all because we know that the reality is that talk is cheap when one is in opposition. We have delivered the goods in very difficult economic circumstances-circumstances that have been forced upon Australia through no fault of our own. The Sydney Morning Herald went on to point out:
The crucial question is whether Mr Howard would do better. If he will not say now what he would like to cut because he knows it would be politically too damaging, would he, as Prime Minister--
Heaven forbid!-
be prepared to actually make the cuts? His record as Treasurer and his silence as Opposition Leader will leave the public in doubt.

I thought that was a very significant analysis of the Opposition Leader's contribution. Very conservative elements within the Australian media have looked at what the Opposition Leader had to say and have dismissed his comments as indeed they should be dismissed. We are in very difficult economic circumstances because we as a nation have for too long relied upon a very narrow economic base. For many years we have had the attitude that if we experienced some sort of external problem all we had to do was to plant a few more crops or dig a few more holes. Unfortunately, the chickens have come home to roost on that proposition. We can no longer do that. The green revolution is a great thing so far as humanitarian ideals are concerned but it has been a trade disaster for a country such as Australia.

What we have to do is to use the new-found competitive position we now have as the result of a floating exchange rate to counteract the sorts of policies that were part of the Fraser-Howard Administration for many years in the 1970s and the early 1980s. Manufacturing industry was wiped out because of an over-valued exchange rate. There are signs in Australia now that that position is being turned around, but at an enormous cost, because most of that industry was just cast aside during those difficult years. I believe that this Budget sets the parameters under which that sort of situation can be reversed. It is not going to happen during this fiscal year; it is a process that will occur over a number of years. But the 1986-87 Budget is a very important start in that process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Anybody listening to this debate-today not being a radio day, very few people have that dubious privilege, although I am glad to see that some members of the Australian Labor Party are present-will appreciate that Australia at this time in its history is crying out for leadership and for a sense of direction. It is crying out for a government that would be clearly committed to making Australia the great country it should be, a government which would build our nation's prosperity, thereby enhancing choices and self-fulfilment for ordinary Australians, and a government which would enhance the freedom of Australians by breaking down the power of big government, big unions and even big business and putting power back into the hands of ordinary people. Finally, Australia is crying out for a government which would enhance domestic social stability and build the external security of our nation.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a great tragedy for Australia that at this time it is receiving none of that leadership from the Government. By the yardsticks I have outlined, the Hawke Labor Government has been nothing short of a complete and utter failure. The Budget we are debating today is one of its instruments of failure. Australians should not really have been surprised by the failure of a Hawke government. They should have expected it. In an historical editorial on 21 August 1980, at the end of the decade of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as the head of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Financial Review said:
The very first thing that needs to be said about Mr Hawke's decade at the head of the ACTU is that it has been a decade of barren failure.

His period as Prime Minister has also been a barren failure. One of the reasons for that failure is that the Government has absolutely no sense of direction. All it is doing is scurrying around in circles trying to please special interest groups. On the first day it tries to please the unions. On the second day it tries to please the Left of its own Party. On the third day, it tries to please the opinion polls. On the fourth day, it provides funds and tries to please the peace groups. On the fifth day, it tries to appease some welfare lobbies and, on the sixth, it tries to please big business. By the seventh day, when the Government inevitably rests, all it does is rest in the knowledge that it has pleased absolutely no one; it has given the nation no leadership; and it has given the nation no sense of direction. In a desperate endeavour to please all these various groups, the Government has, of course, spent money. It has tried to buy the support of the electorate.

As every honourable member of this House now knows, the Hawke Government's record on spending is nothing short of appalling. The tragedy of this Budget is that, despite the economic crisis the Government has created, to which it now admits, and despite the cries of the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for restraint and belt tightening and their recognition that Labor has overspent-and mightily-this Budget does not reduce spending at all. It should have but, in any case, let us look at the totality of the Government's record on spending.

Since this Government came to power in March 1983-a sad time, as it has turned out, for the nation-Commonwealth spending has increased by a massive 16.7 per cent. That figure does not mean very much to people; but, when one puts it into numbers, spending has increased by $25,972m. That is how much public expenditure has been increased by this Government. Forty-four per cent of Australia's national income is now consumed by governments-which, of course, includes State governments as well. Total State, Federal and local government spending last financial year was 10 per cent more than the total value of all companies listed on all Australian stock exchanges-a figure that I find quite staggering-and total taxes and charges were 85 times greater than the profits of Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Obviously this spending spree has had an immense impact on the economy. It has given Australia the highest interest rates in the industrialised world. It has given Australia an inflation rate double the average of our trading partners. It has given Australia the greatest tax burden that it has ever had in its history; and it has given Australia a $100 billion foreign debt-up from just $18 billion in 1981-and a balance of payments deficit the like of which we have never seen before.

We are now into the fourth quarter of a recession created by this Government. When we bear all those factors in mind, it is no wonder that Australia has lost its AAA rating. The assessment of Moody's Investor Services, which led to the loss of that AAA rating, as honourable members well know, was very perceptive. I quote from its assessment because I think it is important that honourable members understand it. Moody's is reported as having said:
Recent measures by the Government to reduce public spending-
and, of course, the report is referring there to the Budget-

are likely to be insufficient to put a brake on the build-up in debt requirements. Moody's said that its rating decision also reflects several internal factors, including inflation rates running at twice the OECD average and unemployment pressures.
Industrial and labour market rigidities are further expected to hamper the country's efforts to shift economic resources into areas with high foreign exchange earning capacity.

That is the assessment, not of the Opposition, of the Liberal Party of Australia or even of the Australian community: That is the assessment of Moody's, which has now taken away Australia's AAA rating. Australians should not be surprised for one moment that we have lost our AAA rating because, when one looks at the history of this Government and at some of the remarks that have been made by members of the Australian Labor Party, one can see that that was almost one of its death wishes. It is interesting to observe that on 11 February 1983, during the then election campaign, the Australian Financial Review reported:
Labor will rely on a naive 19th Century faith in funny money and public works.

I do not think anybody could deny that, in that assessment, the Australian Financial Review was absolutely right. Let us look at where this naive belief in funny money and public works came from. It came from Labor's 1983 policy platform. If only people would now turn back to that policy platform, they would realise that we were always doomed to end up where we are today if we elected, as the nation did, a Labor Government. In that policy platform, the Labor Party said that it wanted to increase the portion of capital inflow on the basis on loan capital, rather than equity capital. It went on to say that Labor would initiate a program of public borrowing overseas and would resort to increased borrowings to fund the deficit. That is why we have an immense balance of payments problem and an immense foreign debt problem. That is why we have lost our AAA rating.

As I said, we should not be surprised that we have lost our AAA rating because one only has to go back to the July 1982 Labor Party conference to see what the then Deputy Premier of New South Wales-a senior member of the Labor Party-had to say.
