We must remember what he said because he had great prescience:
Friends, if and when we get a Labor Government-
he did in the end-

if we adopt some of the policies . . . that are in our Platform international capitalism will take away our AAA rating anyhow, and if we are in a position where we have got to worry and please internationalism to retain our AAA rating then we do not deserve to be in Government.

The then Labor Deputy Premier of New South Wales, by the standards of the Labor Party, was right to say that. He was prescient. He showed great perspicacity because what he predicted in fact happened. It is clear now that the Hawke Labor Government realises the disasters that pursuing the policies that it has pursued for over three years has reaped upon Australians. All the way through it has ignored the warnings that have been given to it. It sneered and denigrated the Opposition with puerile political points. It sneered and denigrated editorials in newspapers. It sneered at and denigrated the international financial community. Attack is all it has been about against those who have disagreed with it. Yet by ignoring those warnings, it has ended up making the very mistakes that were predicted, and that has caused great harm not just to the economy, in terms of statistics, but to ordinary Australians.

In the Budget Papers last year, the Treasury said that it was expected that there would be a marked deterioration in the terms of trade. Yet, in the last Budget, the Government increased public expenditure by $6,000m, while all along it had been advised by its own department that a marked deterioration in the terms of trade was to be expected. But the Treasurer blindly turned his back on that advice. He obviously rejected the advice of his own Department. On 20 May he went around pretending all was well and he said things such as that what we have is an entirely healthy economy. The tragedy of this Government is that, in spite of the collapse of the Australian economy, which I hope I have made clear, the Government has still ignored the exigencies of the times. It has ignored the need to change direction in this Budget.

The Government has argued that it has brought down a $3.5 billion deficit. Practically every respected financial commentator in Australia has agreed with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) that that figure is entirely phoney and that in fact the Government is not really achieving financial restraint in the way it should. That view has been taken not only by respected financial commentators but also by members of the Government. No less a distinguished person than the person who I believe will be No. 3 on the Labor Party Senate ticket in Victoria, Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, has admitted that this Budget is inadequate, because he has said that there must be further spending cuts. The Treasurer, too, with a little gobbledegook, has admitted, in effect, that the Government will be looking for a mini-Budget sometime early next year. I think I am right in saying that Senator Walsh is another person who has added to that particular view. In other words, the Government has admitted that its own policies and its own Budget are completely inadequate.

Let us just look at how the Government achieved this phoney $3.5 billion deficit. It has increased taxes, taking the productive resources out of the economy, by $1,400m in this Budget. With a sleight of hand and creative accounting, as it is often called, it has added some $2,600m to government revenue through the Reserve Bank of Australia selling the nation's reserves, through the Reserve Bank's profits. It has also deferred, not cut, spending worth about $1,000m by postponing the payment of tax cuts and the indexation of various social security measures. In other words, this is a government which, with a sleight of hand, is trying to show that it is economically responsible but which, in fact, is still encompassed with a philosophy of squandermania which is bringing this country to its knees. As a member of the Waste Watch Committee I can say proudly that we have done a great deal to expose the squandermania of the Labor Government. We have exposed the fact that the Government has increased spending on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation by 125 per cent. We all know who is the Ambassador to UNESCO.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your own electoral office?

—The Government has wasted $3m on peace grants to all sorts of groups which, according to the Prime Minister, are backed by the Soviet Union. It spent $100,000 on junkets for environment Ministers to, of all places, Norfolk Island. Why would they want to have a meeting there? I must admit that I am a little surprised to hear the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) interjecting, because I was hoping we would not get on to commercial radio. Grants to unions have been paid in immense proportions. Let us concentrate on Adelaide. There the United Trades and Labour Council has received $323,000 from the Labor Government so far. The Movement Against Uranium Mining, rather ironically I would have thought, has received grants of $84,000 from the Government. The Movement for the Ordination of Women within the Anglican Church has received a grant from the Government, the first time in Australian history that a government has become involved in the internal doctrinal debates of one of our great churches. Unrelated, if I may say so, to the Anglican Church, the Gay Actors Ensemble has received $6,700 worth of taxpayers' money by way of a grant. These are only small figures, of course, but they are an illustration of the way in which this Government spends money on all sorts of vested interest groups which, when the time comes, it is hoped by the Government, will deliver votes for it.

SPEECH.PARA: I warn the Government, though, that the political impact of wasting taxpayers' money can, in fact, be very severe. In the early 1920s the then British Government was accused of being extremely wasteful, and by all accounts it was. So wasteful was that Government that a new political party was formed, called the Anti-Waste League. Surprisingly, although it stood on only one plank, and that plank was to reduce government spending, it had two members of parliament elected in by-elections in 1921. It is a warning to the Government, because the political price of wasting other people's money is a very high one. Australians have had enough of the big spending policies of this Government.

There are really two fundamental consequences, quite apart from the economic consequences that I have described, of this squandermania which is so much part of socialism and Labor governments. The first is inevitably high taxation. When a government spends other people's money it raises money through taxpayers and, in effect, redistributes wealth from the productive sectors of the economy. That is, of course, all part of the Labor Party policy. It wants to reduce incentives-it is not interested in productivity-and it denies the whole philosophy of encouraging achievement, which should be so much part of what Australia is about, and I know it would be about with a Liberal government.

Let me take one industry that is important to my electorate, the wine industry. I would have thought the honourable member for Adelaide would be interested in the wine industry as well. Wine production is one of the few things nowadays that Australia is doing really well. It is producing high quality wines. What does the Government do? It does not assist the industry; it doubles the tax on the industry. Really, that has to be just about the most absurd decision that any government has taken-to double the tax on one of the few industries that we have which is productive. As a result of that, the Government will be forced into taking further action to bail out those people in the wine industry who are suffering. The Government will now have to set up an economic study to assess the impact of the doubling of the wine tax on the industry so that it can predict what the consequences really will be.

It did not do an economic study on the impact of the fringe benefits tax on the car industry, and look what happened to that. It was proud that it did not do such a study. It must do such a study on the wine industry so that at least the Government has some direction about what is going to happen to that industry. It could very well be forced into a position of providing more structural assistance to the wine industry, which is only another form of additional government expenditure, which is something that I do not want to encourage, but that additional assistance could run up a bill of in the vicinity of $20m if expected trends in the industry eventuate. The Government, in any case, will have to do a great deal more to encourage all exports, including exports from the wine industry.

I was recently in the city of Bristol in the west of England, where there was a wine fair. I hasten to add that I paid for my trip to Bristol and back. It was one of the major wine fairs of western Europe. The presence of the Australian wine industry at the Bristol wine fair could be described-I do not exaggerate-only as absolutely pathetic. Much more will have to be done to help that industry. Some of those problems could have been avoided if honourable members on the other side of the House were not so mad on taxation. It has done the same thing to the dairy industry, which is struggling. The Government introduced a tax on flavoured milk. It has done the same thing to the citrus industry, which is struggling against dumped imports from Brazil, by imposing a 10 per cent tax.

High tax in this country is destroying enterprise, incentive and our capacity as a nation to get ahead and compete with the rest of the world. Big spending, let me also add, is not compassionate. The objective of a lot of this big spending is to help those in need, but a government will never be able to provide the assistance that families, friends and neighbours can provide to people. Yet all people in Australia turn to the Government now for assistance because they think that is the only source of help. If we could get government off people's backs, if we could get away from that mendicant mentality in this country, if we could reduce the size of government, we could return to traditional care, community care and compassion, which does so much to help those who are disadvantaged.

In conclusion, let me reiterate that the Hawke Government is a failure. It has failed in the same way as the Prime Minister failed when he was President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions-a complete and utter failure. Australia needs new directions, new vision and new hope for the future, and it will get it from the Howard Liberal government which will be elected at the next election.
Debate (on motion by Mr Grace) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will amend the income tax law to give effect to several of the taxation measures announced in the 1986-87 Budget. In that regard, it will vary in some respects the trading stock valuation arrangements relevant to horse breeders, restore the income tax exemption of the pay of Defence Force reservists and provide income tax deductions for certain gifts. Other amendments contained in the Bill will authorise deductions in respect of cash bids for off-shore petroleum exploration permits, provide a more generous basis for the offsetting of profit on the disposal of animals under the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign and effect changes to the withholding tax on interest on overseas borrowings. In addition, the Bill will amend the income tax law to provide for the calculation of 1986-87 provisional tax. It will also give the force of law in Australia to a taxation agreement with Austria and a further protocol to the existing taxation agreement with the Netherlands. Finally, some minor amendments of the income tax and other taxation laws are being effected. I will now outline in more detail the significant measures contained in the Bill.
Trading Stock Valuation of Horses

The Bill will give effect to two 1986-87 Budget measures relating to the valuation of horses for income tax trading stock purposes. Under the trading stock provisions of the law, live stock on hand at the end of a year may be valued, at the taxpayer's option, at cost price or market selling value or at such other value as circumstances may justify. A taxpayer may bring natural increase in live stock to account at a cost price not less than prescribed amounts-$1 per head for sheep, $5 per head for cattle and horses and $4 per head for pigs-but substantially less than actual cost. This allows tax to be deferred until the disposal of the natural increase.

The economic and rural policy statement of 15 April 1986 announced changes to the trading stock valuation arrangements for animal stud breeders generally. However, reflecting the fact that the tax deferral advantages are generally much greater for horse breeders than for breeders of other animals, it was announced in the 1986-87 Budget that changes would be restricted to horse breeders and would apply only in respect of service fees.

Accordingly, the Bill will amend the law so that for trading stock purposes the cost price of a horse acquired by natural increase is not less than any service fee-whether for physical or artificial service-that is incurred after 19 August 1986 in acquiring the horse. This is expected to result in a gain to revenue of $7 million in 1988-89, with negligible gains in subsequent years.

The second of the 1986-87 Budget amendments under this heading relates to the special valuation option available to horse breeders in respect of sires and brood-mares. Horse breeders may elect to write down the cost of sires and brood-mares at rates of 50 per cent and 33 1/2 per cent respectively on a diminishing value basis or to write down the cost of mares over a minimum period of three years. In relation to horses acquired after 19 August 1986, the Bill will limit this special option to horses that are aged three years or more. This amendment, which should have no revenue consequences, will ensure that, as intended, the concessional basis of valuation is available only in respect of breeding stock.
Pay of Defence Force Reserve

This Bill will give effect to the Budget announcement to reinstate full taxation exemption of the pay and allowances of members of the Defence Force reserves and emergency reserves for service, other than continuous full-time service, on or after 1 January 1987. Full tax exemption will also be reinstated in respect of any gratuity paid to members of the emergency reserves by reason of a calling out for continuous service on or after 1 January 1987. These changes are estimated to cost $5m in 1986-87 and $12m in a full year. There will be an offsetting reduction to outlays of $8m in a full year associated with the discontinuance of the special reserve allowance.
Gifts

Another 1986-87 Budget measure to which the Bill gives effect will allow deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more made after 19 August 1986 to the Australian Academy of Technological Sciences and to the Australian College of Occupational Medicine. The estimated cost of revenue of this measure is nil for 1986-87 and less than $60,000 in a full year.
Cash Bidding Payments

The Bill will implement the proposal announced on 15 January 1986 to allow income tax deductions in respect of payments made to the Commonwealth under the cash bidding system introduced last year for the award of off-shore petroleum exploration permits in highly prospective areas. This will ensure that Australian companies are not placed at a competitive disadvantage compared with foreign based companies entitled to income tax deductions for the payments in their home countries. In cases where exploration leads to the development and production of petroleum, cash bids will be able to be written off on a straight line basis over the lesser of 10 years and the life of the producing field. Write-off will commence in the income year in which a production licence is first acquired in respect of the relevant permit area.

In the event that the original cash bidder disposes of an interest in the permit area before the grant of a production licence, the original bidder may transfer to the purchaser an entitlement to deductions. If no production licence is granted, or if the permit expires or is wholly surrendered, the amount of the cash bid will qualify as an eligible capital loss for capital gains tax purposes. The cost to revenue of this proposal is estimated at $1m in the 1988-89 year, increasing to $1.5m in each subsequent year.

I take this opportunity to make known the Government's intention to extend income tax deductibility, on the basis just outlined, to cash bids paid under the Commonwealth cash bidding work program system introduced in 1967. Deductibility will also be extended to cash bids paid under systems in force in the States and the Northern Territory that are comparable to the Commonwealth systems. In this regard, honourable members would be aware that, in a joint statement yesterday, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Victorian Minister for Industry, Technology and Resources announced the release of a petroleum exploration area straddling Commonwealth and Victorian jurisdictions. The proposed extension of deductibility will ensure that cash bids paid in respect of that area qualify for income tax deductions. The further necessary amendments will be introduced into the Parliament as soon as practicable and, like those contained in this Bill, will apply from 15 January 1986.
Profits from Death or Destruction of Live Stock

Amendments of the income tax law proposed by the Bill will vary the operation of an existing option available in respect of profits resulting from proceeds on the death or destruction of live stock because of bovine brucellosis or tuberculosis. The proposal was announced in the economic and rural policy statement of 15 April 1986 and the variation will apply in respect of the death or destruction of live stock after 30 June 1986. Under the existing law, the average profit per head on live stock that die or are destroyed because of certain diseases may be offset against the cost per head of replacement animals acquired during the year of death or destruction or during the next five years.

The Government recognises that the replacement of animals lost because of bovine brucellosis or tuberculosis may take longer than five years and that a lost herd may be replaced by fewer, but more expensive, animals. The Bill will therefore broaden the basis on which relevant profits may be offset against the cost of replacement animals. It will extend the period of offset by five years. It will also provide for profits to be offset on a herd basis rather than on a per head basis-that is, the whole of the profits may be offset progressively against the total cost of replacement animals. The amendments are not expected to have any significant effect on revenue.
INTEREST WITHHOLDING TAX EXEMPTIONS

The exemption from interest withholding tax for interest payments on overseas borrowings by a State, or by a Commonwealth or State authority where the loan funds are not used in direct competition with the private sector, is to be withdrawn in relation to borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986 in accordance with the Government decision announced on that day.

On 28 July 1986, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) indicated that it was Government policy that public authorities should face a similar environment in respect of borrowings as do private sector borrowers. Consistent with this policy, the Bill proposes that the States and State and Commonwealth authorities be exempted from withholding tax for interest payments on public or other widely spread issues of securities overseas in the same way as a resident company raising money for use in an Australian business.

The withdrawal of the interest withholding tax exemption for the States and authorities is to apply to borrowings contracted for after 1 July 1986 but will not affect interest payments made on or before the date on which the Bill receives royal assent. Pending enactment, the States and authorities may continue to apply for exemption for overseas borrowings in relation to interest payments up to the date of royal assent. Thereafter they will be able to obtain exemption to the extent permitted by the amended provisions relating to public or other widely spread issues of securities overseas. The Bill also proposes removal of the generally applicable conditions for that exemption that the loan be raised in a foreign currency and that interest be payable in a foreign currency.

Advocates of these changes have argued that the existing requirements impose unnecessary additional costs and impede the ability of Australian borrowers to raise off-shore funds in Australian currency and so reduce their foreign exchange exposure. These amendments will apply to interest payments made after the Bill receives the royal assent.

A recent court decision has shown that roll-overs or extensions of loans contracted for some years ago remain able to benefit from the previous `Australian entity' interest withholding tax exemption. This is an unintended result as the exemption was withdrawn to have general effect from June 1983. Accordingly, the Bill proposes to preclude the exemption of interest paid on borrowings resulting from relevant loan roll-overs and loan extensions effected after 1 July 1986 or from the post-1 July 1986 drawing down of funds under a pre-existing loan facility where the borrower was not, before 2 July 1986, contractually bound to use that facility.

Corresponding provisions are proposed in relation to the withdrawal of the exemption for overseas borrowings by the States and by public authorities. Similarly, another provision of the law which until June 1983 provided exemption in relation to overseas borrowings by the Australian Industry Development Corporation is to be amended to make clear that loan roll-overs and loan extensions do not preserve the former exemption. Those measures will also apply in relation to interest payments made after the date of enactment of the Bill. Anti-avoidance provisions will prevent the re-arrangement of interest payments to bring them into the period, prior to enactment, in which the relevant exemptions remain available.
Provisional tax for 1986-87

As provisional tax is part of the pay as you earn system and is designed to collect tax on non-salary or wage income within the year in which the income is derived, it is generally accepted that the amount of provisional tax charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year. Incomes to which provisional tax applies are expected to increase in 1986-87 but, due to the proposed reductions in personal income tax rates from 1 December 1986, effective rates of tax for 1986-87 will be lower than for last year. As in the past, it is proposed that the basis that would otherwise apply in the calculation of provisional tax be varied for the current year to take account of these two factors. Accordingly, this Bill provides for 1986-87 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1985-86 taxable income increased by 11 per cent and by applying the lower rates of tax for 1986-87.

Also reflected in the provisional tax calculation will be the proposed increased rate of 1.145 per cent at which the Medicare levy is to be imposed for 1986-87. The increased low income thresholds to apply for levy purposes in 1986-87 will be taken into account.

Generally, rebates and credits will be allowed in the provisional tax calculation at the levels allowed in 1985-86 assessments. For Christmas Island residents, however, the rebate allowed in their 1985-86 assessments will be reduced by one-third in line with the arrangements for phasing in personal income tax on the Island.

Taxpayers who consider that their taxable income for 1986-87 will increase by less than 11 per cent, or who consider that their rebates will be at a higher level, will continue to have the right to `self-assess' and have the provisional tax for 1986-87 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
The Austrian Comprehensive Tax Agreement

I now turn to provisions of the Bill that will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a comprehensive double taxation agreement dealing with all forms of income flowing between Australia and Austria. The agreement was signed on 8 July 1986, at which time details were announced and copies of the agreement were made publicly available. It accords with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years. The Bill will insert the text of the agreement into the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act 1953 as a schedule to that Act. The agreement will not enter into force until all necessary constitutional processes are completed both by Australia and Austria. The agreement is not expected to have any significant effect on the revenue.
Second Netherlands Protocol

The Bill will provide legislative authority for the entry into force of a second protocol amending the existing comprehensive taxation agreement and protocol between Australia and the Netherlands. The second protocol will enable the Netherlands to close an avenue for avoidance of its tax being exploited by Netherlands investors deriving interest from debt claims secured by mortgage over real property in Australia. At present, Netherlands tax does not generally apply to such interest, which is treated under the agreement as income from real property. The protocol will treat the income in the same way as other interest is treated under the agreement. This will allow the Netherlands to tax such interest from Australia in full, subject to the allowance of a credit for Australian tax paid on the interest, instead of the interest being generally free of Netherlands tax and subject only to Australian withholding tax of 10 per cent.

The tax treatment in Australia of interest flowing from Australia to the Netherlands will be unchanged. The gross amount of such interest will continue to be liable to Australian interest withholding tax of 10 per cent. Mortgage interest derived by Australian residents from the Netherlands is presently exempt from tax in Australia if it is subject to Netherlands tax. Under the protocol, such interest will be taxable in Australia, with a credit for the Netherlands tax, which is limited to a maximum of 10 per cent of the gross interest. The protocol will generally have effect in Australia for years of income commencing on or after 1 July 1986 and, in the Netherlands, for taxable years and periods beginning on or after 1 January 1986.

Transitional entry into force arrangements will ensure that the protocol will not apply to interest paid under contractual obligations entered into before 30 June 1986, when the protocol was formally signed, until Australian years of income commencing on or after 1 July 1988 and Netherlands taxable years and periods beginning on or after 1 January 1988. Appropriate anti-avoidance measures will safeguard the operation of the transitional arrangements. The protocol will enter into force after the procedures necessary to give it the force of law in both countries are completed.
MINOR AMENDMENTS

The Bill will amend the income tax law to add the Secretary to the Department of Science as an authority to approve bodies as approved research institutes for income tax purposes. It will also amend various taxation laws to reverse an unintentional alteration to the burden of proof provisions by the Taxation Boards of Review (Transfer of Jurisdiction) Act 1986.

An explanatory memorandum which comprehensively explains the measures contained in this Bill, and in another Bill that I will introduce shortly, is being circulated for the information of honourable members. In commending the Bill to the House I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill. I repeat that it is also an explanatory memorandum for the next Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BANK ACCOUNT DEBITS TAX AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will give effect to the 1986-87 Budget proposal to increase the general rates of bank account debits tax. For cheque accounts kept with banks outside the Australian Capital Territory, including Jervis Bay, the highest rate of bank account debits tax will be increased from $1.50 to $2, with other rates being increased by up to one half. The increased rates will apply to debits made on or after 1 December 1986.

In view of the proposal announced in the Budget to introduce a financial institutions duty in the Australian Capital Territory from 1 July 1987, the rates of bank account debits tax presently applying in the Australian Capital Territory will remain unchanged. Increasing the general rates of bank account debits tax is expected to raise additional revenue of $45m in 1986-87 and $90m in a full year. The explanatory memorandum that has been circulated already to honourable members also explains the provisions of this Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Carlton) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION AND OTHER BENEFITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Hurford, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HURFORD
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Pensions payable to, or in relation to, former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel under the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976, the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948, the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973 and the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) (Superannuation) Regulations are increased in July each year in accordance with the increase in the weighted average of the consumer price index for the six State capital cities to the previous 31 March. On 3 July 1986 these pensions were increased on the basis of the 9.2 per cent increase in the consumer price index to 31 March 1986.

The extraordinary circumstances of the economy require all members of the community to share the cost of reducing Government expenditure. Accordingly, as announced in the Budget Speech, the 2 per cent wage discount recently applied to wages is to be extended to government superannuation benefits payable to, or in relation to, former Commonwealth Government employees and Defence Force personnel.

This Bill amends the Defence Force Retirement and Death Benefits Act 1973, the Defence Forces Retirement Benefits Act 1948, the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 and the Papua New Guinea (Staffing Assistance) (Superannuation) Regulations to provide for the levels of pensions payable under that legislation to be decreased with effect from 10 October 1986 to the levels that would have applied if the increase in July 1986 had been based on an increase of 7.2 per cent in the consumer price index rather than an increase of 9.2 per cent.

It is expected that, as a result of the proposed amendments, Government outlays on the relevant pensions during 1986-87 will reduce by approximately $12.6m and during 1987-88 by approximately $17.3m. In commending the Bill to the House, I present an explanatory memorandum relating to the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Tim Fischer) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (Budget Debate)
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the Government's Budget, unlike Opposition members, who come in here and grandstand that they have the policies to resurrect our economy and put it back on the rails. The fact is that they have no policies at all-or perhaps they have a couple hidden around this House somewhere, which for sure would be organised by the New Right. Nevertheless, the Australian public will realise which party has firm policies and which party is prepared to make the tough decisions that need to be taken at this point.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable members that the Government remains firmly committed to an economic strategy in which traditional tools of macroeconomic policy are supported by and co-ordinated with a consensus-based incomes policy. It is nothing like the Opposition with its confrontationist attitude to almost everything. If some of the Opposition's so-called policies were to be introduced, it would really destroy the very fabric of our society which this Government has worked so hard to mend after the dismal failure of the previous Government.

I believe that this Budget is one of the toughest brought down by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and I congratulate him on his firm stance and his even-handedness, but we must remember that it was brought down in some of the hardest times that this nation has ever faced. The Government has proved that it is prepared to take the necessary steps to alleviate those problems. Of course, those conditions would not have been easily discernible when the last Budget was delivered.

Let us look at some of the problems that lie ahead. First, it is common knowledge that the trade war being waged between the United States of America and the European Economic Community is having an effect on our economy. For instance, it is well known that we have had $6 billion cut from our national income. This needs to be corrected. The Government, the unions and the business community are not responsible for this, but the Government needs to take the necessary action to address the problems faced by this country. The Government has seen the need to reduce the Federal deficit-a legacy left to us by the previous bumbling Treasurer, the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). This year the deficit has been reduced to about $3.5 billion-a reduction of about $2,233m. But I would remind the House that, had that action not been taken, the deficit would have blown out to $7.5 billion. The deficit blew out to about $9.6 billion in 1982-83, when no action was taken by the present Leader of the Opposition because of his weakness and ineptitude to comprehend the situation.

This year, outlays are estimated to be about $74,764m. This represents an increase in nominal terms of about 6.9 per cent. Increases in real terms are expected to show no change in 1986-87 compared with increases of 2.5 per cent in 1985-86 and 6 per cent in 1984-85. Budget outlays, as a proportion of gross domestic product, are expected to fall to 29.4 per cent this year and Budget receipts are expected to rise by 11 per cent, but this is slower than in the two preceding years.
