Let me now turn to some other aspects of the Budget that I feel are relevant. First, over the years child maintenance has been allowed to go unchecked. Over time it has grown to such an extent that it takes a great chunk out of our social security budget. This had to be changed, and I am pleased that the Government has taken the initiative to place the onus back on parents and make them more accountable for their responsibility to their children. The Government will legislate to set up an office within the Australian Taxation Office to ensure that payments are made.

Welfare cheats will not be too pleased to see further anti-fraud measures introduced. I remind honourable members of some of the anti-fraud measures already introduced and of how effectively they have worked. For example, direct crediting to banks of benefits and pensions has reduced fraud by 72 per cent. There has been a rise in the number of prosecutions for fraud involving $30,000 or more-86 per cent, to be precise. A further commitment that the Government has undertaken is the introduction of the identification card. I feel sure that this will go a long way to stopping social security fraud, and it will also make sure that all Australians pay their share of tax. Those who oppose the card must have something to hide when it comes to paying their taxes. I am also glad that the Government has decided to place a photograph on the card.

The pensioner community will also have to make a very small sacrifice to help the country; and it is a small sacrifice compared with other sections of the community. Pension increases will be delayed for 42 days. I do not think that is too much to ask of the pensioners. The cost of the increases to the pensioners is $300m and the deferral will save the Government $129m. The increases in other areas for allowances are commendable, to say the least, and the tightening of the administration of benefits is long overdue.

Another area of great concern to this Government is community services. It pleases me to see that expenditure is to be increased by 11 per cent to $1,867m, with $26m being earmarked for new projects. The streamlining and bringing together of all existing family support programs is an excellent idea and the Federal-State cost-sharing arrangement is to be continued. The home and community care programs will receive a significant boost of $94m to cater for people outside institutionalised settings. Education is another area where the Government can be proud. The introduction of an administration fee of $250 per annum is an excellent idea. (Quorum formed)

Before the quorum was called I was talking about the introduction of the $250 administration fee and I stated that it was an excellent idea. I say to those dithering on the periphery and calling those charges tertiary education fees that, if they do not understand that, they have a long way to go towards understanding the debate. The streamlining of educational allowances and bringing them under the one umbrella will help more than 233,000 students, and I might add that those receiving the new Austudy allowance will be reimbursed for the administration fee. This means an estimated 114,000 students will not pay any form of administration fee at all.

The Government's ongoing commitment to tertiary education funding is evident in the 2.5 per cent increase in real terms to $67.8m. Some of the significant increases that this Government has achieved are exceptional compared with the record of the previous Government. Under the Fraser Government funding fell by 0.6 per cent in real terms. Technical and further education institutions have also benefited from the Budget. The total outlays for TAFE have increased by 2.5 per cent to $314.6m.

As my allocated time draws to an end I would like to make a few general points. It amuses me to listen to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), talking about their alternative Budget plans. They want to cut this and cut that and freeze all spending increases for three years. That may be all right for the dries on the other side of the House, but what drastic effect will it have on the community and what drastic effect will it have on the economy in general? Fortunately, we will never have to find that out, because the people will realise, as the New Right rises to prominence, that its policies are a recipe for disaster. Charles Copeman and his cohorts in the H. R. Nicholls Society are pressing for some unbelievable demands.

Under this Government we have achieved a remarkably good record on the industrial relations scene. On assuming office in 1983 and introducing the prices and incomes accord, we were able to produce strong economic growth of almost 5 per cent in the first three years. I invite honourable members to compare that with the 2 per cent rate in the life of the Fraser Government. We have had the fastest rate of job growth in the Western world, with 650,000 new jobs. Industrial disputes are at half the level they were under the Fraser Government. There has been a fall of 7 per cent in real unit labour costs. No other country has achieved this. These are some of the results that the Fraser Government could only dream about and something that the Leader of the Opposition is now dreaming about.

If the Andrew Hays, the Charles Copemans, the Hugh Morgans, the John Stones-a lovely name-and the Paul Houlihans-he ought to be ashamed of himself, having an Irish name-get their way and are able to introduce some of their outlandish policy recommendations, this country will indeed be in big trouble. The dismal front that the Leader of the Opposition is trying to put on, that he is not influenced by these extremists, of course is laughable. I believe Dr Gerard Henderson, staff member of the Leader of the Opposition, is also a member of the H. R. Nicholls Society. Then, of course, there is that prolific leaker of documents who needs to have people neutralised, David Trebeck, who is also a member of the Society. But, of course, John Howard has nothing to do with the H. R. Nicholls Society! Well, he could have fooled me.

TALK.START.PARA: -Order! The honourable member will refer to members by their title.

—I refer to the Leader of the Opposition. My last statement is a warning for the people of Australia to beware, for if the H. R. Nicholls Society is influencing this country's political agenda, and I believe it is, there will be more than class warfare in Australia. I commend the Budget to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have this opportunity to contribute to the Budget debate this year. Unlike the honourable member for Fowler (Mr Grace), who spoke before me, the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), who spoke earlier in the day, the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Mildren) and the honourable member for Lilley (Mrs Darling), whose speeches I heard in particular, my comments will not be set in the past, endeavouring to obscure this Government's record by trying to draw comparisons with governments of three or four years ago. I would like to set the scene simply by recording a description of Australia's economy at this point in time:

SPEECH.PARA: The economic and financial background to monetary policy in Australia underwent substantial, sometimes dramatic, changes during 1985-86. The year began with strong growth in economic activity and buoyancy in sentiment. This situation was largely reversed as the year progressed . . .

At the outset of the year economic prospects were delicately poised. The economy was growing strongly, but inflation was double that in the major economies abroad and there was a rapidly growing external imbalance on current account . . .

The outlook nevertheless remains dominated by the need to restore external balance. The period of adjustment appears to be longer and more difficult than previously thought. In particular, the need to further restrain public spending and borrowing, and the rate of increase of labour costs is likely to persist for some time yet . . .
The task ahead remains formidable.

They are not my words; they are words that I picked out of the overview on the Australian economy by the Reserve Bank of Australia in its June 1986 report to members of this Parliament and to the Australian public generally. It set the scene for the way in which this Budget for this Government should have been drafted. I believe the Australian people were ready for the Government to make the decisions that were necessary in Australia's interests.

There were high expectations that this would be a tough Budget. I think all of the conditioning that had gone on before from the comments of the Treasurer (Mr Keating), whether they were deliberate or otherwise, that Australia had the prospect of being a banana republic had brought home to the Australian people the urgency of the situation and the need for our present problems to be addressed, and addressed in a realistic fashion. Community expectations had changed, and changed significantly. In my 13 years in the Parliament I have never seen the Australian public as well prepared for a difficult Budget as they were for this one. Overwhelmingly there has been a change of attitude and expectations. That change of expectations was such that the Australian public was prepared for, and expected, a tough approach in relation to government expenditure. Yet the expected hard decisions were not taken. The Budget was largely a wimp and the Australian people believe that. The fact of the matter is that, while there was some exaltation when the public first heard that there was in prospect a $3.5 billion deficit-a figure that it was generally prepared to believe, from the conditioning that had gone on before, was a reasonably good outcome-when people looked behind the figures and assessed the Budget in an objective way that deficit figure did not stand to scrutiny. That needs to be understood. In the context of a Budget of one of the Treasurers of a Government which I supported in the past, this Budget was seen by the Australian public and commentators to be rubbery. The figures are clearly rubbery.

The downturn in various tax collections is to be expected, having regard to the extent to which our economy is in recession. Mark you my words, Mr Deputy Speaker; this economy is in recession at this time, having experienced negative growth in the last three quarters. Clearly, tax collections cannot be expected to be maintained at the level of performance that the Government has predicted. More importantly, the downturn in economic indicators makes it clear to me that expenditures on the social welfare side will be very much greater than the amount for which the Government has budgeted.

We have already seen that the Government's projections in relation to unemployment in the first two months of this budgetary year have been in excess of the Budget predictions. The Budget predicted an 8 per cent level of unemployment. Already, for two months, we have seen a level of 8.3 per cent. It is unreasonable, when the economy is in recession, to expect that growth in employment will be such as to ensure that the Government's projections are realised. Obviously, the only result will be that outlays will be much more considerable than the amount for which the Government has budgeted. At a time when tax collections are significantly down and the Government's outlays, particularly in the important welfare areas-which are totally beyond government control-are up, the deficit achievement that has been predicted certainly cannot be realised. That, of course, is one of the reasons that this Budget has been so harshly judged by commentators.

There is a concern about the level of international debt that Australia has been incurring of late. The fact is that in June 1983 we had a public sector debt of $3.2 billion and a private sector debt of $19.8 billion-a total debt figure of $23 billion. At December 1984, public sector debt was $19.1 billion and private sector debt was $37.6 billion-a total net debt of $56.7 billion. It is quite clear that that debt is increasing at an alarming rate. The honourable member for Charlton, notwithstanding his claims that the private sector debt was larger and therefore should be regarded as a more significant factor, has totally misread the situation. The fact is that, in the space of two and a half years, public sector debt has increased by a total of 600 per cent. Over the same period, on the figures I have cited, the private sector debt has increased by merely 100 per cent. I am not saying that it is not a significant figure; of course it is. But the total increase in public sector debt has been of such an order that we have a real and significant problem in the making. The Government's Economic Planning Advisory Council, in a Council paper of October 1985 headed `Australia's Foreign and Public Sector Debt', commented:

If the country were to continue to borrow in an overall sense to finance consumption spending, disruptive adjustment would eventually become unavoidable-regardless of whether foreign debt was comprised mainly of public or private sector debt.

The honourable member for Charlton ought to bear those comments in mind. It is clearly a problem of enormous proportions. If the Government does not get that level of debt in hand promptly, other disruptive adjustments will eventually become unavoidable. I think that EPAC, when it talks in those terms, means that if the Government is not prepared to take firm steps in relation to the level of debt, receivers will have to be appointed. The International Monetary Fund-one of those international organisations that look at these questions-will be called upon to take our economy and the necessary adjustment in hand.

In relation to the question of debt, I direct the attention of honourable members to an article prepared for the Westpac Banking Corporation's economic discussion papers by Professor J. O. N. Perkins, who made some observations about the steps that were needed to reduce the level of debt. He stated:

The only wise policy is to take steps to reduce the extent of the rise in the country's external indebtedness, by making . . . efforts to improve the current account by the non-inflationary means of slowing down inflation in Australia.
These are the steps that he says are so essential:
This involves not only finding ways to keep down the rate of increase in labour costs, but also to hold down both government receipts and
more importantly-
the more inflationary forms of government outlay . . .

Those are the steps that an independent observer of government policy believes ought to be taken. Honourable members on this side of the House who have participated in this debate have given very clear warnings to the Government about the sorts of steps that ought to have been taken in the Budget-steps to get government expenditure far more in control than this Government has been able to do, and to be able to do so by taking the hard steps that the Australian public was prepared for and was ready to see put in place.

One of the great disappointments in relation to so many of the steps that were taken in relation to this Budget was the extent to which the Government merely fiddled at the edges and made temporary decisions that will not have any long term impact on future government budgetary outlays. For instance, one of the points that must be clearly made is that the changes to the payment of pensions involved a one-off decision and will have no long term impact on budgetary outlays in future years. These are the sorts of factors that need to be taken into account.

I think the Government should give greater attention to the constructive comments from the Opposition as to the areas in which expenditure cuts can be made. Without spelling out a full and alternative Budget, members of the coalition Waste Watch Committee have given a clear indication of numerous areas of funding that could be constructively attacked great hardship to the Australian people. When one looks at some of the organisations that are being funded by this Government, clearly there is very considerable scope for a reduction of expenditure.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) made it very clear in his contribution that one did not have to increase expenditure in particular areas to appease particular pressure groups at this time. Realistic steps can be taken in many areas simply to maintain and not increase the present level of expenditure. I refer to particular programs that were undertaken by the Government in the Budget. Of course, there are particular organisations that could, quite constructively, be abolished or simply terminated at this time, with a view also to reducing government outlays. I am afraid that the Government has shown itself unwilling to address those areas of expenditure. Its own blinkers and shackles have ensured that the way in which Budget cutting has been undertaken is extremely ineffectual and most disappointing. Having regard to the change of attitude on the part of the Australian public, I am disappointed that, in the national interest, the decisions that were necessary were not taken in this Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to support the Budget I think that, in the economic circumstances, it was a very commendable document and sets Australia on the right road. Although there were some cuts, I think that additional cuts could have been made. I am on record as saying that, had I been in charge, the Special Broadcasting Service would have been wiped out completely. I think it serves no purpose. I think that one of the great myths perpetrated by both major political parties in this country is what I call the myth of multiculturalism. It is nonsense; it is also divisive and potentially dangerous to the community. I think ethnic people in Australia have real problems. Quite a lot of them live in my electorate and they come to me and say: `If you are 40 and unemployed it is tough. If you are 40, ethnic and unemployed it is very tough'. They are very concerned about employment. Most ethnic people come to this country expecting a new life, willing to embrace our ways and our culture. They are quite happy to do that. In my opinion the SBS was always a sop to the middle class.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to pass a few remarks on what is commonly called the New Right. I do not intend to waste much time on it; it is hardly worthy of it. The so-called New Right is the very old Right-the same people with the same worn out ideas and the same rhetoric that have failed this country in the past. Let me refer to a few of the gentlemen involved. John Leard in his retirement, or perhaps dotage, took out full page advertisements in the Australian to tell us what was wrong with the country. Yet when that same gentleman was head of ANI Corporation Ltd he was one of the people who benefited from this country's entrenched system of protection. Obviously, that was bequeathed to us from the Black Jack McEwen era. John Leard was very happy to take advantage of that, and ANI Perkins endeavours in the field of exports were abysmal. Why should they worry when they had a totally protected Australian market?

These people have attacked the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading. We are now told that this is the cause of all our woes. Why suddenly, out of the blue, this should be so is very hard to say. These people resort to lying and the Opposition pushes their lies in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member will not use the word `lies'.

—I will defer to your better judgment, Madam Speaker, but collectively there would be no opposition to that. However, I am prepared to rephrase what I said. The Opposition pushes these people's incredible mistruths in this Parliament, and I think its lack of honesty will become apparent. The truth is that most countries equivalent to Australia have that sort of facility in their wage structure. Some countries have even higher facilities. In Europe the so-called thirteenth month is a very common practice. Taking a few of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries, Belgium has the equivalent of a 90 per cent loading; Denmark, 30 per cent; France, 30 per cent; Greece, 50 per cent; the Netherlands, 30 per cent; Norway, 32 per cent; Portugal, 100 per cent; Sweden, 25 per cent; and Finland, 50 per cent. In Sweden, Finland and Switzerland other measures also increase their wage bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading is not the problem. We often cite the United States of America, which does not have that facility but does pay an hourly rate considerably higher than that of Australia. I have recently looked at a study done in my electorate which pitched the wage rates of people at the North West Cape facility against those of equivalent people in Florida in the United States. It showed there was a minimum $3.50 difference in favour of the United States. One can buy a lot of 17 1/2 per cent holiday loadings with $3.50 an hour. Quite clearly, the leave loading was never a problem.

The so-called New Right has taken industrial action, used industrial lawlessness in my electorate, which has been very heavily hit. There was a nine-week strike at Kambalda which was brought about by the nineteenth century industrial relations practices used by Western Mining Corporation Ltd. Sir Arvi Parbo has taken steps to redress that matter and I am very pleased to see that he at least, of the Western Mining Board, has distanced himself from the antics of the New Right. Mr Copeman's Peko-Wallsend Ltd in Robe River incited enormous industrial trouble and then had the audacity, the gall, to concede that his motives were political. Here is a man who for his own political ideology was prepared not only to wreck the lives of a lot of innocent ordinary workers and their families but also to prejudice the welfare of his shareholders. With some glee one of the company's people told me that the shares had actually risen since the Robe River dispute. The truth is that the shares rose on the strength of the company's gold interests, not because of the industrial relations policy in Robe River. It is interesting to see some of the tired, old failures.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Kakadu National Park-Australian Companies: Economy-Australian Labor Party-Nuclear Waste-Hawke Government-Human Rights in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics-Interest Rates-India: Commercial and Cultural Relations-Taxation: Capital Gains

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.15 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government and particularly the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) object to the financial commitment that is necessary to sustain my electorate, the Northern Territory, as part of the Commonwealth. They conveniently overlook the role of the Commonwealth in bringing about that situation. Yesterday's rejection of the opportunity to raise more revenue for the Commonwealth and to strengthen the Australian and Territory economies is economic lunacy. Yesterday we saw the casual closing off to exploration and mining of 12,700 square kilometres-an area the size of Wales-of some of the world's richest mineralised land in Kakadu. In general the anti-mining lobby has, with some success, painted the entire Kakadu National Park area, both declared and prospective, as a lush wonderland where exotic species of bird and animal life abound beside brimming billabongs. Any intrusion by the dreaded miners, or even by a properly organised tourist industry, would despoil the billabongs, kill the crocodiles, and drive away the birds forever. This is not the reality. For a start, the vast size of the Kakadu parklands is not generally realised. Stages 1 and 2 of the park total up to 12,700 square kilometres. Stage 3 of the park, the Gimbat and Goodparla pastoral leases, will bring the park to around 20,000 square kilometres in total. Section 36 (c) of the Australian Labor Party platform, as approved by the Thirty-seventh National Conference in Hobart this year, reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . opposing mining or any other activity in national parks which adversely affects the prime function of the park, ie nature conservation.

The Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) said during the Conference that mineral exploration ought to be permitted under strict guidelines. Since the Labor Party and its Environment Minister agree with the principle of exploration and mining in parks as long as strict guidelines apply, let us look at whether mining has, or will, adversely affect the prime function of Kakadu. Earlier I spoke of the vast area of the declared park-12,700 square kilometres. We hear a lot about the wetlands and the stunning beauty of the escarpment, and rightly so. However, at the height of the monsoon season these wetlands cover a maximum of 2,200 square kilometres of Kakadu-about 16 per cent-and that includes the extensive mud flats on the coastal fringe and the miles of mangrove swamps surrounding the river estuaries. The escarpment country covers a maximum 1,800 square kilometres of the park proper. So we are talking about up to 30 per cent of Kakadu National Park with the escarpment covering only about 12 per cent. Page 81 of the original Kakadu plan of management, prepared by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and signed by Professor J. D. Ovington, states:

The escarpment and its outliers provide the most dramatic scenery in the park, as well as being the area of richest Aboriginal value and the most diverse habitat for the terrestrial fauna. Waterfalls and plunge pools are also concentrated in this topographic division.

So the overlord of Kakadu is limiting the majority of the wonders of the area to a relatively small portion of this huge land mass. Let us now hear from another professor on 70 per cent of the park area which is not wetlands, waterways or a river system. Professor Harry Messel of Sydney University has surveyed crocodile populations and studied the river systems in Kakadu. Giving evidence to the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in Sydney in May this year, Professor Messel stated:
Do not get carried away with all the nonsense you read down here about what a wonderful place it is up there.
By `up there' he was referring to Kakadu National Park. He continued:

At most of the places there is nothing to see except bloody mud banks, mangroves and a few buffaloes staggering about. When you get into the upstream section, up in the hills and rocky places, the scenery is very spectacular, but for the hundred odd kilometres downstream to the mouth (of the river) there is very little to see, the crocodiles are the most interesting things.

Keeping in mind that the Whitlam Labor Government halted exploration in Kakadu and hoodwinked mining companies in 1972 and 1973, one can only guess at the wealth this bankrupt nation is forgoing to allow Labor ideologues to experience that familiar warm inner glow. The Northern Territory Chamber of Mines conservatively estimates that there is $40 billion worth of minerals in stage 2 alone, and even the ANPWS accepts $36 billion as a realistic figure. It is not just uranium that will be left in the park. It is also gold, zinc, silver and platinum. Earlier this week gold was bringing $600 an ounce on the world market and platinum was priced at $1,000 an ounce. That makes it a very expensive exercise for Australia, when the danger to the environment in Kakadu National Park now is mostly from feral animals and noxious weeds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to talk about some of the bright spots in our economy, which I am afraid are very much neglected by the media. There are people in Australia who are showing initiative, who are developing techniques and products that we can sell overseas. They are doing so with great success. In the electorate of my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) Solar Optical Australia Pty Ltd is a good example. This company, highly innovative and very technologically oriented, was very competitive in world terms before the devaluation. Since the devaluation the company is killing its competition, and I say more power to its elbow. In Perth there is Underwater Systems Australia Ltd, which markets and has acquired for Australia the world's greatest collection of remote underwater technology. This company took up a study commissioned by Senator Button's Department. It also commissioned its own studies, which have vindicated the Government's original vision. The studies indicate that in the United States of America alone there will be a market for Australia worth $550m a year in four years. This is a tremendous achievement. It makes some of the things that make headlines in this country pale into insignificance.

SPEECH.PARA: We have seen page after page on the problems of Kakadu National Park and a lot of nonsense about uranium mining in Kakadu. Why would anyone want to mine uranium in Kakadu? Uranium is so plentiful elsewhere in Australia. Uranium will eventually be mined in Kakadu, of course. It will be mined in Kakadu when we drill for oil on the Great Barrier Reef. That will be when the middle class runs out of oil. It will be years down the track, but it will happen. USAL has unique products which have a market niched not only in military but also in the leisure market. It is saddening-in fact, it is sickening-to see the sort of support this company gets when our own Royal Australian Navy buys an inferior American product in preference to the Australian product. It is a travesty of justice and an absolutely reprehensible act, and I am still waiting for an explanation. USAL has a market in Australia alone which has been identified by people such as Nelson Wheeler and Arthur Anderson as being worth $20m a year. We believe that that figure will be rapidly exceeded.

Other companies are striving manfully to make headway, companies such as Farmers Tractors of Merredin in the electorate of O'Connor. This company makes arguably the best four-wheel drive tractor in the world and is about to put on the market a utility vehicle which will prove to be superior to the Unimog and substantially cheaper. It should open up for Australian markets in other parts of the world. Again, the United States of America could be a prime target for this company. This company, like many small Australian companies, has cash flow problems. It is expensive to develop these new products and the company has had the experience of going out of its way to develop new products which clients wanted, only to have those clients walk away because they could buy something overseas a little cheaper. I am very glad to say that it is poetic justice that this company, after working very closely with Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd in Western Australia, had Co-operative Bulk Handling opt to buy a Japanese product which was slightly cheaper at the time and certainly not as well constructed but which, since the devaluation of the dollar, has become much more expensive. These are the bright spots in our economy-these and many more. In my opinion it is a terrible shame that the Press does not pay a little attention to the good news instead of being the harbingers of doom that it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the qualities a member of parliament needs more than anything else at this time of widespread cynicism and distrust displayed towards members of parliament is integrity. Whatever the differences of view between me, my colleagues and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), we respect him for his integrity. That is a quality sadly lacking in the majority of Government members, so much so that, following the honourable member's realistic assessment of the Kakadu National Park issue, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) was moved to say `We have trouble with some of our members' and the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) said: `This bloke is more at home on your side than ours'. These people cannot be loyal to each other in any sense, such is the divergence of ideology in the Government. In recent days the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has suffered taunts and ridicule that we in the Opposition could not possibly have dreamed up. It is interesting to note that this abuse is directed at the Prime Minister by people who formerly believed in him, who formerly had some belief in his integrity. The only surprise to us is why it took them so long to wake up to the fact that the Prime Minister is totally lacking in integrity.

SPEECH.PARA: One needs only to refer to a number of his commitments or promises made over the years. (Quorum formed) Let all Government members know that the quorum was called by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie in response to the malicious comments made about him by the honourable member for Throsby and the honourable member for La Trobe. During the speech by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie these two honourable members ridiculed him and more or less said that he had no place in the Australian Labor Party. That is how the Labor Party treats its own. Is there no integrity, no loyalty in this Party? Are its members so lacking in honesty and decency that they ridicule their own as their own are speaking? Let me quote for all Government members the words of the honourable member for La Trobe: `We have trouble with some of our members'. The honourable member for Throsby said: `This bloke is more at home on your side than ours'. That is an indication of the harmony and unity of the Government. It is so racked and distorted by internal factions and so unable to agree to a common point of view that the Australian public is missing out.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my intention to make some comments about the contributions of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Everingham) and the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), but after the lunatic ravings of the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), I think it is not appropriate for me to make any further comments. Therefore, I will proceed with my speech. I want to talk tonight about nuclear waste, something about which the honourable member for Gippsland has no knowledge whatsoever. We should implement a total ban on the processing of nuclear materials until such time as the people of all countries can be assured that a safe method for the disposal of nuclear waste has been found and the present huge and accumulating amounts of nuclear waste have been disposed of. One person who does know a good deal about this sort of thing is the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr Scott).

SPEECH.PARA: At present, no known safe method of disposal exists, as I have reminded this House on a number of occasions during the past six years. The problem of nuclear waste accumulation has now become severe. In 1984 it was estimated that in the United States of America alone there was 2.3 million cubic metres of low level radioactive waste, 77.6 million gallons of highly radioactive liquid waste, 331,000 cubic metres of transuranic waste, 175 million tonnes of radioactive uranium mine tailings and 6,700 tonnes of spare nuclear fuel. By the early 21st century, taking into account the nuclear waste from all countries using nuclear fuel, it is estimated that the accumulated high level of radioactive waste alone will equal about 25 per cent of the natural radioactivity of the oceans. These figures are hard to translate into facts which the public can grasp, but suffice it to say that even the vast amounts of water contained in our oceans cannot tolerate the absorption of such large quantities of nuclear waste without causing grave danger to the human race in the lifetime of many children living today.

It is argued by apologists for the nuclear industry-many of whom, of course, sit on the Opposition benches-that the dumping of other wastes in the ocean, such as sewage, is also harmful. This is true, but the highly toxic nature of radioactive substances, which can last for many hundreds of years, and the ability of marine life to absorb and concentrate radioactive material as part of the food chain mean that it is far more dangerous to human life than the disposal of sewage sludge. Apart from the high potential target from the dumping of radioactive wastes from the known causes, the present knowledge of the biology of the deep seas is very limited. Much more knowledge is required of the fauna which inhabit the deep seas to establish whether radioactivity would pass into the food chain through ingestion by deep sea fauna.

We have now experienced more than 40 years of the nuclear age and significant amounts of radioactive waste have entered the environment. Apart from the more spectacular and serious accidents at the Three Mile Island nuclear reactor in the United States of America and the Chernobyl nuclear reactor in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics there have been many hundreds of minor accidents involving the land, air and sea environments. With the continuing development or major national nuclear energy programs, using both conventional and broader reactors, there will be a large increase in nuclear wastes requiring storage or disposal. The irresponsibility of the leading nuclear power generating countries such as France, Japan, the United Kingdom, as well as the USSR and the USA is beyond measure when one considers that there is no known safe method of nuclear waste disposal.

I point out to the House that there are three principal means by which radioactive waste will reach the Pacific Ocean: First, by the underground testing of nuclear weapons by the French in atolls such as Mururoa; secondly, by the introduction of low level radioactive waste from nuclear reactor operations and the research use of radio isotopes; and, thirdly, by the proposed sub-seabed disposal of high level waste. The last method of sub-seabed disposal of high level waste is not permissible under the existing international treaty. In the time which I have available I will not dwell on high level radiation release as it is not permitted, but suffice it to say that the extremely high danger of such wastes to all life forms is so great that it would have been highly irresponsible if the International Atomic Energy Agency had not recommended the outlawing of such waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most, if not the most, damaging and dangerous features of the Australian political scene that has occurred in the last three years has been the change in standards by which we judge whether something is good or bad. A most recent example to illustrate that point was the way in which the Government, the media, commentators and the Australian community generally welcomed a monthly trade deficit of $1.2 billion. There was a time when Australians would have been horrified by such a result. But not now, because this Government, under the leadership of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has fiddled, fudged and shifted ground so often on economic and social matters that the standard signposts by which we should measure our success or failure have been lost in the quicksand of political expediency. They have created their own myths and are now lost in a fog of broken promises, U-turns and abandoned principles. Why should the Australian people trust the Hawke Government when even members of the rank and file of the Australian Labor Party have been stood up and played for suckers and naive hangers-on? That is what the leadership of this Government has done to its own party members in the last few weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: There is hardly any major policy area that has escaped a U-turn by the Government. I wish to go through a few areas to illustrate the point that I am making. First, there is the area affecting young Australians. In August 1985 the Prime Minister claimed that 10,000 traineeships would be made available in the coming year. But by September this year only 2,025 young people had been put to work in the scheme and only 58 of these had been placed in the private sector. So much for this Government's promises. Then, to add to the planning difficulties of young people desiring a tertiary education, the Government gave all the outward signs that it would not introduce tertiary fees. In the Budget just handed down fees were introduced.
I turn to the area of health. In 1984, during his policy speech, the Prime Minister said:
And now I give this undertaking-that for the term of our next government, the Medicare levy will not be increased.

Yet, within two years we have had a 25 per cent increase in that levy. That means that many families who pay, say, $400 for the Medicare levy will pay another $100 this year. People are not only appalled by the Prime Minister's forked-tongue approach to the truth in relation to health cover, but they are also outraged. They are outraged because not only has the Prime Minister misled the Australian community, but as H. W. Bolles said in a letter to the editor of the Australian today:
The Government is now despicably and spitefully withdrawing day bed subsidy to private hospitals.
Nearly every statement that this Government makes is proving to be a false dawn and a forlorn hope as it gropes in the dark to clutch at straws.

There is no better example of this than the economic solutions peddled by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) over the last year. Remember the J-curve? It was first going to appear in late 1985 and certainly no later than March or April 1986. It has been, and still is, a mythical, forlorn theory that is now regarded in many circles as the jaded Keating curve. In February this year the Prime Minister said:
As far as the Government is concerned, we assert that the economic fundamentals of policy-making are right.
In March the Treasurer said:
The economy has been doing very, very well.
In May he said:
1986 will be a year in which the economy can deal with the imbalance on our external account.
Yet, within five days, he was saying:
If this Government cannot get the internal economic adjustment . . . then Australia is basically done for. We'll just end up being a third rate economy . . .

The Australian people are deeply concerned about the double-talk of the Prime Minister and the Keating U-turns. They have been led up so many garden paths that have led to dead ends that they have lost any faith or any confidence that they ever had in this Government. This Government stands condemned because of its affront to the principles of decency, honesty and trust that Australian people have come to expect of their democratically elected governments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, the matter that I raise in the House tonight concerns human rights in the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. In doing so, I will be taking great pains to avoid any reference to any of the matters that were raised as an official part of the recent Australian Parliamentary Delegation to the Soviet Union and Poland because I think you would agree that those matters are properly dealt with in the report that will be furnished to the Parliament. However, while in the Soviet Union, together with the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), Senator McIntosh and Senator Sanders, I was privileged to meet members of an independent peace group in the Soviet Union which is known as the group to establish trust between the Soviet Union and the United States. Memories of the meeting that we had with that group will live with me all my life.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to recount briefly that meeting to the House and also report the fate of four of the founding members of that group. I pre-empt what I am about to say by indicating that those four members have now been allowed to leave the Soviet Union. The meeting that we were able to have with the trust group in Moscow had about it an air of mystery and intrigue. As anyone who has travelled to the Soviet Union will know, there are major concerns about lack of respect for human rights and we were aware that the trust group was not favourably looked on by the Soviet Union. We had, however, been encouraged to meet with this group by a number of Western peace activists. It was emphasised to us by them and also by Amnesty International the hope that these people relied very much upon contact with the West and also on as much publicity as possible being given to the work that they did.

We went to the apartment where a number of the members of the trust group had gathered. We really did not know what to expect because when the average person hears about an independent peace group in the Soviet Union I think it is fair to say that one does not really know whether it is a creature of the Soviet Government or whether it is a group that is funded or promoted by the Central Intelligence Agency. It is very hard, I think, to understand just what an independent group would be like.

We met with the members of the group, and they were truly an inspiration. They were very independent, very courageous and forthright in their actions. They had contacts with a whole range of Western peace groups and also with the Labour Party in the United Kingdom. Among the courageous actions in which they participated was a public protest, such as it was-a very meek and mild protest-about the Chernobyl nuclear accident. I think it was probably the only protest of a public form in the Soviet Union about that very tragic accident. As a result of that public protest, which involved the wearing of T-shirts and drawing attention to a call for a moratorium on the construction of future nuclear reactors until there is a proper inquiry, they suffered an effective loss of their employment and subsequently, on another occasion, were imprisoned. They displayed, as I have indicated, tremendous courage in raising their concerns.

I am delighted to report that they have now been allowed to leave the Soviet Union, but they express continuing concerns about the issue of human rights in the Soviet Union. I emphasise how important it is to Western democracies that people in the Soviet Union are allowed to have freedom of speech and that groups are permitted to criticise the Soviet Government and to operate independently to express their own public views in support of stronger action by the Soviet Government for world peace.

Having said those things, let me also place on the record that, if we are going to have a serious debate about human rights questions and about issues of nuclear disarmament in the House of Representatives, we have to have an honest debate. I do not think that it is constructive simply to slam everything that the Soviet Union does without also giving support to the constructive initiatives-and there have been some, such as the call for a nuclear testing moratorium-promoted by the Soviet Union. I raise these matters tonight not in an attempt to be partisan, but to highlight what I think are very important issues of human rights and world peace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refresh my colleagues' memories and refer to some of the comments made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) before the Federal election held in 1984. The Prime Minister was careful to say, as quoted in the Hobart Mercury on 9 November 1984:

SPEECH.PARA: These things are going to continue . . . interest rates coming down and a fully operational housing industry.
Two weeks later the Prime Minister was quoted in the Daily Telegraph as saying:
I have been very careful not to make any claims about which I cannot be absolutely certain.

The Prime Minister is fond at election time of referring to claims about which he can be absolutely certain. For example, during the South Australian elections he heaped scorn upon the Opposition for suggesting that there was a case for greater flexibility in housing interest rates. He declared:
I have told Mr Bannon again, not that he had any doubt, that my Government will not lift the ceiling on home mortgage rates.
In early 1986, the Prime Minister is reported in the Canberra Times as saying:
I can't give any assurances other than in regard to housing interest rates where we made it clear we are not going to be lifting that ceiling.

The Prime Minister received support from the Minister for Housing and Construction (Mr West) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Parliament. In November 1985, the Minister for Housing and Construction, a member of the deft Left, or should I say the deaf Left, stated:
There will be no deregulation of savings banks' interest rates, nor do we have any intention of increasing the rate of thirteen and a half percent.
Then on 19 March the Minister echoed the Prime Minister's assurance. He stated:
The Government remains committed to the ceiling on housing interest rates.
The Treasurer got into the act on 20 March, and stated:
I will not be bringing a submission to Cabinet recommending a change in the ceiling.
But barely two weeks later when the Government removed the ceiling for new loans the Treasurer remarked:
We never made a specific commitment about the future lending rate.
That is an interesting comment because the news media and the average Australian seemed to think otherwise. On 3 April, on the Midday Show with Ray Martin, Laurie Oakes stated:
It is a backflip of Olympic Gold Medal standard. The Opposition is referring to it as a U-turn but it is more of a wheely.
On 3 April in the Australian Financial Review, Greg Hywood stated:
It was one of the more remarkable political backflips of recent times.
Michelle Grattan stated in the Age:
It was the old story of the disposable promise.
In the Courier-Mail, Wallace Brown stated:
It is clear that Mr Hawke's credibility will, or at least should, suffer.
Finally, Niki Savva in the Melbourne Sun on 5 April stated:
Next time Mr Hawke gives a cast iron guarantee he shouldn't be surprised or hurt if he is questioned about his sincerity or asked how long the warranty will last.

Madam Speaker, I can assure you that the interest rate issue is affecting the vast majority of Australians. Only a couple of weeks ago, I was speaking to a young lady in my electorate whose husband had lost his job because the company he had worked for had gone into liquidation. A contributing factor was the high interest rates that the company had to pay for its loans. But that couple, with their two young children, did not fall back on the Australian taxpayer. The husband immediately went out and found another job. In doing so, their income fell from about $1,400 a month after tax to about $1,100 per month-a crucial blow to a man and wife with two young daughters. But on top of that their house payments have soared from $436 to $573 a month. That family, just one of many, is struggling for survival in an economy which is being wrecked by this Government.

When the coalition left office, interest rates were 12 1/2 per cent for savings banks, 14 1/2 per cent for building societies and 14 1/2 per cent for trading banks. Today only the building societies have a 14 1/2 per cent rate. The rate of savings banks has jumped to 15 1/2 per cent and the rate for trading banks is over 18 per cent. There is the specific comment in the latest issue of the Economist that Australian banks have raised their prime lending rates by one percentage point to 19 per cent, which implies a real interest rate of 10 per cent, the highest of any country with which the Economist makes a comparison.

Today's reality contrasts cruelly with the electioneering deception of the Prime Minister. At the next election the Prime Minister and his Government will receive the rewards that that deception so richly deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always interesting to listen to Opposition members, especially in the adjournment debate. They come into the chamber and talk about how wonderfully the country was being run under the previous coalition Government. If it was being run so wonderfully, I wonder why the coalition parties have been rejected by the people of Australia in recent years, and not once but twice.
—And a third time coming up.

—As the honourable member says, a third one is coming up. However, I am not here to talk about that subject this evening. Next month, the Indian Prime Minister will visit Australia, and this will provide an opportunity for our two countries to get to know more about each other. There is, sadly, a need for that to happen. We have always had good relations with India, but I feel that not enough has been done on both sides to enable the relationship to reach its full potential. I hope that the visit of the Indian Prime Minister will provide a stimulus of which we shall take advantage so that the two countries can get to know more about each other.

SPEECH.PARA: It was recently my privilege to visit India. Most Australians, when they think of India, imagine it to be a country of poverty, yet I guess that it will come as a surprise to many honourable members that India is the seventh most industrialised country in the world. I just wonder how many Australians realise that. I am surprised by the number of Australian business people who fly over India on their way to and from Europe without stopping there for a period. European markets, through the European Community and other organisations, are, in the main, closed to us, and we should be doing much more to develop a growth in trade with India. The potential is almost unlimited. We must get to know more about the Indians, however, before we can trade with them. I suggest that some of the business people who fly across India on their way to and from Europe should take the time, or make the effort, to stop in India for a week or so to explore some of the business possibilities in that country. One way in which that could be done is by developing more trade through joint ventures with India. It is a country with a huge domestic market and it is ideally placed to trade with the African and Asian nations. The Indian market has been ignored by us and by our business people for far too long and we cannot continue to do so. Indeed, we ignore it at our peril.

In May 1985, there was a business mission to Australia from the Madras Chamber of Commerce and Industry. The object of the mission was to explore the possibilities of increased trade, technical collaboration and joint ventures. It was felt that with Madras being well placed geographically in relation to Australia, active business relations could be developed between Australia and India through the southern ports, which are within a week's sailing time of the west coast of Australia. I met the leader of the mission, Mr Kumar, and other members of the mission, and the high hopes that they had of the mission have in many aspects been fulfilled. I should like to see more business missions coming from India and more missions going to India from Australia.

Something else that I should like to see developed is closer cultural ties with India and more of them. Through culture we can get to know and understand more about each other. I believe that when the Indian Prime Minister visits Australia next month there will be a cultural exchange signed between the two countries, which is something that I would welcome very much. I look forward to the Indian Prime Minister's visit with great enthusiasm because I think that it will be one way of increasing knowledge between two great countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Taxation is the creature of government expenditure, even though some honourable members opposite would have us believe that the reverse is true. The Hawke Government gives a classic example of how the perceived need to spend becomes all consuming; that is all consuming until the need arises to raise taxes to offset its undisciplined approach to expenditure. Then, of course, all the promises of reduced taxes become meaningless things of the past. Words of honour are sacrificed at the altar of expediency and deceit prevails. Although there are many examples of broken promises during the already too long term of this Government, the following is among one of the most outstanding. It belongs to the then Leader of the Opposition, the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in his policy speech on 16 February 1983, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond . . . their powers of misrepresentation and distortion. There will be no new capital gains tax.
With capital gains taxes well and truly with us, so it is that another solemn, unequivocal promise has been broken. The tax is here and only a change of government will secure a return to tax sanity.

The basic problem with a universal capital gains tax is that it fails to draw any distinction between productive investment and speculative investment. Under previous tax arrangements considerable speculative investment was already subject to tax at marginal rates; for example, short term share, property and futures investments. The basic opposition to this capital gains tax remains that not only will risk taking be discouraged through its attack on productive long term investment, making it a prospective tax, but also this capital gains tax threatens to devalue existing assets such as farms and small businesses and is thus a retrospective tax.

Moreover, in designing the capital gains tax to apply to real gains on realisation of assets acquired from 20 September 1985, the tax introduces two additional distortions into the tax system. They are a disincentive to dispose of assets which are now subject to the capital gains tax and an incentive to invest in the family home at the expense of investment in other productive, long term assets. Investments being channelled into the private home might very well run into problems, as my friend the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith) will explain to the public in a few days. While the disincentive to dispose of assets will operate in many areas of the economy, both those distortions can be expected to show up, particularly in the housing market. The family home becomes the new property tax haven, with owner-occupiers raising the equity in their properties through renovation or trading up to more expensive homes. At the same time, residential rents can be expected to rise significantly to the level where additional rental income offsets the capital gains tax. Owner-occupiers will replace the smaller investor and the number of rental properties, particularly new developments, is likely to decline, in combination with the effects of the negative gearing legislation also passed by this Government.

The Australian Labor Party Government does not understand the very strong psychological effect that a capital gains tax has on entrepreneurs and business. This tax will hinder the growth of new investment in this country which is essential for the development of our economy and the consequent growth in employment. Our economy is not yet at the same stage as the economies of the United States of America, the United Kingdom, Japan or West Germany, as some would have us believe. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has quite properly described Australia as a capital scarce nation. We need to encourage capital formation in Australia, not discourage it by imposing a new tax on capital, as has been done.
House adjourned at 8 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Territories, upon notice, on 15 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the Government's plans for (a) the future of Bowen Island and (b) the people who lease part of Bowen Island.

(2) If the Government proposes to take over all of Bowen Island, (a) what amount of compensation will the people who presently lease part of the island receive, (b) when will the lessees be required to leave the Island and (c) what period will be allowed for them to evacuate their belongings.
(3) What provision has his Department allowed in its budget for any compensation for the lessees of Bowen Island.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Bowen Island will be managed as a public nature reserve in accordance with the published Draft Jervis Bay Nature Reserve Development and Management Plan and the Bowen Island Management Action Plan. Public access will be encouraged but under Departmental supervision.

(3) This matter was covered in my Department's appearance before Senate Estimates Committee F on 28 April 1986.
(4) (a) $181,000 over the 3 year period 1986-87 to 1988-89.
(5) Not applicable.
(7) Yes.
(a) The former lessee was informed in writing and orally of specific issues of concern;
(b) Some matters were corrected to the Department's satisfaction; others were not.

(ii) Following the successful rabbit eradication program in 1979-81 the penguin colony occupied additional territory previously rendered unsuitable by rabbits and was estimated to comprise 1,500 breeding pairs by November 1982. No firm estimate of the present population is available.
(iii) Detailed information about other bird species is not available.
(iv) Departmental officers are optimistic that rabbits have now been eradicated from the island. Introduced rats remain the most serious feral animal pest. There are pheasants on the island.
(v) Some of the buildings are in an advanced state of deterioration; others are in better condition. The jetty is in need of repairs.

(9) Detailed scientific studies of Bowen Island were progressively initiated in the early 1970's. Since then a resource data base has been established, detailing the distribution of vegetation communities, wildlife habitat and prehistoric sites. Additional wildlife surveys are planned. Monitoring of specific biological indicators is an ongoing activity.

(10) Ranger services are provided by Departmental rangers stationed at Jervis Bay. Successive caretakers employed by the former lessee have lived on the island, but have not been authorised or expected to perform Departmental functions.
(11) A Departmental ranger will be stationed on the island once vacant possession is available.
(12) Not applicable.
(13) The Department has no evidence to suggest that tuna fishermen pose a threat to the penguins on Bowen Island. The presence of a ranger will provide protection for the penguins.
(14) The boat operated by the Jervis Bay rangers was used on 54 days during 1984/85. The cost of answering this question is estimated at $250.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has he taken to encourage distributors of foreign films to manufacture exhibition prints in Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In September 1983, following discussions between officers of my Department and the major distributors of imported theatrical release motion pictures, the distributors agreed to a trial period in which they would process here an annual minimum of 600,000 metres of release prints for Australian exhibition. This represented about six per cent of imported film distributed at the time.
In the event, distributors have, in each of the years to September 1984 and 1985, processed almost twice the agreed minimum level.
I am very pleased that for both years the distributors have been able to substantially exceed their minimum commitment, even in spite of the downturn they experienced in the last year or so.

However, the aggregate level of local processing of imported films is still only a small proportion of the total film imported. My Department is investigating opportunities for the expansion of film printing in Australia, where the Australian product is competitive with overseas-sourced films. Further discussions will be initiated with the film distributors in the near future, with a view to exploiting these opportunities to achieve an increased level of local film printing.

I believe the film distributors will recognise that increased levels of local printing are commercially feasible, and that the benefits this will provide to the local film industry are also in their long term interests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many accidents involving toxic chemicals have occurred in Australia in each of the last 5 years.
(2) How many (a) deaths and (b) injuries have resulted from accidents.
(3) How many of the accidents arose from violations of the law.
(4) If statistics relating to accidents involving toxic chemicals are not available, what steps will he take to ensure their availability in the future.
(5) What measures has the Government taken for the control of toxic substances.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (4) The need for information, on a national basis, relating to accidents involving toxic chemicals has been of concern to various Commonwealth, State and Territory authorities for some time. There are no comprehensive statistics covering all kinds of accidents nor those which arise from violations of the law. The Standing Committee of the Australian Environment Council has this matter under consideration.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics and the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission (NOHSC) are reviewing current statistics on occupational health and safety with a view to rationalising the data collected by the States and the Northern Territory. The Commission has recently released a discussion paper on the range and type of statistics which should be gathered.
A proposal is currently under consideration by a committee of the Australian Transport Advisory Council on a national system of reporting incidents occurring in the transport of dangerous goods.

The Department of Health operates a national poisons case reporting scheme which is voluntary and includes reports from hospitals and State Poisons Information Centres. Not all poisonings are reported and those that are cover accidental or intentional poisoning by all types of chemicals including therapeutic drugs and household chemicals. Cases reported to the Scheme over the last five years were as follows:
1984-71600 (rounded estimate);
Deaths by poisonings reported were as follows:
The Australian Bureau of Statistics publishes data relating to deaths by the following types of accidents (amongst others):
accidental poisoning by drugs, medicaments and biologicals.
accidental poisoning by other solid and liquid substances, gases and vapours.
accidents caused by hot substances or objects, caustic or corrosive materials and steam.
Because of the size of this statistical report, it has been provided separately to the honourable member.

State and Territory authorities have primary responsibility for regulating the manufacture, storage, transport and use of toxic chemicals and for the prevention of accidents involving such substances.
(5) The Government has taken steps in a number of areas to bring about better management of chemicals by its own initiatives and in co-operation with State Governments.

The establishment of the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission in 1984 initiated greater co-ordination of efforts to make Australian workplaces safe and healthy. Its activities relate to safety in the handling of chemicals, amongst many other issues.

The Government has announced its intention to introduce as quickly as possible a national chemicals notification and assessment scheme. The scheme will provide for evaluation of all new chemicals being introduced in Australia for potential health and environmental hazards and for similar evaluation of chemicals previously introduced which may present hazards.
