QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he investigate whether clause 26 of the Housing Industry Association Agreement HIAV 11 (Victoria) revised edition November 1985 breaches the intent of sections 52 and 53 of the Trade Practices Act concerning unfair practices.

(2) Will he also investigate section 55 of the uniform Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 of Victoria and NSW which purports to revoke the previous compulsion to arbitrate known as the ``Scott v Avery'' clause in earlier arbitration Acts.

(3) Will he investigate whether clause 26 of the Agreement HIAV 11 which was published considerably later than the date of commencement of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 (a) is intimidatory, in view of the fact that no mention is made of disputes being resolved at court, (b) makes arbitration mandatory and (c) makes the award final.

(4) Is it a fact that in the published philosophy of the Trade Practices Commission it is stated that it is important that consumers are not misled and that false claims may not only mislead consumers but provide to those who make them an unfair advantage.
(5) Has Agreement HIAV 11 been approved by the Trade Practices Commission; if not, will he suggest a modification of clause 26 of the HIAV Agreement.
(6) Will he investigate whether any ACT building contracts constitute unfair practices.

(7) Will he prepare for introduction a Contract Review Act to prohibit unconscionable contractual conduct thereby not relying upon the uncertainties contained in clause 21 of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1985.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The Trade Practices Commission, which is responsible for administering and enforcing the Trade Practices Act 1974, is currently making enquiries to determine whether Clause 26 of the Housing Industry Association Building Agreement (HIAV 11) could be misleading consumers as to their statutory rights. Further, the Office of Consumer Affairs is represented on a technical committee set up under the auspices of the Standards Association of Australia following a request from the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers. This committee is preparing standard conditions for domestic home building contracts and contracts for additions and alterations to existing homes. The committee includes representatives from the consumer movement, consumer affairs authorities, the building industry and the home finance industry. It is expected that the inclusion of Scott v Avery clauses in home building contracts, and their relationship with section 55 of the Commercial Arbitration Act 1984 (Victoria), will be amongst the matters which receive close attention by the Committee.

(4) The consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act administered by the Commission are designed to encourage fair and honest business practices, protecting both consumers and ethical traders alike.

(5) The agreement HIAV 11 has not been authorised by the Trade Practices Commission. I would not wish to pre-empt the work of the technical committee of the Standards Association of Australia developing a standard home building contract by suggesting a modification of clause 26. As noted above, I expect that the inclusion of Scott v Avery clauses in home building contracts will be one of the matters examined by the committee.

(6) As noted above, the Office of Consumer Affairs is represented on a Standards Association of Australia technical committee which is preparing standard conditions for domestic home building contracts. When this work is completed, it is hoped that the standard contract will be adopted and widely used throughout Australia, including the A.C.T. In the meantime, however, if the honourable member has information about particular contracts which may breach the Trade Practices Act, I would be pleased to receive it and refer it to the Trade Practices Commission for investigation.

(7) Section 52a of the Trade Practices Act 1974 prohibits a corporation engaging in unconscionable conduct, in connection with the supply or possible supply of goods or services ordinarily acquired for personal, domestic or household use. This section, which came into force on 1 June 1986, is intended to prevent a corporation taking unfair and unconscionable advantage of its superior bargaining position. While the operation of the new section will be kept under review to ensure that it is having its intended effect, I do not see a need at this stage for any change in the provision.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services, upon notice, on 30 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that some project officers have suggested to child care centres that they could charge $80 as a maximum fee plus the $5 permissible gap fee and then add a surcharge for parents with a combined family income of more than $700 per week for child care; if so, does this encourage provision of child care for high income earners at the expense of low income earners.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Project officers have advised child care centres that under the arrangements introduced from 1 April 1986 fee relief subsidies provided by the Government are based on the centre's maximum fee, up to a limit of $80 per week.
If a centre's maximum fee is between $80 and $85 per week, all users are required to pay a gap fee equivalent to that portion of the fee above $80 per week.
If a centre's break-even fee is above $85 per week, the Government is providing transitional assistance during the period 1 April 1986 to 31 March 1987 for that portion of the fee above $85 per week.

In some cases, the child care centre adds a surcharge for costs such as over-award wages or salaries or employment conditions. Conditions which are in excess of awards will not be approved by my Department for fee relief purposes or for transitional assistance.

The Government remains committed to the maintenance of affordable child care for low to moderate income families by continuing to provide fee relief, while at the same time ensuring that the child care needs of users across the entire income scale are met. However, centres have a responsibility to contain their costs so that child care remains affordable.
From 1 July 1986 the fee relief ceiling was increased to $90 a week for those services with a new annual fee due for approval on or after that date.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Everingham The Hon P.A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 2 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a requirement of the Malaysian Government that all applicants for passports, renewals of passports and registrations of births must have the applicant's signature witnessed by a Malaysian Consular official.

(2) Has his attention also been drawn to the fact that this requirement causes much difficulty and hardship to Malaysian citizens and their families who are resident on Christmas Island, which is several thousand kilometres from the nearest Consulate.

(3) Will he discuss with the Malaysian Government arrangements whereby the Administrator of Christmas Island can be given the necessary certification as an authorised person to witness the signatures for applications for these official Malaysian documents.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I am aware that there are some 2,000 Malaysian citizens on Christmas Island whose presence could generate consular work. I accept that their distance from Malaysian consular offices in mainland Australia could cause delays in the carrying out of consular functions on their behalf.

(3) The type and extent of consular services provided by the Malaysian Government for its citizens on Christmas Island is a matter entirely for that Government. The suggestion made by the honourable member has, however, been informally passed to the Malaysian authorities in Kuala Lumpur.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 8 May 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What (a) Federal and (b) State laws or regulations require country of origin of foreign fresh fruit sold in Australia to be indicated to intending consumers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Commerce (Trade Description) Act 1905 and the Commerce (Imports) Regulations made under that Act, prohibits the importation of a range of goods including fresh fruit unless the goods, or in certain circumstances their packaging, are marked to show the country in which those goods are made or produced.

(b) I am unable to provide advice on specific State laws and regulations. I am advised, however, that the Minister for Health has completed negotiations with his State and Territory counterparts on a co-operative agreement to adopt uniform standards applicable to food and beverages in Australia. This draft agreement has been circulated to Premiers with a view to early implementation.

This agreement will mean the application of a single uniform standard throughout Australia and will include the requirement for the labelling of imported foods to include a statement of the name of the country in which the food was made or produced.

The enforcement of these requirements will continue to be a State responsibility consistent with present practice. The honourable member may care to take up his specific queries with the relevant State departments.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 19 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are approaches being made by the Government for reciprocal or additional rights for Qantas to US airports following the decisions of Continental Airlines to increase the number of flights to Australia from the USA, and to provide one stop services from Australia to New York.
(2) Has any such approach been made requesting rights to ports additional to San Francisco and Los Angeles; if so, which ports does Qantas intend to serve.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Last February I announced that Australia would be seeking talks with the United States in order to negotiate better balanced air service arrangements. I explained that the concept of fair and equal opportunity between the airlines of both sides had become distorted over the years and it was time to correct the situation.
One area of serious imbalance in our arrangements with the United States is that of the respective route entitlements of the two sides. These heavily favour the United States at present.

Two rounds of talks have already been held with the United States authorities, in May and August, and further talks are planned. To date discussions have focused mainly on the question of capacity on the route. The question of route entitlements will be pursued in greater depth at a later stage in the negotiations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mildren Mr J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 21 August 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What initiatives have been undertaken by the Australian Electoral Commission to encourage young Australians to enter their names on the electoral roll over the last 2 years.
(2) What has been the cost of these initiatives.

Young Australians also formed part of the target audience for enrolment advertising at the December 1984 Federal election.

(2) It is not possible to provide cost details of all activities for young Australians as these are part of on-going programs for the wider community. However, the following activities can be separately costed:
Item
Brochure: `It's Your Australia: Have a Say' (374,000)...
Resources Kit for Divisional Staff (200 kits)...
